title: Путин победил на выборах президента России
translation:
Chairman of the Russian Central Election Commission Ella Pamfilova reported that Vladimir Putin won the presidential elections in Russia with 87.28% of the votes.
DUSHANBE, March 21 – Sputnik. Vladimir Putin won the Russian presidential elections, which took place from March 15 to 17.
The Central Election Commission officially reports this after processing 100% of the protocols.
Putin won 87.28% of the vote in Russia. In total, more than 76 million Russians cast their votes for the current president.
Other candidates scored accordingly: Kharitonov - 4.31%, Davankov - 3.85%, Slutsky - 3.20%.


The turnout in the elections was 77.49%, in total more than 87.5 million citizens took part.
There were 269 polling stations abroad, and over 388.7 thousand people came to them. More than 281.8 thousand or 72.54% of voters voted for Vladimir Putin.
In Tajikistan, more than 9.5 thousand citizens of the Russian Federation who live on the territory of the republic expressed a desire to vote in the Russian presidential elections.
Polling stations opened in the country on March 17 from 08:00. A total of 6 points operated - in the building of the consular department of the Russian Embassy, on the territory of the Russian Consulate General in Khujand, and for military personnel of the 201st military base and members of their families - four sites in Dushanbe and Bokhtar.

Putin won 93.89% of the votes cast in Tajikistan.
Vladislav Davankov received 1.38% of votes, Nikolai Kharitonov - 0.69%, Leonid Slutsky - 0.37%.
After re-election, Putin will remain in the presidential chair for another 6 years.

The inauguration of the Russian President will take place on May 7. The next day, May 8, deputies of the lower house of parliament will consider the issue of appointing the Chairman of the Government of the Russian Federation.
Let us recall that the Federation Council has scheduled presidential elections for March 17, 2024. Voting in Russia took place over 3 days - March 15, 16 and 17. In total, more than 94 thousand sites operated in the country.
Four candidates registered by the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation were vying for the post of head of state: Leonid Slutsky, Nikolai Kharitonov, Vladislav Davankov and Vladimir Putin.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
translation:
The other candidate is Leonid Slutsky, leader of the Russian nationalist Liberal Democratic Party. He has been accused of sexually harassing a journalist. But Slutsky said the charges were part of a "conspiracy" against him.
Slutsky replaced Zhirinovsky as the Liberal Democratic Party's presidential candidate. Zhirinovsky is a flamboyant populist who has been Putin's election opponent four times and has been widely compared to former U.S. President Trump. He passed away in 2020.
While the presidential candidates from the Communist Party and the Liberal Democratic Party are relatively well-known, the third registered candidate, Vladislav Davankov, a member of the Novosibirsk Party, is virtually unknown outside Moscow.
All three candidates are part of the "systemic opposition" and come from a handful of parties with seats in Russia's State Duma, the lower house of parliament.
All three candidates support the war in Ukraine and generally support the Kremlin's party line.
According to the results of a poll conducted by the VtsIOM agency, 2% to 4% of Russians are expected to vote for them.
Liberal opposition candidate Boris Nadezdin has been refused registration on the grounds that his supporting signature on his candidacy application was "invalid".
Nadezdin, a public critic of the war in Ukraine, said he would recruit independent election monitors and pledged to continue to fight the Supreme Court ruling against him. But he has no chance to run.
He told Al Jazeera in early February that he was being excluded because of his electoral rating - a 5% weekly increase in the number of people prepared to vote for him.
The winter of 2011-2012 saw some of the largest opposition rallies in Russia's post-Soviet era following parliamentary and presidential elections that were widely seen as rigged.
The Kremlin responded with a massive crackdown. Now, it has even more sophisticated tools to silence opposition—identifying individual protesters through facial recognition software and cell phone data.
Any protests "will be canceled and poorly organized," said Sergei Bizyyudin, an opposition activist from the western city of Ryazan who was reportedly forced to leave Russia after trying to register to run in the 2018 presidential election. .
He told Al Jazeera, “Whatever the attitude of the majority of the population toward Putin, this election looks like a show.”

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
translation:
On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 
Referring to the ongoing "special military operations", Putin said that the Russian army is advancing every day, and its current strategy is "not just active defense." "In general, the Russian armed forces have completely taken the initiative." He He also stated that during his new term, he must first achieve the goals of "special military operations" and strengthen Russia's defense capabilities and armed forces.
 
This election has once again highlighted the contradiction between Russia and the West. According to reports, many Western countries criticized the Russian election. A spokesman for the National Security Council of the White House said that Russia's election was "neither free nor fair" and accused Putin of suppressing the opposition. Ukrainian President Zelensky said on March 17 that the vote in Russia was illegal.
 
Putin said at the press conference that Russia's elections are democratic and more transparent than those in the United States. He said that "the whole world is laughing at what is happening (in the United States)" and called the U.S. election "a disaster, not a democracy." Putin said he was not surprised by the West's criticism of the Russian election. "What can you expect from them? A standing ovation? They are fighting us, conducting military battles."
 
Putin said the West "will act in a more sophisticated way" against Russia as a new generation of experts with a more realistic view of the current situation gradually replaces the old ones. He also said that the possibility of a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO cannot be ruled out. If that happens, "we are only one step away from a full-scale World War III... I think no one would want to see this." a little".
 
Earlier this month, Sweden ended its "military neutrality" policy that had lasted for more than 200 years and officially joined NATO. Russia stated that day that NATO expansion is damaging to Russia's security and interests, and Russia will take countermeasures to ensure its own security tactically and strategically.

title: 盘点｜2024年全球有哪些重要选举？
translation:
Russian election
Voting in the Russian Federation's presidential election will be held on March 17, 2024. By then, it will have been more than two years since the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, and it has been a long time since Russia entered the "new normal" of wartime society. The presidential election is largely seen as a vote by the Russian people against the Kremlin-led "extraordinary military operations." According to current predictions from many parties, President Putin is expected to win the election with a high vote rate and continue to lead Russia.
In the West, many observers had predicted that with the deepening of economic sanctions and the prolongation of military conflicts, the daily lives of the Russian people would be increasingly restricted, eventually leading to widespread dissatisfaction with the Kremlin and that Russia could "disintegrate" from within. . But reality has proven that all these predictions have failed.
Ella Pamfilova, chairperson of the Russian Central Election Commission (Central Election Commission), said, “So far, we have received applications from 16 people to become candidates for the Russian presidency.” The Central Election Commission also stated that Russia will The four regions of Ukraine and the Crimean peninsula under its control held general elections.
On December 18, 2023, Putin submitted documents to the Russian Central Election Commission to participate in the 2024 presidential election as an independent candidate and officially registered as a presidential candidate. On March 26, 2000, Putin was officially elected as president. After his first term, Putin served as the president of Russia three times in 2004, 2012, and 2018, taking the helm of this large northern country that spans Europe and Asia.

title: 再干6年，普京能带出一个强大的俄罗斯吗？
translation:
There is no suspense, Putin was re-elected.


According to data released on the website of the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, all votes for the 2024 Russian presidential election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 87.28% of the vote, overwhelmingly leading other candidates.


Russia is about to begin the "Putin 5.0 Era". Next, Putin will serve as President of Russia for at least another 6 years, and possibly 12 years.


Before that, Putin had been the president of Russia for 20 years.


In 2000, Putin won the presidential election for the first time and was successfully re-elected in 2004. He served as president for two terms for a total of eight years. Since the Russian constitution stipulates that the president can only be re-elected once, Putin did not participate in the 2008 presidential election. Then Prime Minister Medvedev won the election to become president that year and nominated Putin as prime minister.


In his first year as president, Medvedev pushed for and signed a constitutional amendment to extend the term of the Russian president from four to six years. After Medvedev's term ended, Putin ran for president again in 2012 and started his third presidential career with an overwhelming vote rate. He was successfully re-elected six years later in 2018 until 2024.


According to the "term clearing" clause of the 2020 Russian Constitutional Amendment, the number of times the existing president has been elected is "cleared" and recalculated. Therefore, this election can be regarded as a "new" election in a "legal sense". After Putin wins the election, he can seek re-election until 2036 after the end of this term.


"Give me twenty years and I will give you a strong Russia." This is Putin's bold statement that has been widely circulated in the market. Although many experts have verified that this sentence did not come from Putin's mouth, people who follow Putin and Russia may have it. This feeling is indeed Putin’s “Russian dream”.


Now, 20 years have passed under Putin's rule. Is Russia strong? Give him another 6 or 12 years, where will he take Russia? Can it bring out a strong Russia?
input:

Putin's extension of his rule over Russia through a rigged election.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
Results of the Russian presidential elections. Infographics
Policy
In Moscow, according to the results of online voting, Putin gains 89.1%, said Olga Kirillova, Chairman of the Moscow City Election Commission. Davankov has 4.4%, Kharitonov has 3.3%, Slutsky has 3.2%. At the polling stations, after processing 100% of the protocols, Putin in Moscow gains 85.13%, the Central Election Commission reported. In second place is Davankov with 6.65% of the votes, followed by Kharitonov (3.84%) and Slutsky (2.83%).
In St. Petersburg, after processing 99.29% of the protocols, Putin gains 81.65% of the votes, said Maxim Meiksin, chairman of the city election commission. Davankov receives 7.01%, Slutsky - 5.13%, Nikolai Kharitonov - 3.49%.
In all new regions, 100% of the protocols of precinct election commissions have been processed. In the Kherson region, Putin has 88.12%, in Zaporozhye - 92.83%, in the LPR - 94.12%, in the DPR - 95.23%. The turnout in the Russian-controlled part of the Kharkov region was 92%, said the head of the military-civil administration Vitaly Ganchev.
After processing 100% in Yakutia, Putin receives 87.79%, in Chukotka - 90.49%, in Khakassia - 85.28%, in Kolyma - 84.89%, in the Khabarovsk Territory - 80.06%, in Transbaikal Territory - 87 .71%. In Chechnya, after processing all the protocols, he scored 98.99%. In Crimea - 93.60%.
In the 2018 elections, Putin won 76.69%, which was a record figure for him.
The turnout throughout Russia was a record 77.44%, 87 million 113 thousand Russians took part in the voting, said the head of the Central Election Commission Ella Pamfilova. According to her, on March 15 the turnout exceeded 36%, on the 16th - 22%, on the 17th - 18%. 2.6 million people voted early.
Abroad, as of 8:30 Moscow time on March 18, over 372.7 thousand people took part in the voting, said Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
In his State of the Union address delivered on February 29, although Putin praised the achievements of the Russian armed forces at the beginning and end, most of the content of the address—the 19 he has delivered since he first became president in 1999— The longest part of the speech - mainly listing the achievements, plans and goals of domestic affairs, has almost no direct connection with the "special military operations" itself.
In addition, Putin’s high approval rating has to some extent concealed the popularity of Prime Minister Mishustin. Against the background of massive Western economic sanctions, Mishustin has also received high approval ratings. Therefore, some observers believe that the Russian people's acceptance of Mishustin actually shows their concern for Russia's internal affairs and people's livelihood.
According to surveys conducted by polling organizations such as Levada, not as many Russians are really keen on supporting military action as imagined. The survey results show that most Russians prefer to start peace talks, although the content of the peace talks they say and the peace talks envisioned by Ukrainians may be very different.
In the long term, rural Russians will have more troubles to worry about: The next generation with a smaller population may see an increasingly functional Russia with roads, housing, schools, health care and other infrastructure. will continue to worsen.
Therefore, Nikita, like many villagers, feels a little ridiculous about the Western public opinion that continues to exaggerate that "if Ukraine falls, it will be Europe's turn." "Westerners have failed to understand this truth: Russia's problem is not to occupy the world and obtain endless land. Our problem now is where to get enough people to fill the existing vast land and make it It won’t be deserted,” Nikita said.
New “voters” in new “territory”
Compared with the 2018 election, four new "regions" have joined this year, namely Luhansk, Donetsk, Zaporozhye and Kherson. For the first time, the population of these lands participated in the Russian presidential election.
Karina, a native of Donetsk, comes from a typical Soviet-style multi-ethnic family. Her ancestors moved from all over the Soviet Union. Family members have not been absent from the Soviet Union's iconic historical moments such as the Great Patriotic War and industrial construction. She is of Tatar, Russian and Central Asian descent.
"Soviet people from all over the world came to Donbas, where they fought against German fascism, participated in mining and industrial construction, and finally got married and had children. This is not only my own 'family myth', but also that of thousands of Donbass A person’s true family history.

title: 俄罗斯大选：普京宣布压倒性胜利，赞俄罗斯民主优于很多西方国家 - BBC News 中文
translation:
Putin mentioned Navalny at a post-election press conference, the first time he has mentioned his name publicly in several years.
Putin confirmed previous reports that he had considered exchanging Navalny for prisoners held in the West, provided that Navalny never returned to Russia.
"I said I supported it, but unfortunately, what happened happened. What can you do? That's how life goes."
The outside world interpreted Putin's remarks as an attempt to refute widespread accusations that he killed Navalny.
Navalnaya's widow, Yulia Navalnaya, queued for six hours to vote at the Russian embassy in Berlin, describing it as part of a protest against the election, saying she put her late husband's name on the ballot and She thanked everyone present, saying that they gave her hope that "everything is not in vain."
In London, one protesting voter said she queued for seven hours to cast her vote.
In Washington, US, activist and lawyer Lyubov Sobol said the protest votes would not be reflected in the Kremlin's election results, "but this solidarity, this symbol is still important."
Russian presidential elections are never a fair contest. The Kremlin tightly controls the political system, media and elections.
Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov received just over 4% of the vote, with other candidates even lower.
None of the three could be called serious candidates, with Kharitonov even praising the president before the election for his "efforts to consolidate the country's victory in all areas."
Millions of Russians voted for Putin to become president for a fifth term, in part because they saw no credible alternative.
But that's all because the Kremlin has eliminated any possible challengers from the political scene. Opponents were imprisoned, exiled or killed.
Previously, anti-war politician Boris Nadezhdin intended to run, but after a large number of Russians lined up to register for support last month, the Central Election Commission disqualified him.

title: 俄罗斯中选委：已有16名候选人报名参加明年俄总统选举
translation:
According to "Reference News" citing a report from Agence France-Presse on the 20th, Russian officials stated on the 20th that 16 candidates have signed up to participate in the presidential election to be held on March 15 next year.
According to the report, Ella Pamfilova, chairperson of Russia’s Central Election Commission (Central Election Commission), said, “So far, we have received applications from 16 people to become candidates for the position of President of Russia.” The Central Election Commission also stated that by then, Russia will hold general elections in four regions of Ukraine it controls, as well as the Crimean peninsula.
It is reported that the Russian Liberal Democratic Party nominated Leonid Slutsky, chairman of the Russian State Duma's International Affairs Committee, as its candidate this week. Slutsky said his candidacy would not "take votes away from Putin." In October this year, former Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) member Boris Nadezdin announced his candidacy through his current "Citizen Initiative Party", which is not among the five parties in the Russian State Duma. In November of this year, journalist Ekaterina Duntsova from Tver Oblast north of Moscow announced that she would run as an independent candidate and announced that she would start collecting signatures.
According to the Presidential Election Law of the Russian Federation, presidential candidates can run for election in two ways: nominated by political parties or self-recommended. Political parties nominate candidates at their respective congresses. Independent candidates must convene an advocacy group of no less than 500 people and collect at least 300,000 signatures from supporters in 40 or more regions. The signatures collected by independent candidates will be submitted to the Russian Central Election Commission, which will complete signature verification within 10 days of receiving the signatures and decide whether to register the independent candidate as a presidential candidate.
According to a previous report by China News Service, on December 8, Putin stated that he would run for president during a conversation with participants at an event held in the Kremlin. According to the Kremlin website on the 18th, Putin went to the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation that day and submitted relevant documents to participate in the 2024 presidential election by self-recommendation.

Nomination of candidates for Russian elections.

Navalny's supporters called on Russian people to go to polling stations around noon on the last day of voting, but not to vote, but to show up to express silent protest. This protest action, which was approved by Navalny during his lifetime, was called the "Noon Anti-Putin" demonstration.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
translation:
How the elections took place
For the first time in history, presidential elections were held in Russia over three days. The corresponding legislative norm was enshrined in the law “On the elections of the President of the Russian Federation” on March 14, 2022. According to this document, the decision on multi-day voting (no more than three days) is made by the Central Election Commission, which on December 8, 2023 decided to hold voting in exactly this format - on March 15, 16 and 17. This was explained by the goals of “creating additional opportunities for the implementation of citizens’ voting rights.”

Election legislation allows for early voting at polling stations in hard-to-reach or remote areas, on ships at sea, at polar stations, as well as in countries where there are no Russian diplomatic missions. On March 14, 2024, CEC Chairman Ella Pamfilova reported that more than two million voters voted early in 42 regions. For comparison: in the 2018 presidential elections, according to the Central Election Commission, 268,163 people took part in early voting.
input: Voting at Russian diplomatic missions abroad.

title: 俄议会通过宪法修正案二读草案，普京再度参选总统出现可能
translation:
On March 10, local time, the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament) passed the second reading of the draft amendment to the Constitution of the Russian Federation (hereinafter referred to as the "Constitutional Amendment").
According to RIA Novosti news on March 10, the Russian State Duma held a second reading of the draft amendment to the constitution that day. 382 deputies who participated in the State Duma plenary session voted in favor of the draft, 44 deputies abstained, and no one objected. In preparation for the second reading of the draft, the State Duma received nearly 400 opinions on constitutional amendments regarding state construction and legislation, of which about 200 were taken into consideration.
On the 10th, Russian President Vladimir Putin went to the State Duma to deliver a speech, expressing his disagreement with the removal of the limit on the number of Russian presidential terms in the Russian constitution, but also revealed his intention to run for president again after the constitution is revised.
According to RIA Novosti, before Putin arrived at the meeting, Valentina Tereshkova, a member of the "United Russia Party" and the world's first female astronaut, proposed that the limit on the number of presidential terms should be removed from the constitutional amendment, or that the limit on the number of presidential terms should be removed. After the constitutional amendment takes effect, the current president's term of office shall be counted from zero.
"It is proposed to remove the limit on the number of presidential terms, or to add a clause in the amendment: after the new constitution takes effect, the current president, like other citizens, has the right to run for president of the country." Tereshkova said.
Putin responded by saying that removing presidential term limits from the constitution was unreasonable. In the long run, society should ensure that the change of power occurs, which is necessary for national development.
"I believe and am convinced that strong presidential power is absolutely necessary for our country. However, the public should guarantee that elections (including presidential elections) are open and competitive." Putin further said.
According to a report by "Russia Today" (RT) on the 10th, Putin is not opposed to the possibility of running for president again in 2024. He considered a change of power crucial to Russia's dynamics, but also said that if the amendments are approved by the Constitutional Court, the former head of state should be able to run for office in a new presidential election under the updated constitution. Regarding this idea, Putin emphasized that in the upcoming referendum on April 22, "only if citizens support such a proposal" can such a proposal become a reality.
Putin also said: "Since the initiative to amend the constitution comes from me, I would like to express my position here. The constitutional amendment has long been mature, and I firmly believe that the amendment will be useful to our citizens, it will strengthen our sovereignty, our traditions and Our values." He said he hopes to work together with members of the State Duma to work for the country until 2024, "and we will see how things develop then."
According to previous reports by Russian media, if the second reading goes well, the Russian State Duma will conduct a third reading of the draft constitutional amendment at 10:00 Moscow time on March 11. It will then be voted upon by the Federation Council, followed by approval by two-thirds of the legislative assemblies (local assemblies) of the subjects of the Russian Federation, and then reviewed by the Constitutional Court for specific provisions, and finally submitted to a referendum.
The referendum is scheduled for April 22. If more than half of the citizens who vote support it, the constitutional amendment will take effect on the day the voting results are announced.
Putin proposed amending the constitution when delivering a State of the Union address to both houses of the Russian Parliament on January 15, and a constitutional amendment working group was formed on the same day. On January 20, Putin submitted a draft constitutional amendment to the Russian State Duma. On March 2, Putin submitted the second reading draft of the constitutional amendment to the State Duma.

And during this New Year's holiday, in most festively decorated Russian cities, there was little to suggest what was happening in Ukraine.
However, concerns about Russian border shelling and Ukrainian drone strikes remain. The public's fatigue with long-term special military operations began to show at the end of 2023.
But in mid-February, Ukraine announced its withdrawal from Avdeyevka, an important town in the Donetsk region. title: Путин победил на выборах на фоне сообщений о нарушениях
translation:
Some voters admitted that they voted for the incumbent president due to the lack of a real alternative

MOSCOW - Russians went to the polls on Sunday to take part in a presidential election whose outcome few doubted.

Even preliminary results, released shortly after polling stations in the Kaliningrad region closed, showed that incumbent head of state Vladimir Putin had secured victory in an election that critics say was staged.

According to the latest data from the Russian Central Election Commission, published this morning in Moscow, Putin received more than 76 percent of the vote - a record result for his entire reign, as announced by Ella Pamfilova, chairman of the Russian Central Election Commission. It is unclear whether the Kremlin succeeded in achieving its goal of raising turnout to 70 percent - according to the latest data from the Russian Central Election Commission, it was 67.7 percent of all Russian voters. However, these data are not yet final, and Kremlin officials insisted that this figure would be achieved after all the calculations.

During the voting, there were reports of hundreds of irregularities with ballot papers at polling stations in different parts of the country. Election officials played them down, saying only that the reports were being investigated.

Putin's closest rival, candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Pavel Grudinin, as Pamfilova reported, according to the processing of more than 99 percent of the ballots, he received 11.8 percent of the votes.

The Kremlin may have encouraged some candidates to run in the elections to make them appear competitive. Surrounded by weak rivals, Putin, who has been in power since 1999 when he succeeded Boris Yeltsin, was initially guaranteed victory in the election, which coincided with the fourth anniversary of Russia's annexation of Crimea.

Putin's only real rival, blogger and activist Alexei Navalny, was barred from running due to a criminal record that he believes was staged to prevent him from running as a candidate. Navalny and his supporters said on Sunday that across Russia, voters were being bused to polling stations.

Deputy head of the Central Election Commission Nikolai Bulaev rejected claims of violations, saying: “No country in the world is as open as we are. With such a degree of openness, every slightest violation is visible.”

However, videos posted by activists online show gross violations. At one polling station in the Republic of Sakha, a member of the election commission throws ballots into a box while voters wait in line to vote. An observer was beaten in Dagestan when he refused to stop filming an illegal vote. Another video shows a young woman stuffing ballots while observers are distracted.

While Russian citizens were voting, the main question was: what will the turnout be?

Kremlin officials were clearly focused on achieving huge results for Putin to demonstrate his legitimacy, and by mid-afternoon, hours before polls closed, election officials were projecting turnout to be as high as 70 percent.

Kremlin insiders said before voting day that the desired outcome would be a “70-70” result: 70 percent of the vote for Putin with a 70 percent turnout.

On Sunday evening, the Central Election Commission announced that more than half of Russia's adult population had already voted, and turnout exceeded that of the previous elections, which took place in 2012.

Some analysts believe the March 4 nerve agent poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal, which British authorities blame on Russia, was planned to provoke a confrontation with the West to boost turnout and support for Putin on a patriotic wave.

This suggestion was categorically rejected on the eve of the election by Putin's aides, who said Russia was not involved in the poisoning. Some officials claim that the incident was staged by British authorities.

The deterioration of British-Russian relations has given some voters pause. At a polling station in Moscow school No. 1250, businessman Alexey said: “I think all these allegations were concocted by the British government. I don't think anyone poisoned Skripal. Our country did not poison anyone.”

Police officers roamed across the street from the school, ready to respond to protests that had been talked about but never materialized.

Most Muscovites interviewed by the Voice of America correspondent said that Putin is the ideal candidate. Some voters explained that they support him because he has restored Russia's power and transformed the country from a regional power to a global one.

Before the vote, Putin emphasized the restoration of Russian power. This was especially noticeable in his message to the Federal Assembly, in which he stated that the world was now forced to listen to Russia.

There are still these challenges in the next six years
Putin also said that he will continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of Parliament and that every effort will be made to achieve the set goals.
In his annual State of the Union address before the election, Putin outlined in detail Russia's political and economic goals for the next six years. For example, in the next six years, Russia's non-resource and non-energy exports should increase by two-thirds; by 2030, Russia's imports as a share of GDP should drop to 17%; and the share of Russian domestic high-tech products in the domestic market should increase by 1.5 times. At the same time, Putin also mentioned that Russia should vigorously develop AI.
Regarding this State of the Union address, Zhang Hong, a researcher at the Institute of Russian, Eastern European and Central Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, told China Business News: "By introducing future plans for domestic and foreign affairs, Putin conveys confidence to Russian voters and outlines the overall plan for Russian society."
The latest data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service show that the Russian economy will grow at a year-on-year rate of 3.6% in 2023, reaching 171.04 trillion rubles; the real wages of Russian people will increase by 7.8% year-on-year; the real disposable income will increase by 5.4% year-on-year. The latter two are the highest in the past five years. In addition, Russia's unemployment rate was 3.2% last year, the lowest level since 1992.
Looking to the future, Wei Jinshen, associate professor at the School of Politics and International Relations at Lanzhou University, believes that Russia will face many major challenges in the next six years, such as how to deal with the international and regional environment worsened by the Russia-Ukraine conflict, thereby creating a better environment for Russia's development. Favorable space; at the same time, the Russian government also needs to consider how to promote the optimization and adjustment of the domestic economic structure to cope with the impact of sanctions on the domestic economy and transform the current wartime economy into a normal economy.
In addition, what measures to take for social mobilization and strengthening the unity of Russian domestic society will also be one of the important tasks of Putin's new government in the future.

translation:
Vladimir Putin, 71, has been in power for more than 20 years. He was initially appointed caretaker president by former President Yeltsin and won his first general election in March 2000.
Between 2008 and 2012, he changed roles and became prime minister, but still maintained full control of the government. At that time, the Russian constitution stipulated that the president could only serve two consecutive terms, so switching to prime minister allowed him to run again.
After amending the constitution in 2020, Putin is widely expected to remain in power until 2036.
He will then become Russia's longest-serving ruler, surpassing Communist leader Joseph Stalin and 18th-century Empress Catherine the Great, both of whom ruled for more than 30 years.
Russian elections are rarely nerve-wracking events, but they are important for the legitimacy of those in power and for signaling public opinion.
This time it is particularly important for Putin not only to win, but to see high turnout and support, as Russia is embroiled in an all-out war that will have lasting consequences for Russia and the world at large.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举正式投票开始举行
translation:
At 8:00 local time on March 15, official voting for the Russian presidential election began in the Chukotka Autonomous Region and the Kamchatka Krai.
Russia spans 11 time zones, and voting will begin in the Far East first, with voters in the Kaliningrad region voting last. There are three voting days in the election and will end on the 17th.
Previously, early voting for the Russian presidential election was launched on February 25, and some voters in inaccessible and remote areas began to vote on that day. Russian voters living abroad can also vote early starting March 1. In addition, affected by the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, voting for the presidential election began in advance on March 10 in 9 regions in Russia's Belgorod region adjacent to the Russian-Ukrainian border.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission, there are approximately 112 million registered voters in this election, with more than 94,000 domestic polling stations and 295 overseas polling stations in more than 140 countries and regions. Observers from international institutions such as the Commonwealth of Independent States, the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and the Collective Security Treaty Organization monitored the elections. More than 1,400 journalists from Russia and other countries covered the election.
There are four candidates running in this presidential election, including current President Putin.

Russia spanning 11 time zones.
Russian voters living abroad voting early starting March 1.

Participation of current Russian President Vladimir Putin in a presidential election with three other candidates.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
However, Andre's mood always took a turn for the worse when the topic turned to the war. Although he did not personally experience the cruelty of the war, the two-year war still left a deep mark on his heart. Around him, there were people who were fighting on the front line, facing blood and death, and there were also people whose lives were stuck at the age of 25 forever under bullets. "Terror" and "terrible" are the adjectives he most often uses when talking about war.
On one side is the war with no end in sight, on the other side is life that must go on. How to continue to explore one's own life in a fragmented reality is a question that young Andrei and many ordinary Russians must face.
For the future, Andrei has simple and slightly naive expectations: "I hope everyone can live in peace. I hope Ukrainians will come to Russia and drink our red cabbage soup, and we can also go to Ukraine and drink theirs." Beetroot soup. I want American burgers on our table and our pancakes on their table, honestly, I don’t want to find out who’s right and who’s wrong, I just want this to end.”
When Andre talks about the war, the first thing he thinks of is his friend Sasha, who is currently fighting on the front line. "Almost every Russian today knows someone on the front line," Andrei said. "Sasha is a childhood friend of mine who has been fighting on the front line since the beginning of the conflict. We haven't been in touch for a long time... I Hope he survives."
In September 2022, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a partial mobilization order, announcing that 300,000 reservists would be recruited. This is the first time Russia has launched military mobilization since World War II. Putin said at the time that "first of all, those who have served in the armed forces and have certain military expertise and relevant experience will be called up for military service." "Those who are called up for military service must receive additional military training before being deployed to the troops. ".
Unlike the Russian people who were conscripted during the war, Andrei's friend Sasha had already voluntarily joined the army before the outbreak of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict and became a contract soldier. Before joining the army, Sasha was just an ordinary construction worker and had a younger sister at home. At that time, for those who did not receive higher education and were in good physical condition, joining the army was a good option to obtain a higher salary. There are also some highly educated people who choose to join the military, where they receive higher wages and different responsibilities than others.
"Before February 2022, being a contract soldier is not that scary. They don't need to fight at that time, and the army's salary for contract soldiers has always been very high." Andre said.
Andre also added that during the war, contract soldiers were paid higher, with a minimum monthly salary of around US$2,000 (approximately RMB 14,000), and some even received US$3,000-5,000 (approximately RMB 22,000- 36,000 yuan). If you destroy some enemy weapons and equipment, you will get additional rewards.

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
translation:
According to the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), Navalny's supporters did hold symbolic protests during the Russian presidential election, but they did not have any impact on the election results.
 
Putin also mentioned the death of Navalny for the first time in his victory speech. He said Russia's elections were democratic and the protests triggered by Navalny's death had no impact on the results. He also called Navalny's death a "sad event."
 
In fact, the turnout for this election in Russia hit a new historical record. According to "Russia Today", Russia's Central Election Commission stated on March 17 that in the three-day general election, more than 74% of Russia's 112 million voters participated in the vote, which was the highest turnout in Russia's modern history.


On March 15, voters registered to vote in the presidential election in St. Petersburg, Russia. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter An Xiaomeng
 
The last time Russia had such a high turnout was in the first presidential election in 1991, when the turnout was about 74%. The turnout rate in subsequent general elections has generally been between 64% and 69%. The turnout rate for the 2018 general election was 67%.
 
Voter turnout was also high in the four regions participating in Russia's presidential election for the first time - the Russian-controlled Donetsk People's Republic in eastern Ukraine, the Lugansk People's Republic, the Kherson region and the Zaporozhye region. . The voting rates in the four regions were 88%, 87%, 83.7%, and 85% respectively. In September 2022, these four regions will hold a "referendum" and agree to join the Russian Federation.
 
This election is the first three-day presidential election held in Russia. Voters across Russia can vote from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. on any of the three days from March 15 to 17.

title: 普京胜选表态:竭尽所能实现国家主要任务和目标
translation:
China News Service, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Tian Bing) Russian presidential candidate and current President Vladimir Putin said at his first press conference after the election voting on the 18th that he would do his best to achieve the country's main tasks and goals.
At 7:00 a.m. Moscow time on the 18th, the Russian Central Election Commission announced the counting results of 99.43% of the votes. Putin won 87.32% of the support in the 2024 presidential election. Putin has actually won the election.
Kharitonov, the candidate nominated by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, received 4.32% of the votes, Davankov, the candidate nominated by the Russian New People's Party, received 3.79% of the votes, and Slutsky, the candidate nominated by the Russian Liberal Democratic Party, received 3.19% of the votes.
Putin came to the campaign headquarters near the Kremlin to deliver a speech in the early morning of the 18th, and then held a press conference.
Putin said that the source of Russian power is the people, and the votes of every Russian citizen constitute the unified will of the people. He will continue to promote national development in his new term.
Putin pointed out that all the main tasks and goals of Russia's development have been elaborated in the recent State of the Union address to both houses of parliament, and he will do his best to achieve the set goals. Russia will move forward and become stronger, more powerful and more efficient.
Regarding the Ukrainian issue, Putin stated that the initiative on the frontline of the special military operation against Ukraine lies entirely in the hands of the Russian army. The issue of special military operations and strengthening Russia's defense capabilities are one of the main tasks of his new term. He said that Russia supports peace negotiations, but not just because the other side is running out of bullets, but if they truly, seriously and long-term hope that the two countries can establish peace, Russia supports negotiations on the Ukrainian issue. "This is a very serious issue."
Putin also said that considering the Ukrainian army's attacks on Russia's Belgorod region and other places, Russia does not rule out the possibility of establishing a "safe zone" in the border area at some point.
Regarding the United States, Putin once again stated that Russia has no preference for any American presidential candidate and that Russia is ready to cooperate with any American leader that American voters vote for.
When answering the question of whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO is possible and how likely it is, Putin said, "Everything is possible in the modern world." He pointed out that there are currently military personnel from NATO countries in Ukraine, and they are "dying in large numbers."
Regarding Sino-Russian relations, Putin said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary. Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.
Putin spoke positively of China's development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those who seek provocation around Taiwan and take various measures to delay China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. The Russian-Chinese Election Commission announced that it will confirm the final results of this presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.

title: 普京胜选后有人公开唱反调,俄共候选人:社会主义俄罗斯才有前途
translation:
On March 18, the 2024 Russian presidential election finally came to an end. With 87.82% of the vote, Putin took away a total of more than 76 million votes nationwide and ascended to the throne of Russia's president without any doubt. There are a total of four candidates running in this Russian presidential election. In addition to Putin, there are also Slutsky, Kharitonov, Davankov and others running, but it is obvious that all three of them are "running with them" character of. However, among these three people, Kharitonov is relatively eye-catching because he is a candidate promoted by the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and is also the deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma. After Putin won the election, he publicly sang the opposite tune and said that only a socialist Russia has a future.
Kharitonov has run for office several times before, but was defeated by Putin each time. After the 2024 presidential election, he started his old propaganda again. In an interview with Russian media, Kharitonov claimed that only when Russia restores its socialist system can the country's development have a future. Putin naturally doesn't care about his rhetoric. Because Putin is now the real "talker" in the political arena, he naturally doesn't need to pay too much attention to other people's irrelevant remarks. But it is probably not absolute to say that Kharitonov's words will not stir up any waves in Russian society.

title: Раз, два, три, четыре, пять — честность я иду искать. Как прошли выборы-2024 в цифрах
translation:
The presidential elections in Russia lasted three days. From March 15 to 17, Russians doused trash cans with green paint, set tablecloths on fire, dressed up as emperors and tsars, and even prayed. While the election commissions were adjusting the results to the “required” level, “7x7” also decided to count the election results.

They poured brilliant green, iodine, paint and ink into the ballot boxes to ruin the ballots. According to the head of the Central Election Commission, they were promised money for this and instructed by telephone from abroad. We noticed such cases in 16 regions. The rating is headed by the Voronezh region and Moscow. There, residents painted the ballot boxes three times; see our map for more details. In 33 cases, the Ministry of Internal Affairs opened criminal cases under the article on “obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights.”

Voters burned ballot boxes, tablecloths, voting booths and other items at polling stations. They threw smoke bombs, Molotov cocktails and firecrackers. In seven cases the arson fires were successful.

The reasons for the arrests are different: the security forces did not like the scarf with an Orwell quote, the attempt to throw Navalny’s photo into the ballot box, and children’s scribbles on the ballot papers of a mother who came to the station with her one-and-a-half-year-old child.

A third of them are under the article “on obstructing the work of the election commission” (Article 141 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation).

Depicting or mentioning any candidate at a polling station is considered illegal campaigning. In the Altai Territory and the Murmansk Region they refused to remove the portraits because they are a “state symbol.”

In Krasnodar, PEC member Ruslan Khubaev and observer Dmitry Korolev were detained after reporting the stuffing and several administrative protocols were drawn up against them. Khubaev was accused of petty hooliganism and displaying extremist symbols on social networks, and Korolev was accused of disobeying the police.

Pavel Sychev, an observer in Voronezh, persuaded the commission to remove the thrown ballots from the ballot box.

One of them was Nadezhda Pinegina, a voting member of the commission. On March 15, she poured greenery onto an electronic ballot box. The head of the Central Election Commission, Ella Pamfilova, called her a “freak.”

In the Trans-Baikal Territory, voters came to the polls in the images of Ivan the Terrible, Joseph Stalin, Catherine II, Alexander II, Alexander Nevsky and Peter I. In Chita, Alexander II the Liberator apologized for the sale of Alaska, and Stalin came to “scare the enemy.”

Singer SHAMAN crossed himself three times before throwing his ballot into the ballot box. And the mufti of the republic, Akhmed Abdulaev, together with his wife, organized a collective prayer at a polling station in Dagestan.

At the PEC at Novosibirsk State University, he was beaten by the candidate from the New People party, Vladislav Davankov. True, at the polling station in Altai Barnaul, where Nikolai Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation first won, after reports about this in the media, they decided to count the votes in Putin’s favor. In Vladivostok, according to the exit poll of Nadezhdin’s headquarters, Vladislav Davankov received 41% of the votes, and Vladimir Putin - 19% at the Far Eastern Federal University.

title: 克宫：普京尚未就是否参加2024年俄总统选举发表任何声明
translation:
According to a report by TASS on November 6, quoted by Global Network, in response to Reuters citing sources who said that "Putin has decided to participate in the next Russian presidential election", Russian Presidential Press Secretary and Kremlin Palace Spokesperson Peskov responded that Putin has not yet made any decision. Make any statement whether to run in the 2024 presidential election.
Previously, six sources revealed to the outside world that Putin has decided to participate in the Russian presidential election to be held in March next year, and this move will allow him to be in power until at least 2030. The above-mentioned sources also said that Putin's advisers have begun preparations for the election and are expected to make an announcement soon. Peskov responded: "Putin has not yet made any statement on this. The campaign itself has not yet been officially announced."
According to Russian news, the Russian presidential election is expected to be held on March 17, 2024. The Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament) will officially set the election date in December 2023, after which political parties will hold pre-election meetings and formally nominate candidates.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
In addition, Slutsky also said: "I hope to win in special military operations. But defeating Putin - no, I do not expect to do this. Why? Putin is the most influential politician in the world."
Kharitonov: The oldest candidate to have participated in the Russian presidential election
Nikolai Kharitonov was born in a village in Novosibirsk Oblast, Russia, in 1948. He is a member of the Russian Communist Party. Kharitonov has been a member of the State Duma since 1994, and will serve as chairman of the Russian State Duma's Far East and Arctic Development Committee in 2021.
In 1972, Kharitonov graduated from the Novosibirsk Agricultural College (now Novosibirsk State Agricultural University). In 1995, Kharitonov received an associate doctorate in economics from the Institute of National Economics under the Russian government.
Before the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Kharitonov was a member of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. From 1976 to 1994, Kharitonov served as the director of the "Galinsky" state farm. In February 1993, Kharitonov co-founded the Russian Agricultural Party. In the same year, he was elected to the Russian State Duma for the first time. In 1999, after a split within the Russian Agricultural Party, he first appeared on the list of Duma members of the Russian Communist Party.
In 2004, Kharitonov represented the Russian Communist Party in the Russian presidential election that year and ranked second with 13.69% of the vote, second only to Putin (71.31%).
After the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in 2022, Kharitonov was sanctioned by Western countries for supporting the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk and Russia's "special military operations" against Ukraine.
On January 18, 2024, Kharitonov submitted his campaign platform. His campaign slogan is: "We have played with capitalism, now enough!" He called on the Russian economy to "turn to the left" and advocated changing social and economic policies, developing industry and agriculture, increasing pensions and wages, and Said that the key to Russia's development lies in the Far East. In addition, he also said that the main issue at present is "war and peace." He said that the Russian Communist Party "came with peace, bread and goodwill" and would help the country get out of the "systemic crisis."
In February, Kharitonov and the leader of the Russian Communist Party Zyuganov met with participants of the "Special Military Operation" at the Lenin State Farm.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
The conflict between Russia and Ukraine has lasted for more than two years. From March 15th to 17th, Russia ushered in the six-year presidential election. This election is Russia’s first presidential election since the adoption of constitutional amendments in 2020, and it is also the country’s first “wartime election.”
Valery Ferodov, chairman of the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center, previously talked about Russian social sentiment before the election and said that from the announcement of delayed retirement in 2018, to the new crown epidemic, to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the risks Russia faces and threats are increasing day by day, anxiety has become a basic emotion in Russian society. But at the same time, the process of adaptation is also underway. Most people are not interested in who started the war and why it happened. The most critical question is when will all this end and how can it end as soon as possible.
Ferodov believes that "special military operations" may have different meanings for every Russian. It may be a long-awaited move, an opportunity to earn a decent income, a shock and trauma, or an inducement to emigrate. But in any case, apart from those who have left Russia, Russians who remain in the country still regard Putin as their protector.
"Everyone realizes that we are in the same boat and if we run in a different direction now, the situation will only get worse," Ferodov said.
On March 13, 2024 local time, citizens voted in early voting for the Russian presidential election in Mariupol, Donetsk region.

title: 普京胜选后欧盟援乌调门依旧坚定，但准备好真金白银了吗？
translation:
On March 17, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Russian presidential candidate and current President Putin addressed the media at the campaign headquarters. Visual China Map

The Russian presidential election ended without any surprises. Putin was successfully re-elected. For the EU, this is a result that everyone has expected. Countries have probably already prepared corresponding rhetoric. On the evening of March 17, EU countries had begun negotiations on the wording of the joint communiqué. On March 18, the foreign ministers of the European Union gathered in Brussels. Among them, the foreign ministers of the Eastern European countries were as sharp as ever in their evaluation of the Russian election. The Lithuanian Foreign Minister was the first foreign minister to be interviewed by reporters that day. When the reporter mentioned his views on Putin's successful re-election, his first reaction was: "Your wording is really tolerant and generous." He then said that the EU Countries will naturally issue a joint statement on the Russian election, but the top priority right now is to continue to discuss how to support Ukraine.
Putin's increasingly solid power is a consensus among EU countries regarding this election - Russia is unlikely to change direction in the short term. Under such circumstances, and against the background of the protracted conflict between Russia and Ukraine, it is not surprising that French President Macron said some time ago that he would not rule out sending French soldiers to Ukraine. If the EU's determination to continue to support Ukraine remains unchanged and Putin will continue to be at the helm of Russia, then, in order to continue to support Ukraine, EU countries will naturally increase their measures.
However, behind its insistence on continuing to assist Ukraine, the dilemma faced by the EU is also obvious: Ukraine is significantly weaker than Russia in terms of population, strength, etc. The new international situation also determines that Russia can maintain economic growth even without relying on the West. India, the "democratic star" favored by Western countries, has blatantly helped Russia circumvent Western sanctions.
At the same time, internationally, the EU certainly cannot cause a world war; within the EU, EU people are naturally not prepared to sacrifice their lives for Ukraine. At the same time, the possibility of Trump winning the US presidential election at the end of this year has also made diplomats in Brussels nervous.
The EU has long expected Putin's election, but for the EU, the "hard battle" only begins now.
On March 18, 2024 local time, the Foreign Ministers’ Meeting of EU member states was held in Brussels, Belgium. EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Affairs Josep Borrell attended the meeting. Oriental IC map

Continued funding and support for Ukraine is the focus of the EU Foreign Ministers' Meeting on the 18th. EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Borrell believes that at the meeting on the 18th, EU countries can reach the main terms of a new round of sanctions against Russia, as well as the death of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. Pass additional sanctions against Russia.

title: ﻿普京成功连任 得票率逾87% _大公网
translation:
Picture: Russian President Vladimir Putin won re-election again with an overwhelming advantage. Preliminary vote counting results announced by Russia's Central Election Commission on the 18th showed that current President Putin won the presidential election with more than 87% of the vote, significantly ahead of other candidates. Putin said that the election results reflected the trust and expectations of voters. Analysts believe that after Putin's re-election, Russia's domestic and foreign affairs will continue its existing policies, including focusing on strengthening technological independence, promoting economic diversification, actively developing relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, and promoting the development of a multi-polar world. .
The official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission announced the results of 100% of the votes on the 18th. Putin received 87.28% of the votes, winning the fifth presidential term with a huge advantage; the Russian Communist Party candidate Kharitonov ranked third with about 4% of the votes. 2; New People’s Party candidate Davankov and Liberal Democratic Party candidate Slutsky ranked third and fourth respectively.
Russian media said that Putin’s vote share set a record in contemporary Russian history; the turnout rate in this election exceeded 73%, also a new high. China, India, Cuba, North Korea, Bolivia and other countries congratulated Putin. Catholic Pope Francis also congratulated Putin on his re-election as president of Russia. The United States, Britain, Ukraine and other countries accused the Russian election of being "unfair". Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that the Russian people's high support rate for Putin shows that Western countries' remarks about the unfairness of the Russian election are groundless.
​
input:
Putin's re-election as President of Russia.
Developing diplomatic relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and Latin America.
Putin's vote share and turnout rate set new records in the 2024 Russian presidential election.
China congratulating Putin on his re-election.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
In addition, Putin also stated that Russia's strategic nuclear forces are in a state of full readiness, and any armed intervention in Russia will suffer an unprecedented defeat and encounter a conflict involving the use of nuclear weapons. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin’s speech can be regarded as his campaign platform to a large extent.
On the eve of the election, Putin's team also released a series of campaign videos. In one of the videos, a very Russian image of a bear and a taiga appears. Putin himself does not appear in the video, but provides a voiceover for the video. Putin said that there are always people who want to chain the bears living in the taiga and remove their teeth and claws, but the bears "will never give their taiga to anyone."
Davankov: The youngest candidate, emphasizing the resolution of the Russia-Ukraine conflict through negotiation
Vladislav Davankov was born in Smolensk in 1984. He is a member of the Russian New People's Party and Vice Chairman of the State Duma. He was once active in the business community. On February 8 this year, the Russian Public Opinion Research Center conducted a poll by telephone interview, surveying a total of 1,600 Russian citizens over the age of 18. Among those who plan to vote, 75% said they would support Putin in the general election, and 5% said they would support New People's Party candidate Davankov.
Davankov's grandfather Vadim Davankov is a chemist, his father Andrei Davankov is a military pilot, and his uncle Alexander Davankov is the owner of the famous Russian cosmetics company Faberlic. One of the founders. After graduating from local high school, Davankov entered the History Department of Lomonosov Moscow State University, majoring in American history, and graduated in 2006. In 2008, Davankov received an associate doctorate in sociology from the Russian State Social University. After graduation, Davankov chose to go into business. Since 2013, he has served as vice president of Faberlic, a company founded by his uncle. According to Russian media reports, Davankov has also been involved in many fields such as finance, manufacturing, and IT.
Davankov's political career began in 2020. At that time, his uncle Alexander Davankov co-founded the New People's Party (новые люди) with Alexei Nechaev, another founder of Faberlic company. Davankov himself also participated in the formation of the party and was mainly responsible for the work of the party's regional branches and managing campaign activities.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
translation:
This is an election without much suspense. The 71-year-old current Russian President Vladimir Putin is almost certain to win re-election in the voting that starts on March 15.
However, according to the "term clearing" clause of the 2020 Constitutional Amendment (signed on April 5, 2021), the number of times the existing president has been elected is "cleared" and recalculated. In this case, the election from March 15 to 17 was considered a "new" election in a "legal sense".
Even if there are no surprises, no one will deny that this is an unusual election. With the prospect of a ceasefire in the Russian-Ukrainian military conflict still unclear, everything from careful mobilization of soldiers to the selection and design of nationwide inspection sites, from election issues The focus of the setting, the avoidance of risks, the description of the future vision, and the publicity... all reveal the subtle changes in Russia's domestic political life and the country's political elite's unusual sensitivity to the international environment.
The outside world has been paying close attention to Putin's campaign and campaign trends in the past few months, trying to get a glimpse of the Russian top leader's next governing goals and gain insight into the current stable state of Russia's ruling system.
On December 8, 2023 local time, Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a speech at the "Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony held in the Kremlin. The pictures in this article are all Visual China data maps

The election campaign focuses on people's livelihood, and domestic political stability is guaranteed
Last December, at an elaborate "Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony in the ornately decorated hall of the Kremlin, I met with Artyom, Chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic" who was dressed in perfect uniforms and decorated with medals. While talking with Dzoga, Putin announced his candidacy.
"I won't hide it. I had different ideas at different times," President Putin said with a grim expression. "But now, the moment has come when a decision must be made. I will run for president of Russia."

The predictable outcome of the Russian election.
Putin delivering a speech.
"Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony in December 2023 at the Kremlin.

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
translation:
Xi Jinping has worked hard to develop his relationship with Putin since the Kremlin launched the war more than two years ago, strengthening trade, security and diplomatic ties while refusing to abandon the "uncapped" partnership with Russia announced weeks before the invasion.
China has paid the price for this. China claims to remain neutral and refuses to condemn the invasion, raising suspicion in Europe about its motives. NATO's annual report released last Thursday reflected the organization's tough stance on China, with NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg saying Beijing "does not share our values" and "challenges our interests." ” while noting that Beijing is increasingly aligned with Moscow.
Steve Tsang, director of the China Institute at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London, said before the results of the Russian election were announced, "Xi Jinping regards Putin as a true strategic partner."
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi also acknowledged Russia's election results, saying he looked forward to strengthening New Delhi's "special, time-tested and superior strategic partnership" with Moscow. India, China and Russia belong to the BRICS emerging economy group.
At present, India is strengthening its relations with the United States and calling for peace in Ukraine, while on the other hand it is purchasing discounted oil from Russia.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un was quick to congratulate Putin on his victory on Monday, according to North Korean state media. Kim Jong-un, accused by the West of supplying arms to Russia, has stressed his desire to further expand bilateral ties with Moscow. In September last year, he met with Putin in the Russian Far East. This is Putin's rare overseas trip. Washington said the focus of this trip is Moscow's purchase of arms from Pyongyang. Kim Jong-un urgently needs to withstand coordinated suppression by the United States and South Korea and continue to develop nuclear weapons. Close ties with Putin are to support his shaky economy. an important opportunity.
The sanctions-hit Iranian government has been expanding cooperation with Russia and supplying it with drones and munitions. Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi also congratulated Putin.

title: ﻿俄大选投票三天 普京支持率86% _大公网
translation:
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from March 15 to 17. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin and three other candidates will run for the next president. The conflict between Russia and Ukraine has lasted for more than two years. Under heavy restrictions from Western sanctions, the Russian economy has shown resilience. Last year, its GDP grew by 3.6%, higher than the global average. Analysts point out that many voters in Russia are satisfied with the economic performance, while some believe that only Putin can maintain social stability. According to statistics from the Levada Center, a well-known Russian polling agency, Putin's current support rate is 86%, which is much higher than the 71% before the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Putin is expected to obtain more than 80% of the votes.

[Ta Kung Pao News] This election is the first presidential election since the adoption of the constitutional amendment in 2020, and it is also Russia’s first wartime election. About 110 million Russian citizens have the right to vote, and people in the four regions of eastern Ukraine that will be merged into Russia in September 2022 can also participate in voting. This is the first presidential election held in Russia with a three-day voting period. Voting will start at 8:00 and end at 20:00 every day from March 15 to 17.
This election introduced remote electronic voting for the first time. In some remote and inaccessible areas, voters began voting in advance on February 25; voters living abroad began voting in advance on March 1. As of March 14, approximately 2 million voters had completed voting. 
Putin is regarded as Russia’s “crisis manager”
A total of four candidates participated in this presidential election, including current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russian Liberal Democratic Party's Slutsky, Russian Federation Communist Party's Kharitonov and Russian New People's Party's Davankov. After Russia's 2020 referendum to amend the constitution, the number of presidential terms will be reset to zero, allowing Putin to serve two more terms from 2024 to 2036.
A poll conducted by the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center on March 11 showed that the turnout rate for this presidential election will exceed 70%, of which 82% of the respondents are ready to vote for Putin, and the support rate for the other three candidates is 6. %about. The media predicts that Putin is expected to easily win with more than 80% of the vote, surpassing the 76.7% vote rate in 2018.
The 72-year-old Dushko voted for Putin on the 15th, saying that he "chose a trustworthy person to be the leader of the country."

Obtaining more than half of the votes in a presidential election.

Putin's role as Russia's crisis manager.

title: 俄罗斯大选普京连任 西方各国指责“不公、不合法” | 俄罗斯总统 | 执政时间最长 | 斯大林 | 新唐人电视台
translation:
[New Tang Dynasty News, Beijing time, March 19, 2024] The Russian presidential election ended. Putin was re-elected with an overwhelming majority of votes. Western countries criticized the election as unfair and illegal.
The Russian election ended on Sunday (March 17). President Putin won this "election without a real opposition candidate" with 87.28% of the vote and was re-elected.
On Monday (18th), Western countries such as the United States and the European Union criticized the Russian election.
A spokesman for the White House National Security Council said, "With Putin imprisoning the opposition and preventing others from running for president, this election was neither free nor fair."
NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg: "It is completely illegal for Russia to organize elections in the occupied areas of Georgia and Ukraine."
European Commission Vice-President Josep Borrell: “More importantly, this election was based on repression and intimidation, was held in occupied Ukrainian territory and violated Ukraine’s sovereignty. "
The German Foreign Ministry issued a statement on the social media platform X: "Putin's rule is authoritarian. He relies on censorship, repression and violence."
British Foreign Minister David CAMERON said on the X platform: "The election was illegally held on Ukrainian soil and voters lacked choice."
While Western countries unanimously condemned the election, the Communist Party of China, Cuba, North Korea and Venezuela expressed congratulations to Putin on his re-election.
Analysts worry that after Putin is re-elected with an overwhelming majority, he will implement larger-scale repression in Russia.
Natalie Sabanatz, senior fellow at Chatham House's Russia and Eurasia Program: "In fact, at the same time that Russia was launching a war in Ukraine, Putin was launching a special operation inside Russia. In these 87 % (Putin’s vote share), I expect there will be greater repression in Russia.”
If Putin is successfully re-elected, his term will be until 2030. At the same time, he will surpass Stalin and become the Russian leader with the longest reign in more than 200 years.
Comprehensive reporting by NTDTV reporters Zhao Fenghua and Mingyu

Putin's re-election as President of Russia.

title: «Россия – это Путин»: политические последствия 87% президента
translation:
But everything is in vain, everything is useless. The Russian economy is not only not collapsing, but growing. The country courageously and calmly endures all the hardships of non-peaceful times, all its troubles and deprivations. As for the prospect of an internal political split, here you go - 87% for the current president. Take a bite and slander as much as you like that these 87% are supposedly “not real.” They are real. And the turnout figures close to 75% are also real. It’s not for nothing that in the voting queue at the Russian embassy in Berlin one could notice such characters as Yulia Navalnaya and Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who are not at all sympathetic to Putin. (recognized as foreign agents in the Russian Federation,)

Even a completely radical and completely non-systemic opposition recognizes - if not in its words, but in its deeds - the legitimacy of the elections. In short, the elections took place and demonstrated the unprecedented consolidation of society, its unprecedented unity around the current president and the political course he is pursuing. And it is not just words. These are words that will have great political consequences. Vladimir Putin received a gigantic mandate of trust - a mandate that gives him the right to absolutely any political actions, any political initiatives and any political maneuvers - both within the country and abroad. Of course, the GDP had such a right and such a mandate even before the 2024 elections. But now this mandate has been renewed, strengthened and formalized. fix the collapse of the Russian economy and political system.
