title: «Россия – это Путин»: политические последствия 87% президента
translation:
What will it be like – Putin’s new six-year plan? We don't know and can't even guess. Who, for example, based on the results of the last Russian presidential elections in 2018, could have predicted the turbulent events that occurred in February 2022 and the equally turbulent events that are happening now? Nobody. French President Macron almost daily promises to send troops to fight Russia. Six years ago, such a forecast could easily send its author to a madhouse. Let us therefore directly acknowledge the inadequacy, limitations and failure of our imagination and our ability to predict and anticipate. Everyone around is speculating, but Putin (we, of course, do not touch God and take him out of the political equations) has it.

Therefore, I will limit myself to a prediction that can be 100 (okay, 87) percent certain. Victory over Kharitonov, Davankov and Slutsky is the easiest of the tests that Vladimir Putin has had and will still have to go through in 2024. Such characters as Biden, Zelensky, Macron, Sunak, Scholz, Borrell and further down the list can, of course, be mocked if desired. But these figures are definitely not ready to lose with such a devastating score. On March 17, 2024, Putin’s Russia completed, albeit an important, but the simplest political task of those that lie ahead of it.

title: 俄罗斯大选：精心控制的投票将让普京获得第五任期 - BBC News 中文
translation:
Ovchinnikov uses his art not only to comment on the present, but also to shed light on Russia’s dark past – the repression of the Stalinist era. His graffiti criticizing the war in Ukraine did not go over well with the authorities and was quickly painted over.
“My paintings make people think: Are we right or wrong in this conflict?” Ovchinnikov told me. "I consider this a crime against the territorial integrity of neighboring countries. If I remain silent, I condone this behavior."
"A lot of people do stay silent because they're afraid of being repressed, they're afraid of losing their jobs, they're afraid of being criticized."
After Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny died in prison, Ovchinnikov painted Navalny's portrait on a local monument commemorating victims of political repression.
“That same day, someone wiped it off,” Ovchinnikov told me. "But at home, I drew a rough sketch on cardboard. So I later placed it next to the memorial."
How does Ovchinnikov see the future of Russia?
"There are predictions of more repression," he said. “We are moving towards totalitarianism and total dictatorship.”
Ovchinnikov told me that he never watches television.
Once he turned on the TV, he saw a very different picture of Russia on state media.
That’s Putin’s version of Russia.
There were no mountains of human skulls, no meat grinders, no mention of Navalny.
This is not a Russia that expands externally and suppresses internally, but a Russia with a glorious past and an equally glorious future. This country has many heroes, and patriots unite under the national flag to defend the motherland from foreign aggression.
This is a Russia that loves its current leader.
A few days ago, Russia's Channel 1's evening news broadcast showed Putin's fans greeting the president as if they were star-struck.
"Take care of yourself," one woman shouted before kissing the president.
"Long and healthy!" a man shouted.
If you relied solely on Channel 1 for your news, you might conclude that Putin has a good shot at a landslide victory in the presidential election.
But, like painting, context is important. Context here is crucial.
The Kremlin controls not only Russian television but the entire political system, including elections.
President Putin faces no serious challenges as he seeks a fifth term. His most strident critics are in exile abroad or in jail at home. Navalny, his fiercest rival, is dead.

translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin consolidated his power with a landslide victory in an election widely criticized as lacking democratic legitimacy.
At a post-election press conference, Putin said the results vindicated his decision to defy the West and invade Ukraine.
"No matter who they want to intimidate, no matter how much they want to intimidate us, no matter how much they want to suppress us, our will, our consciousness, no matter how much they want to suppress us, our consciousness," Putin said in a speech at his campaign headquarters early Monday morning. The will, our consciousness, no one in history has ever succeeded in anything like this.”
"It doesn't work now and it won't work in the future. Never."
Shortly after the last polls closed on Sunday, early polls concluded what everyone expected: Putin will extend his nearly quarter-century rule for another six years.
He received about 87% of the vote, with about 60% of precincts counted, according to Russia's Central Election Commission. The result means that the 71-year-old Putin will surpass Joseph Stalin and become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.
Preliminary results showed Communist candidate Nikolay Kharitonov in second place with just under 4% of the vote, with newcomer Vladislav Davankov in third , ultranationalist Leonid Slutsky ranked fourth.
Election officials said polls closed with a national turnout of 74.22%, exceeding 2018's level of 67.5%.
Putin's victory was by no means certain as most of his critics were in prison, exiled or dead, while public criticism of his leadership was suppressed.

translation:
Well, what about the election winner himself? In his triumphant speech, Vladimir Putin thanked voters for their high trust and promised to continue to defend Russia’s national interests and ensure its sovereignty and security. At the same time, he harshly condemned the West’s attempts to interfere in the country’s internal affairs and “rock the boat” under the guise of a struggle for democracy.

“Russia itself determines its own destiny and chooses its own path of development. And we will not allow anyone to dictate their terms to us or impose alien values,” the president emphasized. Well, it seems that Moscow’s foreign policy course will remain unchanged after 2024.

So, despite all the complaints and questions, the voting results cannot be attributed solely to fraud and administrative pressure. Vladimir Putin really has many sincere supporters, especially among older people, state employees, security officials and residents of the provinces. Many of them believe that only he is able to protect the country from external threats, ensure order and social stability. Some support the existing foreign policy and ambitions of the Kremlin.

Of course, the real level of support for the president is unlikely to reach the official 87.28%. But the fact that more than half of the voters are ready to vote for him is a fact that must be taken into account. The opposition still has a long way to go to offer society an attractive alternative and win the sympathy of the majority. In the meantime, Putin remains the most popular and influential politician in Russia.

[Ta Kung Pao News] Comprehensive reports from Reuters and the Associated Press: Russia will hold voting in the presidential election for three consecutive days from the 15th to the 17th of this month. President Putin, who is seeking re-election, issued a video speech on the 14th, calling on the people to vote. At the same time, Ukraine intensified its attacks on the Russian border. Local officials in Belgorod Region stated on the 14th that Ukraine launched at least 8 missiles, killing 2 people and injuring 12 others. Some shopping malls had to be closed.
In a video speech on Thursday, Putin called on the Russian people to actively vote and participate in the general election to show their patriotism. He pointed out that the election results will directly affect the country's development in the next few years. He emphasized that in this difficult period, Russia faces complex challenges in various fields. To overcome all these difficulties, the Russian people must be united and confident.
Putin also pointed out that frontline soldiers who have shown courage and heroism in defending their homeland will also participate in the vote. They participated in elections and set an example for everyone.
According to the Russian Federation Council, voting in the presidential election will be held for three consecutive days from the 15th to the 17th of this month. A total of four candidates, including Putin, have registered to compete for the president. The Russian president-elect will take office on May 7 and will serve a six-year term. If no candidate obtains more than half of the votes of voters participating in the voting, a second round of voting will be held 21 days later by the two candidates with the most votes.
As Russia is about to hold a presidential election vote, Ukraine has increased its attack power on the Russian-Ukrainian border. The Kremlin accused Ukraine of interfering in Russia's elections, saying it fired at least eight missiles at the Belgorod border area, killing two people and injuring 12 others. The Ukrainian army also tried to conduct a cross-border attack in the Kursk border area, but was repelled by the Russian army. Ukrainian heavy drones launched an attack on Russia's local oil refinery on the 13th, causing a fire at Rosneft's largest refinery.

title: А президент-то рисованный
translation:
Vladimir Putin won the presidential election for the fifth time and was elected to another six-year term. The incumbent president received 87% of the vote with a turnout of 77%. The Kremlin was counting on approximately these indicators and regional administrations throughout Russia were focusing on them. Until this moment, similar numbers in elections were recorded only in the republics of the North Caucasus - regions with the highest level of electoral fraud in favor of government candidates. “New-Europe” tells how to evaluate stuffing using statistics.

Without taking into account electronic voting, based on the results of processing 97% of the protocols, 74.5 million voters took part in the elections. Of these, 64.7 million people, according to the Central Election Commission, voted for Putin. However, this is not the only record indicator of the past presidential elections. In terms of the level of fraud, these elections surpassed all previous presidential and parliamentary elections (with the exception of voting on amendments to the Constitution), and the methods of depicting the results also differed.

We previously published an estimate of fraud at 31.6 million, which is based on the method of physicist and election statistics expert Sergei Shpilkin. But this year’s elections are so “dirty” that standard methods of analyzing fraud work with reservations.

In the case of fair voting, the distribution of polling stations based on turnout and the result of the winner should have one “cloud” of relatively even shape. In the case when ballots are stuffed, both the turnout and the result increase for the leader, and thus the “cloud” grows a “tail.”

Almost always, in this case, the “honest core” remains visible, taking which as a starting point, one can evaluate falsifications. This was possible at all federal level votes in Russia until this year.

However, in 2024, it is almost impossible to identify the “honest” core of results: most of the votes are concentrated in the area that is usually considered to be fake.

The reason for this may be not only direct falsifications, such as stuffing, but also “administrative resources,” that is, forcing state employees to vote. All this blurs the “cloud” and makes analysis difficult. Almost all votes for Putin are in the area where the result increases with turnout, while for alternative candidates (especially Davankov) this relationship is reversed.
input:
Recorded electoral violations.
Vladimir Putin received approximately 87% of the votes in the Russian presidential election according to the Central Election Commission.
Processing of election protocols in Russia.
Election Falsifications.
Forced voting in elections.

title: 快讯！拿下87％选票 普京宣布连任总统-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
translation:
Voting in the Russian presidential election has ended. Officials announced that after nearly 72% of the votes were counted, current President Putin won 87.17% of the votes. Putin himself announced at his campaign headquarters that he had won the re-election, and that Russia's strongman president would continue to dominate the country for another six years.
Comprehensive foreign news reports indicate that Putin’s vote share in this election is the highest in all previous presidential elections. In the last presidential election in 2018, he was re-elected with 76.7% of the vote, which was the highest vote share in any previous presidential election in which he participated. The highest rate ever.
The 2000s to the present are the era of Putin. He was elected president for the first time that year and has been in power for 24 years. If he is re-elected this time, he is expected to surpass the former Soviet leader Stalin and become Russia's longest-ruling ruler in 200 years.
The Russian presidential election has more than one voting day. Voting started on the 15th and ended on the 17th. The turnout rate exceeded 73%. More than 8 million people voted online. Among the officially counted votes, Putin received an overwhelming number of votes. , the vote rates of the other three presidential candidates fell around 3% to 4%.

Putin's continued dominance of Russia.
Putin's re-election as President of Russia.
Putin surpassing Stalin as Russia's longest-serving leader.

title: 普京连任后将首访中国？克宫：正在筹备总统的数次出访活动
translation:
According to Global Network, the voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election has ended. Putin was successfully elected as the President of the Russian Federation and will start his fifth presidential term of six years. Putin said on March 19, local time, that he was considering making China the country he would visit for the first time in his new term.
According to a Reuters report on March 19, a person familiar with the matter revealed that Russian President Vladimir Putin will visit China, and the relevant details were confirmed by four other sources. One of the sources said Putin will travel to China in May. This may be Putin's first overseas trip in his new term.
When the Kremlin was asked whether Putin would visit China, Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov responded, "Preparations are currently being made for several visits by the president and several top-level contacts. As the date approaches, we will Inform you.”
According to Xinhua News Agency on March 18, President Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. Xi Jinping pointed out that China attaches great importance to the development of China-Russia relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era to the benefit of the two countries and their peoples.
From March 15th to 17th, Russia held a presidential election. According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission website on March 18, local time, all votes in this election have been counted. Preliminary data shows that current President Putin received 76,277,708 votes, with a vote rate of 87.28%.
On March 18, Li Hui, head of the Chinese Observer Group for the Russian presidential election and the Chinese government’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, submitted a statement on the Chinese Observer Group’s observation of the Russian presidential election to the Chinese and Russian media. The statement stated that the Chinese observer team believed that the Russian presidential election was democratic, transparent, and fair, and that the election process was smooth and calm, and no irregularities were found. The election results are the independent choice of the Russian people. China respects the choice of the Russian people, sincerely congratulates President Putin on his re-election as Russian president, and believes in and firmly supports Russia in achieving national stability, development and revitalization.
Global Network quoted the latest news from Russia's TASS news agency that at a meeting with various parties in parliament on the 19th, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Zyuganov asked Putin to choose Beijing as the destination for his first visit. "I hope your first visit (of the new term) will be to the East, not the West." TASS quoted Zyuganov as saying. Putin responded with a smile, "I will definitely consider what you said seriously, I am not joking."
input:

China congratulating Putin on his re-election.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
Putin's current term as President of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after this term ends.
At the Heroes of the Motherland Day award ceremony in December 2023, Putin announced that he would participate in the 2024 presidential election. At that time, Artem Zoga, chairman of the People's Committee of the "Donetsk People's Republic", talked with Putin after the ceremony and said that the entire Donbas region hopes that Putin will participate in the election. Putin responded: "I had different ideas at different times, but now the moment has come when I have to make a decision. I will run for president of Russia."
In this Russian election, Putin is the only presidential candidate running as an independent candidate. Some analysts believe that Putin has run as an independent candidate in three of his four elections. This approach will help him shape his image as a representative of all Russia, rather than just representing a certain party.
As in previous elections, Putin will not participate in pre-election debates on television and radio programs. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin is the current head of state and has a very busy schedule, which makes him fundamentally different from other candidates. The president himself appears in the media every day, and Russians have a daily opportunity to see what Putin has to say about all aspects of life.
Although he did not participate in the pre-election debates, Putin frequently appeared in various domestic activities before the Russian election. After announcing his candidacy, at the end of 2023, Putin held his first "live connection" event and annual press conference since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. In more than 4 hours, he answered about 80 questions from the Russian people and domestic and foreign reporters. The content covered is very wide. At the event, Putin pointed out that the Russian economy had recovered from the downward trend, emphasized that the goals of Russia's "special military operations" had not changed, and also mentioned the need for Russia to return to traditional values.
After entering 2024, Putin’s domestic itinerary is relatively intensive. From the Chukotka Autonomous Region in Russia’s Far East, which he has never visited before, to the enclave of Kaliningrad in western Russia, Putin talked about the regional economy during his visits to many places. Development, social security and other livelihood issues, and visited a number of industrial enterprises including Ural Vagon Zavod (one of the largest military equipment developers and manufacturers in Russia) and Kazan Aviation Plant to understand the business operations of the enterprises.
In early February, Putin accepted an exclusive interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson. This was Putin's first one-on-one interview with Western media since the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in February 2022. In an interview, he emphasized that Russia would not expand the Russia-Ukraine conflict to other parts of Europe, and said that only if the United States stops providing weapons to Ukraine can a peaceful solution to the conflict be possible.
In his two-hour State of the Union address on February 29, which set a new record in length, Putin focused on people's livelihood issues and repeatedly emphasized that Russia should solve population problems, promote economic development, and achieve technological independence.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
How security is ensured
In regions bordering Ukraine, elections are being held against the backdrop of ongoing drone attacks. In Belgorod, since March 12, a missile danger was declared every day.

In the Belgorod, Kursk, Rostov regions and Crimea, voters can vote remotely. In the Belgorod region, increased security measures have been taken at polling stations: in the voting premises there are signs “Place for shelter”, the windows are lined with sandbags. In the Kursk region, security measures have also been strengthened at sites.

The governor of the Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported on the morning of March 15 that more than 80% of voters in nine border municipalities of the region voted early. “Due to a threat to the life and health of voters,” the regional election commission allowed early voting to be held from March 10 to 14 in nine border districts of the region.

title: В США раскрыли причину ненависти лидеров стран НАТО к Путину
translation:
MOSCOW, June 4/ Radio Sputnik. The leaders of NATO countries avoid establishing relations with Russia, since the leadership of these countries does not have politicians of the level of Russian President Vladimir Putin, says American professor and international relations specialist Michael Brenner.
"
"Putin clearly surpasses them (Western leaders - ed.) in intelligence and knowledge, he has a broad outlook and deep knowledge in various topics. And (US President Joe) Biden, for example, can hardly connect three sentences. Putin has excellent diplomatic and political skills. Not to mention the fact that under him Russia returned to the international arena as a major player,” the expert said in an interview with the Dialogue Works YouTube channel.

Brenner also said that the West prefers to avoid direct contact with the Russian president and has disliked him since the presidency of Barack Obama.
He estimates that in the past the United States and European countries have held more talks with the leadership of the Soviet Union than they currently hold with Putin or anyone else in Russia. According to him, such a situation could lead “to disastrous consequences.”

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
translation:
But there were plenty of scandals and violations. Observers and oppositionists have recorded hundreds of violations throughout the country - from ballot stuffing and “carousels” to pressure on voters and falsification of protocols. The situation was especially hot in Moscow and St. Petersburg, where the police harshly detained protest participants, and some hotheads even attacked polling stations.

Regarding falsifications. I present the calculations of analysts, which were made using the method of mathematician Sergei Shpilkin. They estimated the share of “anomalous” votes in the last elections and claim that Putin received at least 31.6 million votes through fraud. And this is approximately half of the votes. They claim that there was so much falsification that it is almost impossible to identify the area of “honest” votes using statistical methods (scroll through the photo).

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
According to Russian media analysis reports, in 2023, the production of the Russian defense industry and other industries related to military needs will increase by 35% year-on-year, and the growth rate of the construction industry involving military infrastructure and reconstruction will also reach 15%. Such a large-scale war economic expansion naturally involves rural areas. Starting from the end of 2022, people in Village A have been leaving their homes to become workers in military production, or to join construction teams in newly occupied areas.
But the so-called "economic overheating" of Russia due to the war seems to be more of a joke in a difficult situation, a blessing in misfortune. At least in major Russian cities, the impact of sanctions imposed by the West is obvious. Foreign brands have left one after another, and cross-border financial transactions of companies and individuals have been severely affected. Among ordinary people, Nikita's former colleagues were among the most affected.
Western sanctions since 2022 have mainly targeted the Russian middle class or wealthier people, aiming to divide the cohesion between the Russian elite and the wealthy middle class. For example, middle- and high-income people are prohibited from traveling to Europe and the United States. It is common for international students going to Europe and the United States to be deported and have their studies interrupted. Young Russians who originally wanted to study in the West have lost their qualifications to apply this year.
However, in places like Village A, this rather strong measure seems to have had some counter-effects:
"Now those rich people in Moscow can't just take their families and children abroad!" "Yeah, what's so bad about Russia that they have to go to the enemy?" "Isn't going to Paris and London a holiday shopping trip? To support the enemy?" These are comments that can often be heard on the streets.
Nikita found that she could not use the experience of her previous circle to try to gain the understanding of her new neighbors. And as time went by, he also believed that, aside from the jingoism and nationalism mixed in these comments, the neighbors’ views were not entirely unfounded.
"Actually, I have to admit that the so-called urban elites were very out of place before the war. They, no, it was us," Nikita let out a shy laugh and hastily changed the subject, "Always buy Western brands, go When we go on vacation in the West, use Western websites, and interact with Westerners, we seem to have forgotten that there is still a countryside in Russia. But now, it seems that everyone is brought together again, using the same brand of products, watching the same TV programs, and in the same land. "Business and rest. In other words, in the eyes of the villagers, the war finally made Russia more like Russia."
russian fortress
It is somewhat absurd and ironic that a war has such unexpected effects, and strategic analysts on both sides of the war may be surprised by this. However, in the vast Russian land, the situation in Village A is far from unexpected and accidental. On the contrary, it is just a microcosm of thousands of small villages and towns located in the hinterland of Russia.

title: 普京刚胜选,给了中方一个明确信号,拜登的指责,看起来荒唐可笑
translation:
Putin’s victory draws attention from China and the West
At 8 pm on March 17, in the presidential election held in Russia, Putin was re-elected as president with a high vote rate of 87.21%, and will start his fifth presidential term. After his victory, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters, mentioning plans for the new term and looking forward to the situation in Russia and Ukraine. Analysts believe that the results of this election will profoundly affect Russia's future development, especially its stance and future development direction in the Ukrainian conflict. At the same time, in a series of statements, Putin also gave China a clear signal, emphasizing that Russia-China relations will continue to deepen and develop.
1. The international impact of Putin’s victory
The results of the Russian election showed that Putin received as much as 87.21% of the votes. This result will undoubtedly attract widespread attention from the international community. Putin's victory means that Russia's political situation is stable, which will have a profound impact on the international situation. Especially under the current international situation, Putin's return to power will trigger different views and attitudes between China and the West. The US and the West’s concerns and uneasiness about the Sino-Russian alliance will also intensify.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
translation:
During the election days, Ukrainian armed forces continued their attempts to break into Russian territory, which they began on March 12. On March 16, it was reported that saboteurs were attempting to break into Russian territory in the areas of the settlements of Spodaryushino and Kozinka. The DRG entered from the territory of the Sumy region of Ukraine, all attempts, according to official data, were repulsed. Russian aviation and artillery targeted the Ukrainian Armed Forces fighters. The saboteurs lost up to 30 personnel, as well as 3 tanks, 2 other armored vehicles and 2 MLRS vehicles.

Press Secretary of the Russian President Dmitry Peskov said that the losses of the Ukrainian Armed Forces during the attempt to invade Russia in the Belgorod and Kursk regions on the night of March 16 amounted to 60-70 percent.

On March 17, the head of the Main Intelligence Directorate (GUR) of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine, Kirill Budanov (listed as terrorists and extremists by Rosfinmonitoring), commented for the first time on the attacks on Russian border regions, promising that they would continue in the near future.

Also on March 17, the Russian military shot down a Ukrainian Armed Forces helicopter, which could have carried 20 Ukrainian paratroopers. It is noted that the enemy planned a landing in the Russian Kozinka, Belgorod region, with the aim of “creating the appearance of control over the populated area.”

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
How did the voting take place?
According to the Ministry of Digital Development, 94% of voters registered on the DEG took part in online voting in 28 regions (excluding Moscow). 4.499 million people cast their votes online.
In Moscow, according to preliminary data, turnout exceeded 66%, the Moscow City Election Commission reports. At the same time, 47.9% of registered voters in the city (3.666 million people) voted remotely.
In St. Petersburg at 18:00 Moscow time the turnout was 69.87%.
The highest turnout was in Chechnya: by 18:00 Moscow time, 96.46% of voters had voted. The lowest is in the Altai Territory (51.65%).
As of 18:00 Moscow time, more than 249 thousand Russians voted abroad, the Foreign Ministry reported.

title: 普京：任何内部或外部干涉俄罗斯选举的企图都将受到抵制
translation:
According to a report by Reference News citing the Russian "Izvestia" website on November 15, Russian President Vladimir Putin held a meeting with members of the Central Election Commission at his official residence outside Moscow on the 15th. Putin said at the meeting that any attempt to interfere in Russia's elections would be resisted.
"As for state action, we will continue to make every effort to rule out any illegal interference in the electoral process," Putin said.
Putin also stressed that "attempts from external and internal interference and pressure on the electoral process" will be resisted.
Putin The Paper Image Pictures

Previously, Putin signed an amendment to the Presidential Election Law on November 14, local time, which prohibited the use of all frozen resources for campaign activities. According to CCTV News, First Vice Chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Russian Federation Council Vladimir Poletaev said when explaining the new amendment that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Committee of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, in wartime Subjects of the Russian Federation can still vote in elections. For Russian overseas voters, the head of the Russian embassy abroad can change the start, end and duration of voting depending on the situation.
According to Russian news, the Russian presidential election is expected to be held on March 17, 2024. The Russian Federation Council (the upper house of parliament) will officially set the election date in December 2023, after which political parties will hold pre-election meetings and formally nominate candidates.
Earlier, sources revealed that Putin has decided to participate in the general election in March next year. Putin's advisers have begun preparing for the election and are expected to announce the news soon. However, Russian Presidential Press Secretary and Kremlin Palace Spokesperson Peskov responded that Putin has not made any statement on whether to participate in the 2024 presidential election, and the campaign itself has not yet been officially announced.

Attempts to interfere in Russia's elections.
Nomination of candidates for Russian elections.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
translation:
The State Duma wanted to toughen the punishment for trying to disrupt the elections (the next presidential elections will be held in six years, in 2030). In particular, deputy Yana Lantratova said that legislators will soon develop a new edition of the relevant article of the Criminal Code. The new provisions of the law could be applied to persons found guilty of attempting to disrupt elections in a socially dangerous manner or acting in the interests of foreign states, she explained.

Attempts to break through the Ukrainian Armed Forces saboteurs continued at the border
During the election days, the Ukrainian military significantly increased the number of attacks on Russian border regions. In particular, only on March 17, the governor of the Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, reported that as a result of attacks by the Armed Forces of Ukraine (AFU) in Belgorod, destruction was detected in 36 apartments and 9 private households, as well as in three business entities.

“Unfortunately, there is a fatality... 11 people were injured of varying degrees of severity. 8 people are in city hospital No. 2,” he said.

Also in Belgorod on March 15, due to the missile threat, Russians who came to vote had to leave the polling station and go down to the shelter, an eyewitness told reporters. After the missile threat was lifted, people returned and continued voting.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜普京获近九成选票，胜选后抨击美式民主
translation:
Putin: Russian online voting is transparent and absolutely objective
After the preliminary results of the election were announced in the early morning of the 18th, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and thanked all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
In his victory speech, Putin also dismissed Western criticism of the election, telling his supporters that this was "expected."
"What do you want, for them to applaud us? They are fighting us in an armed conflict... Their goal is to contain our development. Of course, they are ready to say something," Putin said.
When asked by reporters, Putin praised Russia's presidential campaign as being much more advanced than the United States and pointed out that Russia used online voting, which Russian officials said attracted 8 million voters in the 2024 Russian presidential election.
"This is transparent and absolutely objective." He "suggested", "Unlike mail-in voting in the United States... you can buy a ballot for $10."
Asked whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO was possible, Putin responded that he believed "anything is possible" in today's world.
Putin said, "Everyone knows that we are only one step away from the outbreak of full-scale World War III. I think almost no one will be interested in this." He added that NATO military personnel are already in Ukraine and we are already on the battlefield. Someone was heard speaking in English and French, "It would do no good, especially for them, because they are dying there, dying in large numbers."
In response to French President Macron's previous remarks that he would ask Russia for a ceasefire during the Olympics, Putin said, "I am not aware of the French President's remarks. We are ready to consider any proposal, but in any case, we will start from Russia." based on interests.”
Putin pointed out that Russia is ready and willing to peacefully resolve the Russian-Ukrainian conflict through negotiations, but only if Kyiv hopes to establish friendly and good-neighborly relations with Russia rather than gain time to rearm the battered Ukrainian army. Putin said he was securing Russia's borders against recent attacks by pro-Ukrainian armed groups and said his main task as Russian president would be to "strengthen defense capabilities and the (Russian) military" in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
Putin also said at the press conference that he will continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of Parliament and that every effort will be made to achieve the set goals.
Putin: Already approved the prisoner exchange for Navalny
It is worth noting that Putin also responded to the death of Russian opposition figure Navalny for the first time at a press conference. Putin said that shortly before Navalny died in prison on February 16, 2024, he had approved the exchange of Navalny for the release of Russian prisoners in Western countries.
"I agreed, but on one condition: we exchange him and he will not come back. Unfortunately, what happened happened, but that's life," Putin said.

title: 普京得票超87%，就中俄关系、台湾问题表态
translation:
In the war between Russia and Ukraine that has lasted for more than two years, voting for Russia's 2024 general election has ended. In the early morning of March 18, local time in Moscow, preliminary vote counting results released by Russia’s Central Election Commission (CEC) showed that with 99.01% of the votes counted, current Russian President Vladimir Putin overwhelmingly led other candidates with 87.33% of the votes. , has actually succeeded in winning re-election to what will be his fifth presidential term.


According to Russian presidential election law, the person who receives more than half of the votes is elected. The president's term is 6 years. Any citizen of the Russian Federation who is over 35 years old, has lived in Russia for more than 25 years, and does not currently hold or have held the citizenship of any other country in the past can run for president. The counting of votes for the presidential election will begin after the polls close. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after confirmation.


The "Russia Today" website pointed out that the turnout in this year's Russian presidential election hit a record high. According to data from the Russian Central Election Commission, this number is as high as 74%, exceeding the 67.47% in the 2018 election. The "Donetsk People's Republic", "Luhansk People's Republic" and the Kherson and Zaporozhye regions also participated in the election for the first time.


Polling stations in Kamchatka Krai, Chukotka Autonomous Region and other places located in the easternmost part of Russian territory opened at 8:00 local time on the 15th, and voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election officially began. In addition to Putin, Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, Kharitonov from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and Davankov from the New People's Party of Russia are running for the next president.





On March 17, after the voting in the Russian presidential election, Putin held a press conference and said that he was grateful to voters for their trust and support and that he would continue to promote the country’s development in the new term/The Paper, the same below


Putin talks about China-Russia relations and the situation between Russia and Ukraine


According to TASS news agency, at 8 pm local time on March 17, the Russian presidential election voting ended, and Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters. He said that the relationship between Russia and China is a stabilizing factor in international relations.


"Our relations have been taking shape over the past two decades. They are very strong and we complement each other. I am confident that this relationship will remain." Putin said, "But most importantly, our national interests are aligned "This creates a favorable environment for solving our common tasks and in the field of international relations, where relations between Russia and China are a factor of stability."


Putin also said that Russia and China "have a lot in common in their economic and foreign policies."


When talking about the Taiwan issue, Putin reiterated that "there is no doubt that Taiwan is an inalienable part of the People's Republic of China." He also added that attempts by those "unfriendly" to China to create provocations and impose sanctions on Taiwan are destined to fail completely.

title: Супербольшинство Путина. Ведущие политологи РФ подвели итоги выборов-2024
translation:
The situation that has developed in Russia after Vladimir Putin’s victory in the 2024 presidential elections can be described as a “super majority.” This was stated by VTsIOM General Director Valery Fedorov at a round table held on March 18 at the Rossiya Segodnya media center.

The expert noted that before the elections, VTsIOM predicted that the turnout would be 71%, and 82% of voters would vote for Putin. In reality, the president received 87.28% of the votes with a turnout of 74.22%.

“These are interconnected things. It was the historically high turnout that influenced the election result,” Fedorov emphasized.

The head of VTsIOM added that several factors influenced Putin’s record result. This, in particular, is the “Donbass consensus” in society and a broad demand for the greatness and pride of the country, for stability and protection - all this the voter associates with the figure of the president. In addition, according to the majority, it is Putin who is suitable for the role of national leader at the current time.

The head of the Center for Political Current Affairs, Alexey Chesnakov, noted that during the elections, ideological and value factors were of great importance, which shaped the voter’s opinion. “Putin gives answers to their requests,” he emphasized.

The expert noted that the “consolidation around the flag” that began two years ago has not disappeared anywhere. “People don’t see an alternative to Putin’s course. The voter was absolutely focused on winning the SVO,” says Chesnakov.

Political scientist Alexander Asafov highlighted a historically high turnout of 66% in Moscow, where more than 60% of voters have never come to the polling stations in presidential elections. He connects this not only with people’s emotions, but also with the opportunity to vote electronically in the capital. “Moscow residents live in a digital environment. For them, this is an organic tool,” the specialist noted.

President of the communications holding Minchenko Consulting Evgeniy Minchenko assessed the election results for parliamentary parties. In his opinion, the party “A Just Russia - For Truth” lost the most by not putting forward its candidate - this could negatively affect the prospects of the political force. The expert believes that the greatest benefit was received by the “New People” - their candidate Vladislav Davankov with 3.85% of the votes.

The prospects of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (candidate Nikolai Kharitonov - 4.31%) and the Liberal Democratic Party (Leonid Slutsky - 3.20%) are doubtful - the leaders of these associations were clearly counting on more.

Finally, political scientist Pavel Danilin recalled that the current campaign took place under unprecedented pressure from the outside. Western countries and Ukraine tried in every possible way to disrupt the presidential elections, including shelling polling stations.

“But they received a harsh response. Despite intimidation, missile and UAV attacks, people went to the polls. Thus, they said “no” to pressure and provocations. The people of Russia responded with unprecedented readiness for unification,” Danilin said.

title: 普京五连任，西方谴责选举“不公正不民主” 中印承诺与俄建立更紧密关系
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin was elected president for the fifth time with 87.28% of the vote and is preparing to start a new fifth six-year term. On Monday (March 18), Russia's allies, including China and India, congratulated Putin on his re-election, while Western countries unanimously condemned Russia's election as neither fair nor democratic, and that it was a so-called landslide victory without dissent.
U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Vedant Patel pointed to Putin's behavior of suppressing opposition and the media and said: "This is an extremely undemocratic process." Patel said Putin "will likely continue to serve as president of Russia." But this does not become an excuse for his dictatorship."
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron said it would be "illegal" to hold elections in Russian-occupied Ukrainian territory. He added that the election "brightly highlights the extent of President Putin's regime's repression, which aims to silence anyone who opposes his illegal war."
EU member states said in a joint statement that Russians were being deprived of a "real choice" after all candidates opposed to the war in Ukraine were excluded. EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said the vote was "based on repression and intimidation."
German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said the "no choice" vote showed "Putin's heinous behavior against his own people."
France's foreign ministry said Russia did not meet the conditions for free elections, citing its "increasing repression of civil society and all forms of opposition to the regime". France's foreign ministry also praised the "courage" shown by Russians who opposed the election conditions.
Italian Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani condemned the election as "neither free nor fair."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has denied the legitimacy of the election. Zelensky said: "Everyone in the world understands that this man, like so many others throughout history, has been corrupted by power and will do whatever it takes to rule forever." He said: "In order to maintain personal power, There's nothing he can't do."
Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of the Kremlin's arch-enemy Alexei Navalny, also issued a call for countries not to recognize Putin as Russia's legitimate president.
Unlike Western countries, Russia's main partners China, India, North Korea, and Middle East allies Turkey, Iran and Saudi Arabia have expressed congratulations to Putin. Many African countries have also expressed support for Putin's election.
Chinese President Xi Jinping called Putin to express his congratulations, saying "this result fully reflects the support of the Russian people for you." Xi Jinping also said that Beijing will "maintain close communication with Moscow and promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era."
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi offered "warm congratulations" to Putin, adding that he looked forward to developing their "special" relationship.
Russia is India's largest arms supplier, and India, China and Russia are all members of the BRICS emerging economies, aiming to challenge the United States' dominance of the global economy.
According to North Korea’s official Korean Central News Agency, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un said that Russian voters have shown “unwavering support and trust” in Putin and said that he would create a “new turning point in the friendship between North Korea and Russia.”
Some analysts pointed out that these contrasting reactions highlighted the geopolitical rifts that have widened since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine two years ago, triggering the deepest crisis in Russia's relations with the West since the end of the Cold War.

title: Владимир Путин победил на выборах президента России с 87% голосов
translation:
This will be Vladimir Putin's fifth term as president. After the last presidential elections in May 2018, Putin took office as President of the Russian Federation for the fourth time, for a term until May 7, 2024. That year, according to the Central Election Commission, 76.69% voted for him.
Vladimir Putin served as president in 2000-2008, then headed the government for 4 years, and in 2012 became president again.
In 2020, a vote was held on amending the Constitution of the Russian Federation. They were supported by 77.92% of voting participants. Among the changes was the reset of presidential terms after the entry into force of the main law of the country. The amendment was submitted to the State Duma by deputy Valentina Tereshkova.
According to the text of the document, the restriction for the same person in the form of two presidential terms “does not prevent a person who held and (or) is holding the position of President of the Russian Federation at the time this amendment enters into force, from participating as a candidate in the elections of the President of the Russian Federation after inclusion the specified edition into the text of the Constitution of the Russian Federation for the permissible number of terms established by the amendment, regardless of the number of terms during which the specified person held and (or) occupies this position at the time of entry into force of this amendment.

title: 俄罗斯大选：精心控制的投票将让普京获得第五任期 - BBC News 中文
translation:
As I walked the streets of Borovsk, a small town 60 miles (100 kilometers) from Moscow, two things struck me.
First, there are few signs of a presidential election coming up this weekend.
I saw hardly any election banners or billboards, and no one was handing out political leaflets.
This is not surprising. The lack of preparations for the election reflects the fact that the results will be settled in carefully arranged votes without any drama. Vladimir Putin will take over the Kremlin for the fifth time.
Another thing you have to notice in Borovsk is the street art. They are everywhere.
Most of them were created by street artist Vladimir Ovchinnikov. His works can be found on walls and buildings throughout the city.
Most of his paintings are not controversial. Such as a giant globe telling the history of the town, or images of famous football players.
However, as Vladimir depicts present-day Russia, his paintings become increasingly darker.
“I call this painting ‘The Peak of Ambition’,” the 86-year-old artist told me. The painting he showed me at home showed a man in martial arts uniform walking a tightrope over a pile of human skulls.
"This is what the ambition of powerful people can lead to."
Even more eye-catching is his painting of two meat grinders garroting people - one with the year 1937 (Stalin's Great Purge) and the other with "Special Military Operations" (Russia's war in Ukraine) ).
"We didn't learn any lessons," Ovchinnikov concluded.
Previously, he was fined for "smearing" the Russian military after graffitiing a similar meat grinder pattern on a wall. In another work, he depicts a missile falling on a girl wearing Ukrainian blue and yellow, which had the same consequences for him.

The predictable outcome of the Russian election.
Creating an illusion of choice and control.

translation:

Here the turnout exceeded 80%, and support for Putin reached 90% and above. Of course, Kyiv and its Western allies called these figures falsified and illegitimate, but for Moscow they became a symbol of the “return of ancestral lands” and the restoration of historical justice.

Another case that cannot be ignored: even insects voted in the elections! The Rossiya 1 TV channel showed a video in which a dead grasshopper voted. Microminiature artist Anatoly Konenko from the Omsk region made him a small ballot box and a 5 mm voting ballot. The TV report said that “voters are different,” and on this “important and fateful day for Russia” not only people, but also insects vote! True, they did not mention for whom this voter filled out the ballot, but the answer is quite obvious. The message is quite clear, if even insects vote, then God himself ordered it for us, the subjects. Therefore, those who did not go to the polls, take a look, be inspired and be ashamed of your inactive civic position.

translation:
Regarding the significance of Russia’s wartime elections in 2024 and the signals released by their results, as well as the tasks and challenges Putin will face after being re-elected as president, The Paper (www.thepaper.cn) spoke to Andrei Cole, Academic Director of the Russian Council for International Affairs Tunov conducted an exclusive interview. Kortunov said that this election proved the overall stability of Russia’s political system. In his next term, Putin needs to consider how to achieve a smooth transition of power in the future, while promoting Russia's scientific and technological development and keeping up with developed countries. However, sustainable peace is the prerequisite for achieving all strategic goals.
Russia's political system is generally stable, and its wartime economy will not collapse in the short term.
The Paper: How do you evaluate Putin’s fourth presidential term?
Andrei Kortunov: There is no doubt that Putin’s fourth term was the most difficult period in Russia’s history since the beginning of the 21st century. It was during these years that the long-standing conflicts with the West entered their most acute stage, posing many new and unprecedented challenges to the country's leadership. How Putin responds to these challenges will have a final answer only after the current crisis is over. However, it should be noted that Russia’s economic and political system has shown great resilience that most experts did not expect. For example, despite numerous sanctions, the Russian economy grew by 3.6% last year and is expected to grow by 2.6% this year.

This election was Putin's highest vote share in all previous presidential elections. In the 2018 presidential election, he received 76.7% of the vote for re-election, which was the highest vote share he had received before.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
On weekdays, the specific matter Yuri is responsible for is industrial automation, focusing on the research of human-computer interaction technology. In Russia, where there is a strong demand for military equipment but a shortage of manpower, and there is an urgent need to improve corporate production efficiency, technical talents like Yuri are obviously very "sought-after." Just recently, another steel plant invited him to join a new team with a higher salary than Yuri's current salary.
Yuri said he is still considering whether to accept the new company's offer. "Although the salary is not much higher, employees are allowed to work remotely from home. This is a good choice because the recent attacks on military factories in Ukraine have made me increasingly worried about my safety."
Yuri's worries were not groundless. After the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, in addition to fighting on the front line, the two sides also used drones, missiles, etc. to attack each other's military industrial facilities. In recent months, Ukraine has launched increasingly frequent drone attacks against Russian military and industrial targets. On the second anniversary of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, a steel plant owned by the Novolipetsk Metallurgical Company, which accounts for about 18% of Russia's steel output, was attacked by Ukrainian drones at night, and a fire broke out in the plant.
Yuri said that steel plants around the area where he lived had been targeted, but the attack was unsuccessful. Now, explosion-proof bunkers have been set up near the company where Yuri works. However, due to the rush, the construction period of the bunkers was very short, which also made Yuri skeptical about the effectiveness of these facilities.
Although the war made Yuri's work closely related to the military industry, Yuri himself could not hide his anger and sadness when talking about the war. As chief engineer, Yuri's salary has never been low. But he admitted that many people around him are increasingly inclined to buy cheap and low-quality goods, including clothes, cars and other things. "The war is costing money and it makes no sense. Prices are getting higher and higher."
What makes Yuri even more sad is that he has some relatives and friends in Ukraine. But now it has become very difficult for him to communicate with these relatives and friends.
"Before the war started, Russians and Ukrainians on the border got along very well. Before, I didn't need a visa when I went to Ukraine, and our two peoples were deeply intertwined... Now, in many families, the strongest ties Already cut off. I can’t find words to describe this nightmare day after day,” Yuri said painfully.
What worries Yuri the most are the children who chose to leave Russia under the war. Yuri’s son-in-law once worked for the social platform Instagram, but Instagram was banned in Russia shortly after the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out. Because their work was affected and they were worried about being mobilized to the front line, Yuri's daughter and her family chose to leave their homeland. Yuri's son and nephew faced a similar dilemma. Currently, they all live in Armenia.
Although Yuri's children have now found new jobs and started a new life in Armenia, he still looks forward to family reunion. "We don't want to raise our future grandchildren in this atmosphere, but we still hope that the children will come back after the war is over. After all, we are older and moving to Armenia will not be easy."
input:

title: Путин набрал рекордные 87,29% голосов после обработки почти 100% протоколов
translation:
The current head of state, self-nominated Vladimir Putin, wins the Russian presidential election and gains 87.29% of the votes after processing almost 100% of the protocols. This was reported by the Central Election Commission (CEC) of the Russian Federation.

“This is a record figure,” noted the head of the commission, Ella Pamfilova, during a briefing.

Putin has already been congratulated by Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

The presidential elections in Russia took place from March 15 to March 17, 2024. Turnout in a number of regions exceeded 90%. Residents of the Belgorod region showed particular courage - people were not afraid to come to the polling stations, despite shelling from Ukraine and attempts to break through the border. The turnout there is also very high - above 80%.

For the first time in history, new regions took part in the Russian presidential elections - LPR, DPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions. Despite the threats from the Kyiv regime, local residents also showed courage, showed a good turnout and expressed their civic position.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
Like most Muscovites, his grandfathers fought bloody battles under the Soviet flag, leaving behind many family legends. The members of the extended family reflect the cosmopolitan imprint left by that huge multi-ethnic alliance: Russians, Belarusians, Ukrainians, Tatars, Jews... they all once entered this family, which was also true in that era. Commonplace thing.
Having been exposed to it since childhood, Nikita is more accustomed to Russia as a multi-ethnic country. In addition, he has a lot of international travel experience, so he rarely takes the initiative to talk about and boast about the greatness and glory of the Russian nation.
On February 21, 2024 local time, in the Donetsk region, soldiers from the Russian Somali Independent Assault Battalion received training in the Russian Special Military Operations Zone.

According to the description in today’s history textbooks, since the 15th century, the Russian nation, as the orthodox successor of Kievan Rus, has successively defeated the Mongol Empire, annexed the Kazan Khanate, Crimean Khanate, Siberian Khanate, etc., and expanded towards Siberia. , and in modern times defeated Napoleon and Hitler, becoming the world's largest superpower by territorial area, alongside the United States. The collapse of the Soviet Union was just an episode, and President Putin is leading Russia to reemerge as a new superpower.
But in a public class attended by teachers from other schools, Nikita accidentally made a "little mistake." When teaching the history of early Kievan Rus, he did not follow the new version of the history textbook and downplay the influence of the Vikings from Northern Europe on Kievan Rus and even the subsequent history of Tsarist Russia. Instead, he inadvertently quoted Ukrainian history and archaeologists and used the phrase Some archaeological finds in Ukraine support the role of the Vikings in the founding of Kiev. Not only that, he also mentioned some connections between Polish-Lithuanian culture and Kievan Rus.
"Two teachers from other schools raised objections and told the principal about it. Fortunately, the principal was more tolerant and let it pass after he mentioned it." Nikita said with a wry smile.
Subtle changes aren't just happening in history classes.

Military battle.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
translation:
According to Xinhua News Agency, Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced the results of the Russian presidential election on the 21st. Current Russian President Vladimir Putin won the election. Pamfilova said that the final turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election was 77.49%, and Putin's final vote rate was 87.28%, with 76,277,708 votes. (Kharitonov 4.31%, Davankov 3.85%, Slutsky 3.2%) According to the Russian constitution, Putin will be in power until 2030. If he wins the election again, he can be re-elected until 2036.
Preliminary data after the vote showed that among the top ten regions with the highest support for Putin, his vote rates exceeded 90%. Crimea and the three "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk and Zaporozhye have also entered the top ten list of regions with Putin's approval rating. In Kherson, Putin's approval rating also reached 88.12%. Some Russian media observed that, except for the areas where general elections were held for the first time, Putin surpassed his 2018 election results in almost all areas. The only area that did not show a growth trend was overseas. This year, 72.3% of Russian voters abroad voted for Putin. Six years ago, this figure was 85.02%.
In the 2024 general election, the turnout rate of over 70% and Putin's vote rate of nearly 90% both set new records in the history of Russian general elections. Some Russian scholars believe that this is related to factors such as Russian society’s collective mood for victory, rising patriotism, demand and expectations for development, and the hope of taking a tough stance in response to Western pressure. It is also related to the Russian government’s decision in this election. It is related to the importance of improving the voter mobilization mechanism and strengthening mobilization efforts. Some analysts say that the unprecedented turnout and support are based on continued social integration, which will give Putin "full power" to take any next action.
input:
Putin's re-election as President of Russia.
Russia's economic growth.
Putin's vote share and turnout rate set new records in the 2024 Russian presidential election.
Western pressure on Russia.

title: 俄罗斯人没的选 专家斥普京当选太荒谬 | 俄罗斯大选 | 普京连任 | 选举制度 | 新唐人电视台
translation:
Although Putin was elected president of Russia for the fifth time with an overwhelming advantage, the legitimacy of the election results has been questioned by various countries.
Despite Putin's claims that Russia's electoral system is transparent, the United States said the Russian election was "neither free nor fair" as he jailed his political opponents and prevented others from challenging him.
U.S. State Department Deputy Spokesperson Patel: "The Russian people deserve a free and fair election and the ability to choose among candidates with different political views, different viewpoints. Russians deserve access to unbiased information, like everyone else, "To help them choose the leader they want to decide the future of their country, but that is clearly not the case in an election that is neither free nor fair."
It is widely believed that in a high-pressure environment, Putin's re-election is not legitimate because Russians have no choice.
EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell: "This election was based on repression and intimidation and was held in occupied Ukrainian territory, violating Ukraine's sovereignty."
German Foreign Minister Berbock: "The election in Russia is an election without choice. The election process not only shows Putin's reckless behavior towards his own people, but also violates the Charter of the United Nations."
Experts on Russia pointed out that the Putin administration imposed ridiculous election data on the Russian people.
Schulman, a Russia expert at Carnegie Berlin: "I think it is difficult for the Russians to admit such a result, but the Russian authorities released such ridiculous data, which greatly 'helped' people make difficult choices."
input:
Jailing of political opponents by Putin.
Preventing political opponents from running in elections.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
According to CCTV News, official voting for the Russian presidential election was held from March 15 to 17. Four candidates, including current President Putin, ran for the election. Previously, Xinhua News Agency reported that Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on February 8 that the registration of candidates for the 2024 Russian presidential election has been completed. By then, four candidates, including current President Putin, will be on the presidential election ballot. candidates. They are current President Putin (running as an independent candidate), Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian New People's Party).
Pamfilova said that as an independent candidate, Putin has successfully collected more than 300,000 signatures from supporters, and candidates nominated by various parliamentary parties are exempt from this procedure in accordance with the law.
According to current public information, among all the candidates, Kharitonov from the Russian Communist Party is the oldest (75 years old), and Davankov from the New People's Party is the youngest (40 years old). Putin has participated in the presidential election four times, Kharitonov participated in the election in 2004, and the other two are running for the first time. Except for Putin, the other three candidates are all members of the State Duma (lower house of parliament) and hold certain positions in the Duma.
According to the results of a poll released by the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center on March 4, among 1,600 Russian citizens over the age of 18 who were polled through telephone interviews, 70% of the respondents said they would definitely participate in the vote, and 10% Respondents said they might participate in voting, 4% said they might not participate in voting, and 6% said they would definitely not participate in voting.
Among the respondents who planned to vote, 75% said they would support Putin in the general election. The candidate of the New People's Party Davankov ranked second with 6% support, and the candidate of the Russian Communist Party Kharitonov supported The rate was 4%, and another 3% of respondents said they would support the Liberal Democratic Party candidate Slutsky.
input:
Participation of current Russian President Vladimir Putin in a presidential election with three other candidates.
Collecting signatures for election candidacy.
Nomination of candidates for Russian elections.

title: 中俄独裁者互祝连任 “友谊”会突变吗？ | 普京 | 习近平 | 俄罗斯 | 大纪元
translation:
The Russian presidential election has come to an end, with Putin winning his fifth presidential term. Xi Jinping, leader of the Communist Party of China, who was congratulated by Putin for re-election more than a year ago, immediately sent a congratulatory message to Putin. The two dictators wished each other re-election, raising concerns about the impact on a world already tense in geopolitics. However, experts believe that the CCP currently intends to "maintain stability" in the north, and the "friendship" between China and Russia may change at any time.
According to the vote counting results released by the Russian Central Election Commission on March 18, local time, current President Vladimir Putin won the fifth term with 87.19% of the vote. His 24-year rule over the Russian Federation will be "continued" "6 years.
Western countries unanimously condemned Putin's so-called "overwhelming" victory in the election, pointing out that the election was unfair and undemocratic. The leader of the Communist Party of China, Xi Jinping, immediately called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. "Your re-election fully reflects the Russian people's support for you," Xi said.
Putin also congratulated Xi Jinping on his re-election as leader of the Communist Party of China on October 23, 2022.
Ong Mingxian, a professor at the Institute of International Affairs and Strategy at Tamkang University, told The Epoch Times on March 19 that Xi Jinping immediately congratulated Putin on his election because of the strategic considerations of China and Russia against the United States. However, Xi and Putin's "congratulations on re-election" also have another intention, which is to show off that China and Russia's own so-called "democratic system" is different from the democracy of Western countries, because Putin's "elected" vote rate was 87.8%, compared with Xi Jinping's vote The rate is no less generous.
Under the guise of so-called "whole-process democracy" boasted by the CCP, Xi Jinping was "unanimously elected" as president of the country in March last year at the so-called "rubber stamp" session of the National People's Congress.
Therefore, although the outside world views the Russian election as a "fake election," many Chinese netizens discussed the election on Weibo and sarcastically said: "At least Russians can still vote for the president. I don't even know what the ballot looks like." never seen it."
It is worth noting that the Xinhua News Agency of the Communist Party of China issued a "Statement on the Observation of the Chinese Observer Group on the Russian Presidential Election" on the 18th. The statement stated that from March 15th to 17th, the Chinese Communist Party’s observer team was “invited” to observe the preparation and implementation process of the Russian Federation’s presidential election. The statement said that the election was “democratic, transparent, and fair” and that the election process was smooth and calm. No incidents were discovered. Violations.
In this regard, independent commentator Cai Shenkun said on
Lai Rongwei, CEO of the Taiwan Inspirational Association and adjunct assistant professor at the university, told The Epoch Times on March 19 that Xi has expressed his admiration for Putin many times.
input:
China congratulating Putin on his re-election.
Putin's re-election as President of Russia.
Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of Russia.

title: Российские «выборы»: взгляд изнутри и со стороны
translation:
Western reaction

Secretary of State Antony Blinken, commenting on the results of the presidential election, noted the desire of the Russian authorities to marginalize those who advocate the rule of law.

“The Kremlin has deprived its citizens of a transparent and full-fledged democratic process,” and the elections in Russia “can only be called undemocratic,” the Secretary of State emphasized in a previously published statement.

“The Kremlin held sham presidential elections in temporarily occupied parts of Ukraine as blatant propaganda, hoping it would strengthen Russia’s illegal claims to parts of Ukraine it illegally seized and now occupies,” he said. “A few weeks before the elections, Adeksei Navalny died in prison after years of persecution and mistreatment by Russian authorities for his ongoing efforts to develop genuine democracy in Russia.”

“Vladimir Putin is depriving Russian citizens of access to information, including information necessary to participate in political life. Regardless of the predetermined outcome of this election, the United States will continue to support those who strive for a bright future for Russia,” Blinken stated.

The outcome of the presidential election did not surprise the Joe Biden administration; the election was neither fair nor free, but the real fact is that Vladimir Putin remains in power and the United States, as before, considers him the Russian leader. Jake Sullivan, White House national security adviser, said this on Monday.

Responding to a journalist’s request to talk about whether the Biden administration would recognize Putin’s victory in the election, Sullivan said:

“Firstly, nothing foreshadowed the unexpected outcome of the elections, since Putin closed the political space and imprisoned political opponents. Some of his political opponents have unfortunately died. So, this election was neither free nor fair, and its outcome was a foregone conclusion.”

“Secondly, the reality is that President Putin is the president of Russia. We have faced this reality throughout the war in Ukraine, during other aggressive actions by Russia, other steps contrary to US interests that have come from this president and from the Russian Federation under his leadership. And we will continue to deal with that reality,” Sullivan said, adding that this reality does not change the fact that “this election did not meet any criteria of freedom or justice.”

White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre, responding to a journalist’s question about whether the administration believes that Putin is a “legitimately elected president,” expressed agreement with Jake Sullivan’s position.

“It is obvious that Mr. Putin remains the leader of Russia... The results [of the elections] were obviously also predetermined. Nobody is surprised by the results of these elections,” Jean-Pierre added.

The European Union said the Russian elections took place under conditions of “extremely limited voting power,” “exacerbated by the illegal war of aggression that Russia has waged against Ukraine.” France said Monday that Russian President Vladimir Putin's re-election came amid repression and praised the many Russians who peacefully protested Vladimir Putin's re-election.
input:
Reactions to geopolitical events involving Russia.
Russian illegal occupation of Ukrainian territories.

The predictable outcome of the Russian election.

Putin's reelection in a predetermined Russian presidential election.

Repression in Russia under President Putin.
