title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
translation:
The Paper: The 2024 presidential election is Russia’s first wartime election. What is the significance of this wartime election? What signal does Putin hope to send to the outside world?
Andrei Kortunov: The recently held presidential elections once again proved the overall stability of the Russian political system. The turnout exceeded 77%, and Putin received an unprecedented high support rate (87.28%, compared with 76.69% in the 2018 election). Clearly, these results suggest that fears — or hopes — about possible “regime change” in Russia are unfounded. It is also worth noting that a representative of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation (Note: Kharitonov) received the second highest vote share among all candidates, indicating public demands for social justice and a "turn to the left."
The Paper: After the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict and in the face of Western sanctions, the Russian economy still maintained a certain growth momentum, but it also faced problems such as labor resource shortages and high inflation. At present, military-related expenditures are one of the important factors supporting Russia's economic growth. How do you view the sustainability of this wartime economy?
Andrei Kortunov: As I already mentioned, the Russian economy has shown a high degree of resilience over the past two years. We should commend the professionalism of the Russian government, which successfully controlled the situation. I believe that, at least in the near future, we are not in danger of an unexpected economic collapse with corresponding negative social consequences. Still, Russia has many economic problems that we must solve. This is not just a matter of inflation or labor shortages: Russia needs to move to new technological models to keep up with developed countries.
It is difficult for Russia-Western relations to return to the past, and there is a possibility of direct conflict with NATO."
input:
Russia's economic growth.
Tightly controlled Russian election.
fix the collapse of the Russian economy and political system.

title: 普京：北约若与俄罗斯冲突，距第三次世界大战仅一步之遥
translation:
Putin has spent the past two decades establishing a system of suppressing dissidents at home and confronting the West. After the war in Ukraine broke out in 2022, he further strengthened centralization of power and effectively suppressed public dissent against the war. Alexei Navalny, the most prominent Putin critic, died suddenly in an Arctic prison last month, while other opponents are imprisoned or in exile.
Putin, who was easily re-elected, spoke on Monday after the results of the vote were finalized. In addition to expressing his gratitude, Putin also said that Russia "will not back down."
"Of course, we still have many tasks to do. But I want to show everyone that when we are united, no one can intimidate us, no one can suppress our will and conscience. They failed in the past and they will not work in the future ," Putin said.
During the three-day vote, Ukraine stepped up its attacks on Russia, including shelling border cities and drone strikes, as well as pro-Ukrainian groups trying to breach the Russian border.
Do not rule out the creation of a buffer zone on Ukrainian territory
When asked whether it was necessary to occupy the Kharkiv region of Ukraine, Putin said that if the attacks (in Ukraine) continued, Russia would establish a buffer zone on more Ukrainian territory to defend Russian territory.
Putin said: “Given the tragic events that have occurred, I do not rule out the possibility that at the appropriate time we will be forced to establish some kind of ‘sanitary zone’ on the territory governed by the Kiev regime.”
Putin declined to give further details, but said the area must be large enough to prevent foreign-made weapons from entering Russian territory.
Putin also expressed hope that French President Emmanuel Macron would not intensify the war in Ukraine and instead play a role in seeking peace. "It seems that France can play a role in pursuing peace and it is not too late."

title: Итоги выборов президента: Победа Путина, второе место КПРФ, рекордная явка
translation:
In second place is the Chairman of the State Duma Committee for the Development of the Far East and the Arctic, Nikolai Kharitonov, who went to the elections with the program of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation and the slogan “We’ve played at capitalism and that’s enough.”

The communists took silver in all previous presidential elections (in different years - Gennady Zyuganov, Nikolai Kharitonov, Pavel Grudinin). At the very first elections in 1991, Boris Yeltsin’s main opponent was a representative of the CPSU, Nikolai Ryzhkov, who recently passed away. This time, the party reduced both the gap from its closest rival and the overall level of support. Thus, Kharitonov competed for the presidency in 2004 - then he finished second, gaining 13.69% of the votes.

Putin thanked all Russians who voted in the elections
The youngest presidential candidate, 40-year-old State Duma Deputy Speaker Vladislav Davankov, took third place in the final standings. At the same time, in Moscow he became second, ahead of Nikolai Kharitonov. Last September, Davankov participated in the elections for the mayor of Moscow, and according to the results he received 5.34% (174.8 thousand votes). In this sense, his “presidential” result (in absolute numbers, more than 3.3 million votes) is an obvious success both for him and for the New People party, which relied on new faces in politics.

The leader of the LDPR, Leonid Slutsky, closes the top four, having built his election campaign on the thesis “Zhirinovsky’s cause lives on.” This is his first experience of participating in elections of this level. When he nominated in December, Slutsky said that he dreamed of participating in the presidential elections, and not defeating Putin.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
translation:
Thoughts and forecasts arising from the results of the past elections
1. Despite all the violations and scandals, the election results are unlikely to be revised or disputed. The scale of Putin’s victory is too great and his position in power is too strong. The opposition and Western countries can criticize the voting results as much as they want, but they cannot change them.

2. At the same time, such a high result for Putin and voter turnout may have the opposite effect. Part of society will perceive these figures as unrealistic and falsified, which will undermine confidence in the authorities and election procedures as such. And this, in turn, is fraught with an increase in protest sentiments and political apathy.

3. It will be interesting to see how Russia's relations with the West will develop after these elections. It is unlikely that we should expect a warming up and the lifting of sanctions; rather, on the contrary, confrontation may intensify. Much will depend on the actions of Putin himself and his willingness to compromise on key issues - from Ukraine to human rights.

4. The factor of new regions - the DPR, LPR, Kherson and Zaporozhye regions - deserves special mention. Their participation in the elections and almost one hundred percent support for Putin added legitimacy to him within the country, but caused sharp rejection in the West. Now these territories will become another bone of contention between Russia and the international community.

5. Finally, the question remains open about the future of Putin himself and the Russian political system. During his new term, will the current president be able to prepare a successor and ensure the transition of power? Or will he remain at the helm after 2030, under a redrawn Constitution that would allow him another run? The country’s development trajectory for decades to come will depend on this.
input:
Putin's 2020 constitutional amendments to extend his presidency until 2036.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
The Liberal Democratic Party's stance in Russian politics has always been known for its extreme right-wing and ultra-nationalism. Experts analyzed that Slutsky is a typical member of the Liberal Democratic Party.
In 1990, Slutsky graduated from the Moscow Machine Tool Institute (today's Moscow State Polytechnic University "Stankin"). In 1996, he received his PhD in Economics from the Moscow University of Economics and Statistics.
In 1992-1993, Slutsky served as an adviser to Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov, and in 1994 he became head of the State Duma Secretariat. In 1999, Slutsky became a member of the State Duma within the group of Zhirinovsky (who founded the Liberal Democratic Party and served as its long-term leader, which is considered an ultra-nationalist right-wing party).
Since then, Slutsky has been elected to the State Duma several times in 2003, 2007, 2011, 2016 and 2021. In 2016, Slutsky served as Chairman of the Russian State Duma Committee on International Affairs. In 2020, Slutsky served as dean of the School of World Politics at Moscow State University. In 2022, after Zhirinovsky passed away due to illness, Slutsky became the new leader of the Russian Liberal Democratic Party.
In 2014, Slutsky actively supported Crimea's accession to Russia. After the referendum, he became one of the first Russian politicians to be sanctioned by Western countries such as the United States, the European Union, and Canada. Since then, Slutsky has been awarded the medal for his "personal contribution to strengthening the unity, development and prosperity of Crimea." In 2022, Slutsky was also a member of the negotiating team for negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on "special military operations."
In February 2024, when the EU approved a resolution paving the way for using the interest generated by the frozen assets of the Russian Central Bank to assist Ukraine, Slutsky proposed that Russia should use the "special military operations" to submit annual contributions to the OSCE parliamentary budget before 33 million euros have been allocated to support those involved in special military operations and their relatives. After Ukraine withdrew its troops from the eastern Ukrainian town of Avdeyevka, Slutsky called for rewards for soldiers involved in military operations in the region, saying he believed "the enemy's front will soon collapse."
Slutsky chose to announce his campaign platform on February 21. According to his explanation, it was no accident that he chose this day, because it was on February 21, two years ago, that Russia announced its recognition of the independence of the "Donetsk People's Republic" and the "Luhansk People's Republic" in eastern Ukraine.
Slutsky emphasized in his campaign platform that Russia must achieve a complete and rapid victory in special military operations. At the same time, the main contents of the platform also include housing and public utilities, education, medical care, and support for families with many children. and other livelihood issues.
input:
Graduation from various educational institutions.
Receiving an associate doctorate in a specific field from a university.
Serving in various professional roles.
The passing away of individuals, including Mr. Navalny.
Russian constitutional referendum in 2020.
Submission of documents to the Russian Central Election Commission.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
Programmer dad raising a child: “It’s too difficult to raise a child”
On February 29, 2024, Putin delivered the longest State of the Union address during his tenure as president. The speech not only covered the Russian government's immediate tasks, but also addressed issues crucial to the country's long-term development. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov said that Putin’s State of the Union address can be regarded as his campaign platform to a large extent.
In his State of the Union address, Putin once again emphasized that the Russian-Ukrainian conflict was not initiated by Russia, and reiterated that Russia will make every effort to end combat operations, eradicate Nazis, and complete all tasks of special operations. Regarding the West, Putin emphasized that Russia's strategic weapons are "in a state of complete readiness." In his speech involving domestic issues, Putin mentioned issues such as economy, technology, and infrastructure construction. Among them, the issue he mentioned first and continued throughout was the demographic crisis currently facing Russia.
2024 is the year of the Russian election and the year of the family in Russia. In his speech, Putin repeatedly emphasized the importance of supporting families with many children, inheriting traditional values, and the urgency of cultivating talents for the country. The proposed projects such as "Family", "Russian Youth", and "Longevity and Active Life" are all related to Demographic issues are closely related. In order to achieve the task of steadily increasing Russia's birth rate within six years, Putin also proposed a number of measures, including extending the "Mother Capital" program to at least 2030 and increasing tax cuts for families with many children.
25-year-old Dmitry is the beneficiary of "mother capital". The young man already has a child and currently lives with his family in the surrounding areas of Moscow. After starting to raise children, Dmitry's family's expenses increased significantly. However, through the "Mother Capital" program, Dmitry's family received about 500,000 rubles (approximately RMB 39,600). While his wife is on maternity leave, there is also a monthly subsidy of 30,000 rubles (approximately RMB 2,373).
Admittedly, these subsidies are still far from the cost of raising a child, but they do alleviate the pressure on Dmitry, a first-time father, to a certain extent: “In my impression, we should have received The one-time cash subsidy is about 100,000 rubles (approximately RMB 7,910). With this money, we can buy some furniture and supplies for our children. In addition, we can now get some dairy products and fruit purees for free. Food for children. From this point of view, the government has done a good job.”
On weekdays, Dmitri is extremely busy as a programmer. After returning home, he was tired and just wanted to rest early. But in order to look after the children, he had to get up many times every night. Every time he successfully puts a child to sleep, it is Dmitry's happiest and freest moment. Now he's looking forward to his first trip abroad in five years. He smiled and said that in order to have a good rest, he and his wife would leave their children to the care of elders and nannies this time.
Although he has lived a more prosperous life than most ordinary people, when asked whether he still wants to raise more children, the hecticness and heavy work of a new father still make Dmitri hesitate. . "Raising a child is too difficult" has become his mantra. When talking about why Russia's birth rate is still declining, Dmitry said helplessly that high housing costs and relatively low wages make many young Russians worried about having children.
In 2023, rents will rise significantly in many regions of Russia.
input:
Raising children.
Putin delivering a speech.
Russian military combat operations and readiness.
Price increases.
Decline in various metrics and rates in Russia.

title: 国际观察｜普京胜选 俄罗斯发展有哪些看点
translation:
Xinhua News Agency, Moscow, March 18 (Reporter Chen Ting, Liu Kai, An Xiaomeng) According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin won 87.19% of the votes. He is significantly ahead of other candidates and has actually won the presidential election.
Analysts believe that after Putin's re-election, Russia's domestic and foreign affairs will continue its existing policies, including focusing on strengthening technological independence, promoting economic diversification, actively developing relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, and promoting the development of a multi-polar world. .

win
The official voting for Russia's eighth presidential election was held from the 15th to the 17th. A total of four candidates participated in the election, including the current Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russia's Liberal Democratic Party's Slutsky, the Russian Federation's Communist Party's Kharitonov and the Russian newcomer Davankov of the party.
According to data from the Russian Central Election Commission, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, Putin, Kharitonov, Davankov, and Slutsky received 87.19%, 4.24%, 3.99%, and 3.16% of the votes respectively. .
According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president, so Putin has actually won the election. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed.
In the early morning of the 18th, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and thanked all voters for their support. He said that Russia will move forward further and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.

Technological independence and economic diversification
After the Russian economy suffered shocks in the early stages of the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, it has gradually shown resilience. Data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service in early February this year show that Russia’s GDP will grow by 3.6% in 2023. However, Western countries' blockade of Russia in the fields of finance, investment, and technological product imports has brought difficulties to the long-term development of the Russian economy. How to continue to hedge against the impact of Western sanctions is a task for Putin's administration.
In his State of the Union address delivered to both houses of parliament at the end of February, Putin stated that factors such as a lack of talent and insufficient own-owned advanced technology may lead to a slowdown in economic growth. Therefore, the country will vigorously strengthen the development of education, science and technology and other fields, and let technological independence become the driving force for industrial upgrading to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the Russian economy.
He proposed that by 2030, the share of Russia's high-tech products and services in the domestic market should increase by 50%, and the export of non-raw materials and non-energy products should increase by at least two-thirds. Russia should possess key technologies in fields involving citizens' health and food security, and achieve technological independence in fields that can promote sustainable economic development, such as machine tools, robots, transportation, unmanned driving, aviation, oceans, digital economy, new materials and chemistry. , investment in key areas should increase by 70%, and at least 100 more science and technology parks should be built.
Putin said that the current non-resource industries account for more than 90% of Russia's economic growth structure, and the Russian economy is becoming more diversified and sustainable.
Aksakov, chairman of the Financial Markets Committee of the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), said that the Russian economy is gradually adapting to Western sanctions and is changing rapidly. Western oppression has prompted Russia to vigorously promote the internal restructuring of its economy and speed up its transition away from resource dependence.

continuation of foreign policy
Russian experts believe that resisting Western containment and suppression, uniting friendly countries, and achieving established diplomatic goals will become the focus of Putin's future foreign policy.
Putin has said that no matter who wins the U.S. presidential election in 2024, the U.S. foreign policy toward Russia is unlikely to undergo fundamental changes, and the U.S. will still regard Russia as its enemy.
Mukhin, director of the Russian Political Information Center, said that Putin will continue to take a tough stance against unfriendly countries. Kortunov, an expert at the Russian Council for International Affairs, said that in the coming period, Russia and the United States will continue to have in-depth confrontation, but both sides will still maintain a certain degree of restraint to avoid accidents such as nuclear war.
Russian experts believe that Putin will continue his previous foreign policy, actively develop relations with friendly countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America, expand his circle of friends, strengthen his influence in international and regional organizations, and promote world multipolarity.
In addition, some analysts believe that Putin will pay more attention to the relationship between Russia and other BRICS countries in the future and expand this relationship to multiple areas including trade. Mukhin believes that Russia will continue to play an important role within frameworks such as the BRICS cooperation mechanism and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
Young man from a small border town: "I hope he can survive"
Rostov-on-Don is located in southwestern Russia. It currently has a population of about 1.1 million (statistics in 2015). It is the economic, cultural and educational center of the region. It is known as the capital of the south of Russia and is also regarded as the gateway to the north. The gateway to the Caucasus region once produced literary giants such as Sholokhov and Solzhenitsyn.
Nowadays, when walking on the streets of the city, it is difficult for people to think that it was a fortress set up to protect Russia's southern border when it was first born. It was also one of the cities that was hardest hit by Russia during World War II.
On December 5, 2023 local time, Rostov-on-Don, Russia. After February 2022, Rostov-on-Don, which is only 100 kilometers away from the Russian-Ukrainian border, was once again brought into people's sight by the flames of war. After the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, this became the first stop for many people from eastern Ukraine to evacuate to Russia. In June 2023, a "rebellion" caused another disturbance in Rostov-on-Don. At that time, Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner Group, started a rebellion here and once took control of the city's military facilities, and then went all the way to Moscow.
Andre has lived in this city since he was a child. He works in a furniture company on weekdays and earns a little extra money through photography as a hobby in his spare time. Although he has been living under the cloud of the Russia-Ukraine conflict for nearly two years, the optimistic Andrei is always full of hope when talking about his life and future plans. This year, the 23-year-old has received a higher salary than last year and is looking for a new job that is more satisfying.
“For me personally, life is getting better and better.” Andre told The Paper (www.thepaper.cn).
input: The outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
translation:
The first is to eradicate terrorist forces with an iron fist and restore a safe social environment to the Russian people.

When the 48-year-old Putin first became president in 2000, the biggest problems facing Russia were the division of the country and rampant domestic terrorist activities. The shocking thing was that on October 23, 2002, a hostage incident occurred in a Moscow theater, resulting in the death of 129 hostages. , On September 1, 2004, Chechen separatist militants caused a hostage incident at the No. 1 Middle School in Beslan City, North Ossetia Republic in southern Russia, resulting in the death of 333 hostages.

The terrorist incidents spreading in Russia have killed humanity and caused the general public to live in extreme terror, causing the Russian nation's spirit to collapse and shocking the world. Russian media once said that Russia at that time was more terrifying than the dark Middle Ages.

The root cause of the terrorist incident is Chechen separatists. With extraordinary determination, Putin struck hard and ordered the 100,000-strong army to use new weapons and equipment. Over a period of three years, he used air strikes and ground sweeps to get rid of the "nests" of the separatist forces, and then turned to eradicating the fleeing forces. Terrorists everywhere. Putin’s most inspiring vows are that “we must drive terrorists out of cellars and caves where they are hiding” and “shoot them if they are caught at the airport, and drown them in the toilet if they are caught in the toilet.” Under his command, the Russian armed police and special forces promptly surrounded and annihilated all terrorists, allowing the Russian people to obtain a safe social environment, restore normal and harmonious life, and see the hope of the country. Putin, who was trying his best for the first time, won the hearts and minds of the people and his prestige increased greatly.
input:

fix the collapse of the Russian economy and political system.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获得连任 白宫回应 | 大纪元
translation:
His political opponents cannot even be named on the ballot because they are either forced into exile or have been jailed by Putin. Putin's most prominent political rival, Alexei Navalny, died suddenly and mysteriously in a prison above the Siberian Arctic Circle last month.
Apart from Putin, there are indeed three other candidates on the list of candidates on the Russian election ballot, but these three are all unknown candidates put forward by small, symbolic opposition parties that follow the Kremlin line.

The Associated Press quoted observers as saying they had little or no expectation that Russia would hold free and fair elections.

European Council President Charles Michel posted on the social media platform X on Friday to "congratulate" Putin on his resounding victory in the Russian presidential election.

"I would like to congratulate Vladimir Putin on his landslide victory in the elections that start today. There is no opposition, there is no freedom, there is no choice," Michel said.

The Associated Press pointed out in its report that Russian voters had no choice but to vote for Putin this time, and that independent supervision of elections and voting was ineffective.

None of the major international viewing delegations were present. Observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) were also not invited. Only registered candidates or government-recognized advisory bodies can send observers to polling stations. Nearly 100,000 polling stations have been opened across Russia and are open for three days of voting, even though truly independent oversight is inherently difficult.

"The Russian election as a whole is a sham. The Kremlin decides who gets to be on the ballot. The Kremlin decides how those people run. It controls every aspect of the vote and the entire counting process," the Associated Press quoted Those are the words of Sam Greene, director of the Democratic Resilience Program at the Center for European Policy Analysis, a Washington-based think tank.

Ukraine and Western countries have strongly condemned Putin for holding voting in Russian elections in Ukrainian territory occupied by Russian troops.

Two politicians in Russia originally wanted to run in the general election on an anti-war theme, and they received sincere support from quite a lot of people, but the Kremlin banned these two people from running.

Russia's fragmented opposition has called on voters unhappy with Putin's war in Ukraine to go to the polls at noon on Sunday, the last day of voting, to protest. Navalny had endorsed this strategy during his lifetime.

But the Moscow prosecutor's office warned Thursday that the protests were illegal, according to the New York Times. And organizing or participating in protests can result in penalties of up to five years in prison.

The Associated Press believes that Putin also hopes to use his completely predetermined victory to show that his war in Ukraine and his handling of the war have the support of the vast majority of voters.

title: 普京是否值得第五次连任总统？ | 政治 | 半岛电视台
translation:
Political writer Alexander Novogilov told Al Jazeera, “When Putin led Russia, it was in a dangerous state economically and politically, with an economy in recession and a population impoverished.” He added, “Northern Russia was in a dangerous state economically and politically. Caucasian separatist movements have also created their own enclaves, which have expanded over time and put Russia’s territorial integrity at direct risk.”
Novojilov continued: "The strict regime established by the new head of state was able to eliminate these threats and restore state power, and implemented extensive regional and administrative reforms, restored interaction between the center and the regions and strengthened the state's influence on life there Control in every aspect.”
According to him, “Putin was able to achieve two main goals: preserving Russia’s unity and restoring its status as a great power on the world stage. After being almost wiped out of the global balance of power, fifteen years later it became the largest and most powerful country in the world. One of the most influential geopolitical and military players returns to the global stage.”
Regarding internal issues, the author gives examples such as the growth rate of major indices, "Russia currently leads the global average, coupled with the scourge that the Russian economy has been suffering from, represented by inflation, according to established indicators of prosperous countries, reaching reached a record high in the post-Soviet period.”
The speaker also cited tangible improvements in social prosperity and a significant drop in crime rates, "for example, the number of premeditated murders and attempted murders has decreased by more than five times".
On the other hand, political writer Sergei Surdhikov said: "Putin has been unable to solve what he calls the problem of too wide a gap in income among the population, chronic underinvestment in the economy and a low share of investment in gross domestic product."
He also pointed to the continued unpredictability of the economic and political situation, adding that "companies operating in Russia often prefer to register properties and transactions abroad to avoid possible state takeovers or irresponsible court decisions."
Surdhikov explained that, among other factors, "the country is experiencing an outflow of qualified brains due to weak national demand, a lack of promising high-paying jobs and an almost non-existent private sector in high-tech areas".
The political writer himself also believes that the integration process of the CIS countries has failed, and no country, including Belarus and Kazakhstan, has become a true strategic ally of Russia, either militarily or politically, calling it " Situational Partnerships”. He pointed out that the crisis from 2014 to 2018 perfectly demonstrated this point, "Where is the support of these countries on Syria, Crimea and Ukraine?"

title: 枪口之下：被占地区的乌克兰人在俄罗斯选举中支持普京 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
translation:
“There is no secrecy about the vote,” a former resident of Mariupol told Al Jazeera of her friends and relatives’ vote on Wednesday.
“People who love Ukraine have to give in to the regime and pretend they support what is happening because they fear for their lives.”
But she added that some resistance groups, mostly made up of young people, had leaked information to Ukrainian intelligence about the number and location of Russian soldiers and weapons.
Some locals hope that taking part in the vote will give them a real free pass to leave the occupied areas.
Tatyana, who lives in the port of Berdyansk in southern Ukraine, told Al Jazeera, “My father-in-law died of a heart attack. My mother-in-law’s hair has turned white because of what we have been through. We just want to leave and never go back. Don’t look back either.” It should be noted that the Port of Berdyansk was occupied in late February 2022.
It was no surprise that she and her husband voted early for Putin on Monday, as they did not want to be blacklisted by Russian-appointed authorities.
They planned to cross into southern Russia and then fly to Kazakhstan, where their relatives agreed to shelter them.
According to Eastern Human Rights Group, a small number of Ukrainians who refused to vote or spoke out against the election have been rounded up and taken to "basements" - in Russian-occupied Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhia and Kazakhstan. There are many informal prisons in the Ersun area.
The rights group and three Ukrainians interviewed by Al Jazeera (whose full names will not be used for security reasons) reported gun threats at polling stations in occupied areas.
So the only way to safely say "no" is to close the door to election officials and avoid polling stations that open from Friday - the first day of Russia's three-day election.
A former resident of the Russian-occupied southern town of Enelgodar said "no one has reached out" to those who stayed home. She fled to Kiev but remained in contact with family and friends.
The reason is simple - vote manipulation, a phenomenon that has been documented in previous elections in Russia and is widely expected to become more pronounced in the occupied areas of Ukraine.
The former resident quipped, "I think the turnout will be 120 to 150 percent."
Observers agreed, saying Kremlin-appointed officials would compete with each other in vote manipulation to report high turnout and a high percentage of votes cast for Putin.
"In a sham election, there will be maximum fraud, because the local 'governors' will try to outdo Chechnya," Kyiv analyst Alexei Kuschi told Al Jazeera. In the vote held in Chechnya, Putin received nearly 100% turnout and support.

title: 普京得票超87%，就中俄关系、台湾问题表态
translation:
It is worth noting that the 2024 Russian election is the country’s first wartime election. Following the failure of Ukraine's major counteroffensive last summer, the Russian army has continued to consolidate its battlefield advantages over the past few months. Last month, it captured the important town of Avdeyevka in eastern Ukraine and launched attacks on the Ukrainian army in Zaporizhia and other directions. Ukraine has repeatedly attacked Russian oil refineries, shelled Russian territory, and tried to use proxy armed forces to break through the border and cause many sabotage incidents.


Putin said in his speech that the Ukrainian army is launching attacks rashly, and if the enemy likes "meat grinders", it will even be beneficial to us.


Putin also said that Russia advocates peace negotiations on the Ukrainian issue. "We support peace talks, but not because the enemies have run out of ammunition, but because if they are serious about establishing peaceful and good relations in the long run," Putin said.


Putin: Russia's power comes from the people


In his speech, Putin also thanked voters for their trust and support and promised that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.


He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.


"The source of power in Russia is the Russian people." He said that elections are not a formality. The votes of every Russian citizen constitute the unified will of the people, which is the basis for national existence, self-confidence and development, national defense capabilities, science and education, and all important directions. important pillar.


Putin also expressed his stance on issues such as relations with the United States and relations with NATO.


Putin pointed out that it is no secret that NATO has sent soldiers to Ukraine. Russia is very aware of the situation, but the prospects for these soldiers are not good. "We heard French and English there, and first of all it didn't do them any good because they were dying in large numbers," he said.


When asked by a reporter whether a full-scale conflict between Russia and NATO was possible, Putin replied that he believed that "everything is possible" in today's world and that a world war is only one step away, but no one wants such a thing to happen. thing.


Putin said Russia was ready to cooperate with any U.S. president American voters voted for. "We have no preference for any one candidate for President of the United States and will work with the one whom voters give their vote of confidence."





Many countries congratulate Putin on his victory


After Putin sealed his victory in the election, many Russian politicians sent congratulations.


Volodin, Chairman of the Russian State Duma, posted on the social media Telegram: "I congratulate Putin on his convincing victory in the presidential election! This is a victory for all Russian citizens! A strong president is a strong Russia!"


Medvedev, deputy chairman of the Russian Security Council and chairman of the United Russia party, also sent a message of congratulations: "Congratulations to Putin on his brilliant victory in the Russian presidential election!" he wrote on the Telegram channel.


Many countries also congratulated Putin.


Cuban Ambassador to Russia Portel said that Cuban leader Raul Castro congratulated Putin on winning the Russian presidential election.


Venezuelan Foreign Minister Ivan Hill said Venezuelan President Maduro congratulated Putin on winning the presidential election and pointed out that "the turnout was very high." He said that on behalf of the Venezuelan people, Maduro congratulated President Putin on his "overwhelming victory" in the election.


Milorad Dodik, chairman of the Republika Srpska of Bosnia and Herzegovina, said that Putin's victory in the Russian presidential election also pleased the Serb people who regard him as a friend and patron. He said on social media


Bolivian President Luis Arce congratulated Russian President Vladimir Putin on his re-election on social media X, saying that his victory confirmed the unity of the Russian people.

title: 热点问答｜俄总统选举，普京何以压倒性胜出-新华网
translation:
Xinhua News Agency, Beijing, March 18th Hot Questions and Answers｜Russian presidential election: why Putin won overwhelmingly
 Xinhua News Agency reporter Geng Pengyu
 Russia's Central Election Commission announced the results of 100% of the votes in the Russian presidential election on the 18th. The current President Putin received 87.28% of the votes. Putin's vote share not only led by a large margin, but also set a new personal record. How did Putin achieve an overwhelming victory when Russia faced complex domestic and international situations?

 On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 Demonstrate people's unity
 The official voting for the eighth presidential election of the Russian Federation was held from March 15 to 17, with a total of four candidates running. According to the election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected as the president of Russia.

 On March 15, voters voted in the presidential election in Moscow, the capital of Russia. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
 In addition to Putin, Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.31% of the vote; Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia ranked third with 3.85% of the vote; Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third Fourth, the vote rate was 3.20%.

 This is the real-time statistics of the presidential election on a screen taken on the streets of the Russian capital Moscow on March 17. On the 18th, the Russian Central Election Commission also announced the preliminary statistical results of the Russian presidential election. The turnout rate was 77.44%, a new high in Russian history.
 Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that Russia has adopted various methods to make it more convenient for voters to participate in voting. She also said that external attempts to interfere in this presidential election were unprecedented, but the election demonstrated the unity of the Russian people, and the number of voters who voted for the current Russian President Vladimir Putin also reached a new high.
 Pamfilova also expressed her gratitude to the international observers who came to Russia to monitor the voting. She said that the Russian Central Election Commission will officially announce the results of the presidential election on March 21.
 Achievements recognized
 Analysts pointed out that Putin has very rich experience in governing. Under the complex situation currently facing Russia, voters hope that he will continue to lead Russia and lead Russia to move forward.

 This is a video shot of Russian President Putin attending the 14th "Russia is Calling" forum in Moscow on December 7, 2023.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获得连任 白宫回应 | 大纪元
translation:
The three-day Russian general election ends on Sunday (March 17). Exit polls showed that Putin won the election with more than 87% support and was re-elected. The White House and many European countries criticized the election as neither free nor fair.
According to the first official results released by Russia's Central Election Commission after the voting, with about 80% of the votes in precincts completed, current President Vladimir Putin received about 87% of the vote.
Exit polls from the polling agency Public Opinion Foundation (FOM) showed that Putin won 87.8% of the vote, the highest vote share in Russia's post-Soviet history, surpassing the 77% support Putin received in the 2018 election ; Exit polls from the Russian Center for Public Opinion Research (VCIOM) showed that Putin received an approval rating of 87%.
The other three presidential candidates, all from parties loyal to the Kremlin, received less than 4% support in the general election. Putin's most high-profile political rival was Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic exile last month. His supporters called on Russian voters to attend "noon anti-Putin" protests at polling stations on Sunday to express their dissent.
Putin told supporters in a victory speech in Moscow that he would prioritize tasks related to what he called Russia's "special military operations" in Ukraine and would strengthen the Russian military.
According to data from the Central Election Commission shown on state television, the preliminary turnout for this election was 74.22%. It was the highest turnout since Boris Yeltsin became president after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, and well above the 67.5% turnout recorded in 2018. At least six Russian regions claimed turnout exceeded 90%.
Nearly 4.5 million people voted online, the Interfax news agency reported, citing government data.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜选票上，除了普京还有谁？
translation:
The New People's Party is considered a center-right party that is popular among young people and is mainly active in the relatively economically developed regions of central and western Russia. In 2021, the party crossed the 5% vote threshold and entered the Russian State Duma. According to a previous report by "Reference News", Davankov, who was the chairman of the New People's Party's executive committee at the time, said in an interview with the Russian "Viewpoint" newspaper that the New People's Party can hear the voices of young people, which is the reason why the party can enter One of the key elements of the State Duma. He said: "Our activists come from various cities and are young people between the ages of 20 and 27."
In the same year, Davankov was elected deputy chairman of the Russian State Duma. After the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in 2022, Davankov was sanctioned by Western countries for supporting the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk and Russia's "special military operations" against Ukraine. In 2023, Davankov ran for mayor of Moscow, but ultimately failed to win. At that time, he received 5.34% of the votes, ranking 4th among 5 candidates.
On December 24, 2023, the New People Party and the Growth Party jointly nominated Davankov to participate in the Russian presidential election. On the same day, the two parties announced their merger. On January 5, 2024, Russia’s Central Election Commission officially approved Davankov’s candidacy.
In February, Davankov submitted his own campaign platform. The economic content included the development of entrepreneurship and the optimization of national expenditures, while the political content included the "normalization and democratization" of foreign policy. One of the key points was " "According to Russia's terms" and resolve the Russian-Ukrainian conflict through negotiations. According to Davankov, this is a program of "peaceful development". "I have been asked many times about my position. I believe that first of all there should be negotiations. But it is very important that these negotiations should allow our Russia to become independent and strong." Davankov also added, "We all "We want our country to be strong and great, but not just to be feared, but to be proud of its achievements, its people, its success and its economic growth rate."
In addition, Davankov has also stated that he will not criticize other presidential candidates, including current President Putin.
Slutsky: I don’t dream of defeating Putin, I hope to win in special military operations
Leonid Slutsky was born in Moscow in 1968. He is the leader of the Liberal Democratic Party and currently the chairman of the International Affairs Committee of the Russian State Duma.

title: 欧盟和北约：俄大选既不自由也不公平 | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 15.03.2024
translation:
(Deutsche Welle Chinese website) Voting has begun in the Russian presidential election. A day before polling stations opened across the country, the European Union and Nato both said Russia's presidential election was neither free nor fair.
EU spokesman Peter Stano said: "We can know what this election will look like from the track record of how the current Russian government prepares and organizes the vote."
"It is difficult to predict that this will be a free, fair and democratic election in which the Russian people will truly have a choice," Stano said.
NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg pointed out that there is no viable opposition or free press in Russia.
"We already know that opposition politicians have been jailed, some have been killed, many have gone into exile, and some who have actually tried to register to run have been denied that right," he said.
The Russian presidential election takes place this weekend and lasts for three days (March 15-17).
Russian President Vladimir Putin will face off against three Kremlin-approved candidates. No real opposition candidate was allowed to run.
Background reading: Putin – the former KGB’s path to power
The election results are expected to give Putin another six years in power, which would make his total term longer than that of any Russian ruler since Catherine the Great.
 
Prominent opposition leader Alexei Navalny died in prison last month, and his wife Yulia Navalnaya called for protests at polling stations.
Russian authorities have warned against any demonstrations.
"Organizing and participating in such group activities will be punished under current law," the Moscow prosecutor said on Telegram.
While voting in Russia only begins on Friday, voting began on Thursday in four Ukrainian regions it annexed last year.
Ukrainians living under Russian occupation were reportedly coerced into voting, with Moscow urging Ukrainians to vote "for their president" and "participate in the future of our country."
Russian authorities have deployed mobile polling stations, some on people's doorsteps, claiming that voting is safer this way.
 Vadym Boychenko, the Ukrainian mayor of Mariupol in the Donetsk Oblast, which is partially occupied by Russia, described Russia as conducting elections "in ruins."
He informed that a woman showed up at his neighbor's apartment with a ballot box "accompanied by two Chechen soldiers with machine guns" and made it clear that voting was not optional.
Sam Greene, director of the Center for European Policy Analysis in Washington, said: "Elections are an extension of military occupation and war itself... rather than an exercise of the democratic right to vote."
The EU said it would not recognize the vote results in the four regions. "Any election that Russia attempts to organize in the occupied areas of Ukraine is completely illegal and violates international law," Stoltenberg said.
Ahead of the vote, Ukraine stepped up its air strikes against Russia's border areas.
At least two people were killed in an attack on Belgorod on Thursday. The Russian National Guard said they also repelled an attack by pro-Ukrainian militias in Kursk. ​
(AFP, AP)

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
translation:
nThe Paper: In recent years, relations between Russia and the West have deteriorated day by day, and will hit rock bottom after 2022. Is there room for improvement in the future relations between Russia and the West? Will the U.S. election change the external environment Russia is currently facing?
Andrei Kortunov: The deterioration of relations between Russia and Western countries is serious and long-term. The word "forever" should be avoided in politics, but I see no prospect of Russia turning to the West in the near future. Some aspects of Russia’s relations with the West, such as Russia’s strategic partnership with the EU in the energy sector, have been irreversibly damaged. After the current Russian-Ukrainian conflict is over, some aspects can resume, such as normal diplomatic interactions, direct flights, or educational and cultural cooperation, but relations between Russia and the West will not return to the past interaction model.
As for the US election, I would not overestimate its importance for the future of US-Russian relations: after all, Trump was the occupant of the White House from 2017 to 2022, and during that period, the relationship between Russia and the US Not only did it not improve, it got worse. Of course, people hope that after the start of a new political cycle in the United States, relations between Russia and the United States can at least stabilize.
The Paper: In the current context of continued Western aid to Ukraine, the failure of the European arms control system, and uncertain prospects for Russia-Ukraine peace talks, will the Russia-Ukraine conflict evolve into a larger-scale war?
Andrei Kortunov: Unfortunately, this danger is real. NATO countries are now increasingly drawn into the conflict, and some politicians, such as French President Emmanuel Macron, are talking about the possibility of sending Western troops to Ukraine. The stakes of the conflict are high, and neither side is willing to concede victory to its opponent. Furthermore, the possibility of a direct military conflict between Russia and NATO cannot be completely ruled out, taking into account technical errors, unexpected escalations, or other adverse circumstances.
input: Russia facing complex economic and social challenges.

title: 白宫批评俄罗斯选举“不公平”,普京在胜选记者会回应:全世界都在嘲笑美国发生的事
translation:
In the early morning of the 18th local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data showing that among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the presidential election. According to reports from Reuters and Russia Today Television (RT), Putin refuted the criticism from the US White House that the Russian presidential election was "not free" and "unfair" when he delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th.

RT said that Putin said that while criticizing the democratic process of other countries, the U.S. government also used administrative power and resources to suppress one of the United States' own presidential candidates. RT stated that Putin’s mention of “one of the (U.S.) presidential candidates” obviously refers to Trump. According to reports, Trump, as the front-runner in the Republican Party in the US election, is currently facing a series of lawsuits.

"The whole world is laughing at what is happening there (in the United States)," Putin said. "This is a disaster. This is not democracy. So what is this?"

RT mentioned that Putin stated in a previous interview that Russia will not interfere in foreign elections and will cooperate with any elected US president. According to the report, earlier in an interview with the president of Russia Today International News Agency, Putin said, "I think everyone is very clear that the political system of the United States cannot be called a democracy in any sense." Putin declined to comment further on the current U.S. election, but he described the atmosphere in the election as becoming "increasingly uncivilized."

According to media reports, the official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed. Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed.

Putin delivering a speech.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
translation:
As in previous elections, Putin will not participate in pre-election debates. Russian Presidential Press Secretary Peskov explained that Putin is the current head of state and has a very busy schedule, which makes him fundamentally different from other candidates. The president himself appears in the media every day, and Russians have a daily opportunity to see what Putin has to say about everything.
For voters, considering that voting in this presidential election will also be conducted using a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting, voters can apply for remote electronic voting from January 29 to March 11, 2024, and officially vote. The time is from 8:00 on March 15 to 20:00 on March 17.
Starting from February 25, early voting will begin in remote and inaccessible areas of Russia. Starting from March 1, Russians abroad can also start voting in advance. The formal voting will be held from March 15th to 17th. The votes will be counted from the 18th, and the voting results will be counted by the 28th at the latest. Any citizen of the Russian Federation who is 18 years of age or older on the voting day, has legal capacity, and is not sentenced by a court and is incarcerated may vote.
According to Russian law, if a candidate receives more than 50% of the votes in the first round of voting, he will be directly elected president. If no one obtains more than half of the votes, the two leading candidates will enter the second round of voting three weeks after the first round of voting, and the candidate with more votes will be elected president.
What’s special about the 2024 Russian election?
The 2024 Russian election will be the country’s first presidential election after the adoption of a constitutional amendment in 2020, and it will also be Russia’s first wartime election.
In November 2023, Putin signed an amendment to the presidential election law. According to a previous report by CCTV News, Vladimir Poletaev, the first deputy chairman of the Constitutional Committee of the Russian Federation Council, said when explaining the new amendment that according to the results of negotiations between the Central Election Committee of the Russian Federation and the Russian Ministry of Defense, those in the war Subjects of the Russian Federation in the current state can still vote in elections.

translation: Let us just remember the famous “carousels” and forced voting at enterprises and universities. Finally, thirdly, Putin’s lack of real competition and strong opponents played a role. title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
translation:
In the Russian presidential election that attracted worldwide attention a few days ago, the incumbent President Vladimir Putin was re-elected with 87.26% of the vote. This makes people wonder why Putin was able to win the election with an unprecedented high number of votes and an absolute advantage in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

The answer is clear. 24 years ago, Putin quoted the politician Stolypin's words, "Give Russia 20 years to stabilize both internally and externally, and it will become unrecognizable to you." This sentence later spread in China, and Putin said, "Give Russia 20 years to stabilize both internally and externally." I have been a miracle in Russia for twenty years." With his unique ideas, abilities and achievements, Putin has created an extraordinary country, which is highly recognized and appreciated by the Russian people. In the 24 years since he became the first president, his approval rate has remained above 65%, which is rare in the world.
input: Putin's re-election as President of Russia.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
translation:
Chen Pokong told Voice of America: “A Russian election was reported in China, which can be said to be an inspiration to China’s sober people, or an opportunity for them to complain, but it is not for brainwashed people like Little Pink and the Fifty Cent Party. There will be no sobriety or reflection.”
Internet ironic messages highlight Chinese netizens’ awareness of rights

Chen Pokong said that although various "pink" discussions on Weibo have an overwhelming advantage, they are all the result of China's official censorship of speech. For example, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi reported at a press conference held during the "Two Sessions" in March that there were more than 1,500 comments in the comment area, but only 13 could be displayed. Apparently, the other 1,400-plus comments were officials who were unwilling or afraid to display them. Therefore, Chen Pokong said that there are more and more sober people in China.

Internet celebrity writer Shangguan Luan believes that young people’s perceptions of international politics often depend on their own circumstances. For example, young people in China are trapped in the dilemma of rising unemployment and plummeting wages, and may no longer be easily convinced by official explanations.

Taipei scholar Liu Xiaoxiang said that Putin and Xi Jinping have been able to monopolize power for a long time because the two countries have different forms of autocratic systems, but the essence is the same. Putin rose to power with the slogan of "leading the country to rejuvenation" when Russia's reforms failed, while Xi Jinping gradually centralized power through anti-corruption, eliminating dissidents.

Liu Xiaoxiang said that Chinese netizens lamented that Russia at least still has a voting mechanism, which represents their yearning for democracy. However, whether China can move toward democracy depends on how the people persist in their demands. For example, the White Paper Movement at the end of last year successfully forced the CCP to give up on clearing the country. policy.

translation:
What position did Western countries take?
The G7 countries (USA, UK, Canada, Germany, France, Italy and Japan) and the representative of the European Union announced on February 24 that the holding of elections in Crimea, DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions violates the sovereignty of Ukraine and they do not recognize the results . Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova called this statement biased: the time of the G7, in her words, is “irretrievably gone.”

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
translation:
"The election in Russia is an election without choice," German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said at the start of the meeting.
French Foreign Minister Stephane Sejourne said Paris had taken note of Russia's "extraordinary electoral actions", mocking Putin for calling his aggressive war in Ukraine two years ago an "extraordinary military campaign" action". Speaking on behalf of the French government, he said, "None of the conditions for free, pluralistic and democratic elections have been met."
British Foreign Secretary David Cameron (former British Prime Minister) said that the election results highlighted the "intensity of repression" in Russia. He said, "Putin eliminated his political opponents, controlled the media, and then crowned himself. This is not democracy."
France, Britain and other countries also jointly condemned Russia for holding elections in occupied areas of Ukraine it said it annexed during the war.
A White House spokesman said Sunday that Russia's election was "clearly neither free nor fair."
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russia's election had no legitimacy. He said, "It is clear to everyone in the world that this figure (Putin)... is crazy for power and is doing everything he can to rule forever."
The Kremlin dismissed the criticism, saying Putin won 87% of the vote in the three-day election, showing that the Russian people were rallying around him.
In sharp contrast to Europe, Chinese Communist Party leader Xi Jinping and the leaders of India, North Korea and Iran all congratulated Putin on his re-election.
According to the Xinhua News Agency of the Communist Party of China, Xi Jinping congratulated Putin on the phone that day, saying that his re-election "fully reflects the support of the Russian people...". He told Putin, "I believe that under your leadership, Russia will be able to achieve greater achievements in national development and construction." Xi Jinping also promised Putin that the CCP is willing to promote "the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era." ".

title: 俄大选最后一天：“中午反普京”行动引爆全球-环球大观-万维读者网（电脑版）
translation:
Russia's "tailor-made" election for Putin's re-election entered its final day on Sunday, and the "anti-Putin at noon" event launched by the opposition appeared as scheduled. People were rushing to the polls at the same time, either throwing away their ballots or voting for other candidates. Others went to Navalny’s grave and cast their votes there.
Thousands of people came to polling stations in Russia and world capitals on Sunday to take part in what Russia's opposition called "peaceful but symbolic protests," Reuters reported.
People showed up at the polling stations at noon at the same time, no matter how they disposed of their votes, just to show their opposition to Vladimir Putin's re-election by gathering at noon, and to show that they were not alone.
Vote Navalny
In the operation, dubbed "Noontime Against Putin," large numbers of Russians went to local polling stations around noon to either throw away their ballots or vote for any of the three other candidates.
Others vowed to put on their ballots the name of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month. Others went directly to Navalny’s grave in Moscow to symbolically The vote went to him. Agence France-Presse said Navalny’s grave was no longer visible and was covered with flowers.
Navalny's allies posted videos on YouTube of people queuing up at polling stations across Russia around noon, saying they were staging peaceful protests.
During his lifetime, Navalny posted a message on social media with the assistance of his lawyer, expressing his support for the "Noontime Anti-Putin" plan. The independent newspaper Novaya Gazeta called the plan "Navalny's political testament."
"It's a long shot, but if you can do something [like this], you should do it. Democracy is gone," one young woman said at a polling station. She did not give her name and Navalny's team blurred her face.
input:
The final day of voting in Russia's presidential election on March 17.
Casting rigged ballots in a Russian election.

title: 普京顺利五连任是“假选举”？ 中国网民: 至少俄罗斯人能投票
translation:
Putin’s re-election: China’s officials are hot but the people are cold

However, the comment section under the post continued to overturn. Some Chinese netizens left comments criticizing: "Putin is a modern-day Hitler. He launched this war because he wanted to save face and suffer the consequences, and he insisted on dragging the country and people into the abyss of disaster." Another Chinese netizen commented. Not optimistic about Putin's fate, he left a message saying: "I admit that I am not mainstream, and the aggressor will lose."

In addition to criticism, some people also voiced their dissatisfaction and doubts about Russia. For example, one netizen left a message saying: "It's time to raise the issue of the 1.6 million square kilometers captured by them with Putin." Another netizen asked Hu Xijin to express his position and asked him "What do you think of the Russians' high-profile commemoration of the Soviet Union's fallen soldiers in the Battle of Zhenbao Island?" One sentence put it bluntly. It is a border dispute that neither Chinese nor Russian officials want to mention.

The Zhenbao Island Incident refers to the armed conflict that broke out on the Zhenbao Island (called Damansky Island in Russia) in the Heilongjiang River Basin in March 1969 between the Soviet Union and the Chinese People's Liberation Army. Both sides suffered casualties. Although it has been 55 years, many Chinese video bloggers commemorated this battle in a high-profile manner at the beginning of this month in order to protest against Russia's stimulation of nationalist sentiments during the Russo-Ukrainian War. However, China Officials seem to have no intention of revisiting the controversy, apparently deliberately keeping a low profile.

Shangguan Luan, a writer originally from Sichuan, China, who now immigrated to Taiwan, said in an interview with Voice of America that although it is difficult to truly grasp Chinese netizens' personal views on Russia and Putin through Weibo volume under China's strict Internet censorship, she believes , except for the little pinks who have a poor historical perspective, many Chinese people still remember the history of Sino-Soviet enmity and view the current Sino-Russian diplomacy rationally.

Shangguan Ran said: "There is also a more liberal group. They say that if the United States hadn't been staring at him every day, Putin's next prey would have been China. They are still very wary of Putin's wolfish ambitions ( There are also many people in China.”
With the Russian election hotly debated, Chinese netizens sarcastically asked: What does a ballot look like?

In addition to being wary of Russia, some Chinese netizens also used Russia's presidential election, which is recognized internationally as rigged, to mock the Chinese for not even being qualified to vote for national leaders.

Reports said that Putin also sang the Russian national anthem with the attendees after his speech. After the singing of the national anthem, Putin said, "We are proud of Russia!" title: 新闻人物｜俄罗斯当选总统普京简历
translation:
From March 15th to 17th, Russia held official voting for the presidential election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, announced the election results on the 21st. Current President Putin was elected as the eighth president of the Russian Federation with 87.28% of the vote.
On March 21, 2024 local time, in Moscow, Russia, Putin’s voting results were displayed on the video screen at the meeting of the Russian Central Election Commission. Visual China Map

Putin was born in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg) on ​​October 7, 1952. He graduated from the Law Department of Leningrad University in 1975 and later received an associate doctorate in economics. He worked in the Soviet state security apparatus, including in the GDR from 1985 to 1990.
After returning to China in 1990, Putin successively served as the foreign affairs assistant to the president of Leningrad University, advisor to the mayor of St. Petersburg, chairman of the municipal government's external liaison committee, and first deputy mayor of St. Petersburg. In August 1996, he served as deputy director of the Russian Presidential Affairs Administration, in March 1997, as deputy director of the Russian Presidential Administration and director of the General Inspectorate, and in May 1998, he became first deputy director of the presidential administration. In March 1999, Putin served as Secretary of the Security Council of the Russian Federation. On August 9, 1999, he was appointed First Deputy Prime Minister and Acting Prime Minister, and took office as Prime Minister on August 16. On December 31, 1999, then-President Yeltsin announced his resignation and Putin became acting president. In 2000, Putin was elected president for the first time and was successfully re-elected in 2004. In May 2008, Putin became Prime Minister of the Russian government. In 2012, Putin was re-elected as president and has been re-elected in 2018. In March 2024, Putin ran for the presidency as an independent candidate.

The four candidates are: current Russian President Vladimir Putin, leader of the Liberal Democratic Party Leonid Slutsky, member of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolay Kharitonov, and member of the Russian New People Party Vladislav Davanko husband.

title: 俄罗斯外交部发言人扎哈罗娃回怼西方：想想默克尔干了几届？
translation:
As everyone expected, the current Russian President Vladimir Putin successfully won re-election, and various accusations from Western countries were also thrown away. Moscow quickly responded and named Merkel, who has served as German Chancellor for four consecutive times and has been at the helm of Germany for 16 years.


According to a report by "Russia Today" on March 18, a spokesperson for the Russian Foreign Ministry said that a series of NATO actions against Russia will only help Putin win a fifth term. Zakharova said that by consolidating NATO's image as a "dangerous enemy" in the minds of Russians, the West precisely ensured Putin's historic victory in the presidential election.


According to Russian media, the German Foreign Ministry said that the Russian presidential election was "neither free nor fair" and that "the results were not surprising." The White House echoed this statement last Sunday. British Defense Secretary Shapps accused Putin of "stealing the election again" but "cannot steal Ukraine."​


According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission on the 18th, with all votes counted, current President Putin received 87.28% of the vote, overwhelmingly winning his fifth term. The "Russia Today" website also pointed out that the turnout rate in this year's election was as high as 74%, which not only exceeded the 67.47% in the 2018 election, but also set a record high. The "Donetsk People's Republic", the "Luhansk People's Republic" and the Kherson and Zaporizhia regions participated in the elections for the first time.





On March 18, local time, in Moscow, a large-scale music rally was held in Red Square to commemorate the tenth anniversary of Crimea's "entry into Russia". Russian President Vladimir Putin and three presidential candidates Slutsky, Kharitonov and Davankov attended. Image from IC Photo


As Putin sealed the victory in advance, Zakharova refuted Western accusations on the social media platform Telegram on the 17th, saying that Western countries just cannot tolerate Russia's show of unity, especially Germany. She also reminded the West that Merkel had been elected German Prime Minister four times in a row, and her predecessor Helmut Kohl had been in power for 16 consecutive years.


"Germans themselves are wondering whether this fits with the German understanding of democracy... For some reason no one talks about a lack of freedom or injustice," she wrote.


Zakharova said that regarding the Russian elections, the only consensus she has with Germany is that the results are "unsurprising": "NATO barks at our country several times a day, threatening us and causing conflicts on our borders... It’s no surprise that the whole country (Russia) unites to fight back!”


In another post, she went on to refute the British defense secretary's claims that Putin "stole" the election: "We didn't steal anything from them and we didn't give them anything. So they're angry."


On the evening of March 17, local time, the voting for the Russian presidential election ended. Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters and answered questions from reporters on special military operations, the possibility of negotiations with Ukraine, relations with the United States, and relations with NATO.


Putin warned the West that day that a direct conflict between Russia and the U.S.-led NATO meant that the earth was "only one step away" from World War III. He first joked lightly that "everything is possible in the modern world," and then He also responded seriously that "almost no one wants this to happen." He also revealed that NATO military personnel are actually present in Ukraine, so Russian soldiers have learned to speak English and French on the battlefield.


Putin refuted criticisms from the United States and Western countries that the Russian election was "unfree" and "unfair." He said that U.S. elections are truly "undemocratic" and some people even use the country's public power to deal with former President Trump. "The whole world is laughing at what happened there. It's just a disaster, it's not 'democracy', what is it?"
input:

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·专访｜科尔图诺夫：存在与北约发生直接冲突的可能
translation:
For Putin, the fourth presidential term from 2018 to 2024 will not be easy. At the beginning of his term, Putin's approval rating experienced a rare decline due to the Russian government's implementation of a delayed retirement policy. "Pain points" such as eradicating poverty, achieving net population growth, and boosting Russia's economic development have also appeared in Putin's State of the Union address for many years. In addition to people's livelihood issues, the relationship between Russia and the West has continued its previous deterioration. After Russia launched a "special military operation" in February 2022, Western countries imposed unprecedented all-round sanctions on Russia. The political, economic and trade, cultural exchanges and arms control systems of both parties were severely impacted.
Two years after the war was postponed, the Russian economy has shown some resilience. After experiencing a 2.1% contraction in 2022, the Russian economy will achieve 3.6% growth in 2023. Some analysts believe that record-high defense spending and a strong military industry are the main driving forces behind the Russian economy's ability to maintain growth under Western sanctions. At the same time, Russia's long-term gradual de-dollarization and "turn east" and "turn south" strategies have also helped it offset the adverse effects of Western financial and energy sanctions to a certain extent. However, in the face of high inflation, labor shortages and the adverse effects of long-term sanctions, the sustainability of Russia's wartime economy remains to be seen.
Regarding Russia's development path in the next six years, Putin gave a detailed outlook in his State of the Union address in February this year. In his longest State of the Union address to date, Putin mentioned that Russia’s current task is to develop the defense industry and thereby increase the country’s scientific, technological and industrial potential. It must allocate resources as rationally as possible and establish an effective wartime economic system. . While accelerating the solution of Russia's social, demographic, infrastructure and other problems, we must also raise the equipment of the army and navy to a new level. According to the Russian federal budget plan, Russian military spending will exceed social spending for the first time in 2024.
For Putin, who is entering his fifth term, the next six years will still be difficult to say easy. The dawn of peace talks between Russia and Ukraine has not yet appeared, the confrontation between Russia and the West has intensified, and the risk of conflict expansion still exists. In Russia, how to deal with people's fatigue and dissatisfaction with the delay of the war and strike a balance between strengthening national defense and responding to people's livelihood needs are also difficult problems that Putin has to face.
input:
Decline in various metrics and rates in Russia.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Russia's economic growth.
NATO's eastward expansion and its geopolitical consequences.

Independent observers noted numerous violations in the organization of voting. In addition to stuffing and "carousels", it was also reported that in some areas the voting booths had no curtains: police officers monitored what voters marked on the ballot and detained them if they did not like it.
