title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
translation:
What are the important nodes in the general election?
On December 7, 2023, the Russian Federation Council passed a resolution confirming the time for the 2024 Russian general election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, officially announced on the 8th that voting in the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held for three days, lasting from March 15th to 17th.
According to Russian law, self-recommended candidates must submit campaign-related materials before December 27, 2023. On December 18, 2023, Russian President Vladimir Putin came to the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation and submitted relevant documents for self-recommendation to participate in the 2024 presidential election. Each political party can nominate its party candidates at their respective congresses and submit relevant materials before January 1, 2024. Thereafter, self-recommended candidates and candidates nominated by parties that have not entered the State Duma need to collect signatures and submit them to the Russian Central Election Commission before January 31 and await certification.
On February 10, after completing the review of materials submitted by each candidate, current President Putin, Slutsky (Russian Liberal Democratic Party), Kharitonov (Russian Federation Communist Party) and Davankov (Russian New People's Party) ) is qualified to stand for election. After that, the campaign officially kicked off.
From February 17 until the official voting begins, candidates can carry out pre-election publicity activities in the media and release their own campaign videos. Offline, all candidates have the right to conduct pre-election activities such as meeting with voters and holding rallies. At the same time, candidates nominated by political parties need to submit a campaign platform no later than 10 days before voting and publish it on the Internet and the media.

Submission of documents to the Russian Central Election Commission.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
In all areas of public life, including economics, politics, culture, ideology and religion, (Russia's) interaction with the outside world should be relatively limited. In this way, the impact of external forces (on Russia) will be significantly smaller than the impact of internal factors. "This is how the document defines it.
By 2014, the last round of the Ukraine crisis broke out, and Western countries led by the United States imposed more than 90 rounds of sanctions on Russia in the financial and economic fields. Since then, Russia has begun to try to build a resilient and self-sufficient "fortress" system in accordance with the concept of the document. Reducing U.S. dollar holdings, developing its own payment system Mir, changing trade partner countries, etc. are all manifestations of "Russian Fortress" in the economic field. In the political field, measures such as strengthening ideology and banning foreign NGOs have also been introduced.
At the same time, going back to the article about the top-level design of "Russian Fortress", the Russian political elite believes that the foundation of isolationist ideology is achieved by designing new ideas rather than relying on political bans. “Fortress Russia” is an inherent revision of Russia’s economic, social and foreign policy. When needed, it can be "activated" to prepare Russia for the next cold or hot war. When foreign countries no longer threaten Russia, they should put down this concept and return to the international community, including the West.
In addition, "Fortress Russia" should avoid reminding Russians of the closed planned economy system of the Soviet era. After all, the sight of endless queues has been a nightmare for generations of Russians. Therefore, "Fortress Russia" will be an operating system that, although relatively closed, follows market principles. Trying to maintain the livelihood of ordinary people as much as possible has become the key to determining whether the "fortress" can survive.
Although a large number of Russians currently highly agree that Russia will win and support the Putin government, which has exceeded the expectations of Western public opinion, some Russian think tanks and polling agencies also believe that this sense of identification may not be maintained for a long time.
According to some Western analysts, the Kremlin has set a difficult task for this election, that is, Putin must obtain a record vote share (more than 80%) and a very high voter turnout (more than 70%) .
The war has become the core of Russian politics since 2022, profoundly affecting all major policies and decisions. But war did not become the overriding theme of the presidential election.
In fact, although the battle on the frontline is still fierce and the outcome is still unclear, its presence in the general election is relatively invisible and it does not occupy an absolute central position. The reason behind this: Echoes of the Battlefield wasn't very popular.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
translation:
I am now working in foreign trade, shipping cars from Germany, but I also have business dealings with China. European cars, not only German cars, are very popular in Russia. But there are also a lot of Chinese cars on sale now. It's much cooler than before, a huge change.
After Western sanctions, it's hard to explain that everything is different. Direct foreign trade routes were almost all closed. However, our cooperation with China is getting closer and closer. As for Europe, we used to have direct trade with Europe, but now we don’t, and it has become very difficult to do business. But there is still a way to go. That's "parallel import", which is what I do now.
I would say that sanctions have opened up many new windows of opportunity, but they have also eliminated some past opportunities. When the economy is stable, all markets are already allocated. If you are not a genius like Musk, it is quite difficult to start from scratch. And times of change open up new markets that are easy to enter. For example, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, everything was in short supply. People made millions of dollars from chewing gum and Snickers bars. Crises are always new opportunities.
I made more before the war because I was an importer and distributor for two German companies. However, the difference between current income and past income is not too big. But you have to know that the ruble has devalued three times in recent years. This means that even though people receive more rubles, their real income is still less. For Russians, the world is no longer what it used to be.

Working.

title: 西方指责俄总统选举不公正 中朝贺普京当选 | 俄罗斯 | 中国 | 乌克兰 | 大纪元
translation:
In Africa, the West has been trying to win over African countries to isolate Moscow over the war in Ukraine. Some newspapers believe that Putin's re-election has strengthened the pro-Russian stance of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger.
The above three countries are located in the Sahel region (the Sahel region, which refers to a strip of more than 3,800 kilometers long between the Sahara Desert in northern Africa and the Sudanese grassland region in central Africa, starting from the Atlantic Ocean in the west and extending to the Horn of Africa in the east). In recent years, After the coup, they strengthened relations with Russia at the expense of their traditional allies France and the United States.
"Burkina Faso Daily" (Aujourd'hui au Faso) stated that "Putin's re-election may sound insignificant in Africa, but in the context of the Sahel region, it has special significance because Putin controls the African continent. A new geopolitical balance of power, with Russia’s growing presence and influence.”
Although Putin's electoral victory is no longer in doubt, whether he can maintain his iron grip on power, especially his eventual victory on the Ukraine issue, is far from a sure thing. He experienced a clear miscalculation when his government's "Special Military Operation" in Ukraine did not succeed as quickly as expected, as well as the mercenary Wagner Group leader Yevgeny Prigozhin It launched an insurgency and suffered successive battlefield defeats, while Western sanctions cut off much of the Russian economy from global markets.
Importantly, the U.S. presidential election in November is likely to change the situation in the Russia-Ukraine war. Whether Putin can get out of the predicament is difficult to predict. U.S. President Joe Biden has yet to comment on Putin's victory.
(This article refers to reports from Reuters)
Editor in charge: Li Lin#

title: 普京赢得俄总统选举，表示将继续推动国家发展
translation:
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election.
Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.24% of the votes, Davankov of the New People's Party of Russia ranked third with 3.99% of the votes, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third with 3.16% of the votes. The rate ranks fourth.
Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
Putin said at the subsequent press conference that he would continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all major tasks for national development have been spelled out in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of Parliament and that every effort will be made to achieve the set goals.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on the 17th that Russia invited 1,115 international observers from 129 countries and regions to monitor the voting to ensure that the election was fair and transparent.

title: 没有对手的选举：俄罗斯展开总统大选投票，普京获胜几无悬念
translation:
Russian voters began to go to polling stations across the country on Friday (March 15) for a three-day vote to elect a new president. However, as the current President Putin suppresses dissent, eradicates dissent and noise, and bans two opposition candidates from running, this election is widely regarded as just a show. Putin will win without any suspense and win another six-year election. year term.

The Associated Press pointed out in its report that before the Russian election, Putin unscrupulously suppressed independent media and major human rights groups, and had firmly controlled Russia's entire political system in his hands.
The Russian election was also held as the Russo-Ukrainian war entered its third year. Moscow has an absolute advantage over Kiev in terms of soldiers and weapons. Therefore, the Russian army has taken the initiative on the battlefield and achieved some small and slow results in the battle. However, Ukraine's fighting spirit has not diminished, and the Ukrainian army often launches attacks behind enemy lines and even directly attacks Russia itself. Long-range attack drones have hit Moscow many times, and high-tech drones and unmanned boats destroyed nearly one-third of the main ships of the Russian Black Sea Fleet.

Because Russia is so large and spans 11 time zones, Russian voters have three days from Friday to Sunday to go to the polls to vote. Residents of Ukrainian territories illegally annexed by Russia can also vote. Russians will also be able to vote online for the first time in a presidential election.

The Associated Press quoted Russian authorities as saying that more than 200,000 local voters completed voting quickly after polling stations in Moscow opened on Friday.

Putin, 71, is running for his fifth presidential term and has faced almost no challenge.

title: 华语智库:为什么普京能高票胜选连任俄总统？当天他给我国送来“超级大礼”！
translation:
The second is to strive to develop the economy and lead the country from "second or third rate" to the top five in the world.

Before Putin became the first Russian president, he pointed out in his article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia is now facing very complex economic and social problems. In the 1990s (of the last century), Russia's GDP dropped by almost 50% , equivalent to one-tenth that of the United States and one-fifth that of China. After the 1998 crisis, Russia's per capita GDP dropped to US$3,500, which is only one-fifth of the average level of the 'Seven Big Countries'." . "Russia is in the most difficult historical period in its hundreds of years. This is probably the first time in the past 200-300 years that Russia is truly in danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world."

Because Putin objectively and correctly viewed and evaluated Russia’s economic situation 24 years ago, the second part of the “Russian Federation’s National Security Concept” approved in January of the year he took office, “Russia’s National Interests,” pointed out that “Russia’s national interests in the economic field "Interests are the most important national interests", and the top priority in Russia's domestic and foreign policies is "overcoming poverty."

Concept navigation has a difficult start. Putin's economic strategy was launched amid the economic downturn of his predecessor Yeltsin. On the one hand, he adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms; on the other hand, he used a "strongman" style to vigorously combat oligarchy and restore the country's control over the economic lifeline. At the same time, based on Russia's basic national conditions, he proposed resource-dependent economic development as the basis , with the goal of pursuing and achieving rapid economic growth, in the first eight years of his tenure, Russia achieved an economic development process from emerging from crisis to restorative growth, and then to gradual revitalization, maintaining an average growth rate of nearly 7%. Entering the ranks of the world's top ten economies.

In the following 10 years, although Russia was severely affected by the decline of the international economic situation and the epidemic, and the Russian economy encountered various difficulties, Russia's GDP still grew by 3.6% last year, which was higher than the world average. Russia's economic situation has ranked sixteenth in the world since 2000, lagging behind Spain and the Netherlands, and even surpassed by Brazil, India, South Korea and other countries. In 2023, Russia has become the largest economy in Europe, and its gross national product ranks first in the world. Fifth, the domestic poverty problem has been improved, with the number of poor people reduced from more than 42 million 23 years ago to the current 13.5 million. In 2014 and 2018, Russia had the capability to host the Sochi Winter Olympics and the World Cup.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
translation:
As for the anti-war candidate Boris Nadezhdin, tens of thousands of Russians lined up to sign in support, but ultimately failed to register as a candidate.
Russian voters will cast their votes over three days, March 15-17, for the first time in the country's presidential election history.
The three-day voting format first appeared in the 2020 constitutional amendment vote and the vote on protecting public health during the new crown epidemic. Independent observers have criticized this approach as making it difficult to ensure transparency in the voting process, but this election has adopted this format again.
In addition, this presidential election will for the first time use remote online voting systems, mainly in areas known for protest voting or where authorities have difficulty ensuring turnout.
Russia has also been criticized for including Ukraine's occupied territories in the election, with reports of pressure on local residents.
The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) Parliamentary Assembly has sent observers to Russian elections since 1993 but has stopped in the past three years.
There are no independent opinion polls in Russia, and most Russians get their news from state-owned media, which is heavily biased in favor of Putin and his policies.
Experts believe that more Russians are skeptical of the government than appears on the surface, but even the slightest move to support the opposition may be severely punished, so dissidents are afraid to speak out publicly.
Navalny's widow, Yulia, called on compatriots to boycott the vote and asked foreign governments not to recognize the results of the election.
The latter is unlikely to come true, but the former is possible. The independent Russian media "Medusa" quoted a source close to Putin as saying that the authorities were indeed worried about low turnout. “Why would people vote if they didn’t have any doubt that the current president would win?”
The most likely outcome of this election, at least on paper, is a convincing victory for Putin.
But low turnout would mean weakening support for the president, which in turn could usher in tighter state controls and plunge Russia further into a climate of fear and oppression.
input:
People lining up at polling stations in Russia.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选：普京为何大费周章举行这次选举 - BBC News 中文
translation:
Over the past 24 months, hundreds of thousands of Russians, mostly educated and well-off young people, have left the country, either because they disagree with the war or because they do not want to be drafted into the army.
Even when not involved in the campaign, war is an important theme in the media and Russians cannot avoid it.
High turnout and high support for the president will increase the legitimacy of his subsequent decisions, many of which will be directly related to the invasion of Ukraine.
In addition to Putin, there are three other registered candidates: the nationalist conservative candidate Leonid Slutsky, the communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov and the New People's Party's Vladislav Davankov). The New People's Party was newly formed and had a small number of representatives in the lower house of the Russian Duma.
All three have expressed support for Putin and Russia's war in Ukraine, and none of them poses a real threat.
Putin's real challengers are either in jail, eliminated or have fled Russia. Navalny, Putin's fiercest opponent, died in a high-security prison in February.
BBC reporter Steve Rosenberg asked candidate Kharitonov if he thought he would be a better president than Putin. He replied that it was not for him to say and that voters would "decide everything." He has been subject to Western sanctions since 2022.
Leonid Slutsky, a member of Russia’s Liberal Democratic Party (LDPR), has been accused of sexual harassment many times. He organized a state visit to occupied Crimea, which has been subject to international sanctions since 2014.
Vladislav Davankov of the New People's Party has the lowest exposure in the media. He is the co-founder of a cosmetics company and received just over 5% of the vote in the 2023 Moscow mayoral election. While advocating for "peace and negotiation" in the war with Ukraine, Davankov voted for the annexation of Ukrainian territory, which also led to him being subject to international sanctions.

translation:
At noon today, hundreds of Russians were waiting in line at polling stations at Russian embassies and consulates in Australia, Japan, Armenia, Kazakhstan, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
Navalny's widow in Berlin
In Berlin, Navalny's widow Yulia appeared at the Russian embassy to join protests there, along with Navalny's spokesman Kira Yarmish. Other Russians present applauded and chanted her name.
But not all Russians who came to vote at noon on Sunday were in the opposition. In London, a man queuing to vote wore a top that read "Jesus is my savior." Putin is my president."
Others protested.
Voter Natalya Cherednikova said in London: "For the past 30 years, our voices have not been heard. No one has listened to our voices. We move, we emigrate, and even here, far away from Russia, we And also feeling the consequences of not being heard”.
She said, "This year has been very important for ourselves, even though all of us... are fatalistic and no one really cares. We are here just for ourselves. We have voted. We show up."
Further reading:
Although there is no suspense about Putin’s “win” in the general election, “anti-Putin” crowds were seen at noon on the final voting day


On March 17, 2024, during the Russian presidential election, people gathered at a polling station in the Siberian city of Novosibirsk.
The three-day voting in Russia's general election entered the final day on Sunday (March 17). After eliminating dissidents and suppressing dissent, the current President Vladimir Putin has secured an overwhelming "victory" even without counting the votes. But the opposition, which is banned from running in the election, is still calling on people to go to the polls at noon on the last day of voting to express symbolic protests.

translation:
Between the start of the war and now, I have seen an increase in thefts. People started trying not to pay for their purchases because there wasn't enough money to live on. Inflation is very high, but income growth ratios are not keeping up. In general, we live on credit. Some families paid their entire income into the loan. Now that's not enough.
Our institutions of power will still vote for Putin. But there are a lot of complaints from the increasingly poor lower classes, who are working harder to survive.
The war wiped out the Slavs. But as long as the war benefits those at the top, it won't end.
Russians are very patient. Starting that year (2022), we adapted to the new reality. Hatred is meaningless, just adapt. This is how we live.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
In Nikita's main English class, he noticed that some students were becoming less serious. After several conversations and inquiries, he discovered that the original problem lay with the parents or grandparents of the students: some elderly villagers began to think that English was the "enemy language." This view influenced the children in family conversations, making them I also feel disgusted with English classes.
Unlike the urban middle class who have been unable to get used to the war, the villagers in Village A seem to have quickly adapted to the "new normal" under the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Nikita, who has lived there for nearly two years, recalled that there was indeed a panic in the village at first, but it passed quickly because everyone believed that the Russian army could quickly complete the "special military operation" announced by the Kremlin. However, as the situation became tense and the "blitzkrieg" failed, the Russian army had to withdraw from the outskirts of Kiev, and people's hearts began to fluctuate again.
"It will be around September 2022 that I really see people around me worried." Nikita mentioned the time when the Russian army suffered a setback on the Kharkov front and began partial mobilization in Russia, "because even during the Chechen War, there was no Mobilization on this scale.”
However, this emotion did not last long. After all, this is a village that is no stranger to war memories. From the Great Patriotic War to Afghanistan to Chechnya, several generations of the village have participated. What's more, the Russian government has accelerated the war economy, causing many ordinary people to become involved and become stakeholders.
First, the number of people joining the military has increased. At least three of Nikita's students have family members who have signed up to join the army. The brother of another student has been a contract soldier of the Russian army and has rich combat experience. In 2023, he was responsible for destroying a Western-style infantry fighting vehicle when blocking the Ukrainian army's counterattack. Get extra rewards for your car.
"This makes Alexei (the student's name) very proud. He has even become a little different. He has become particularly interested in military equipment and wants to sign up for military summer camp this year." Nikita said

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·布局｜冲突笼罩下的选战
translation:
In the past three months, Putin has not publicly launched a campaign, but Russian state-owned television has often seen him inspecting various parts of the country - whether it was the nuclear submarine construction plant in the northern city of Severodvinsk or his first visit to Russia A modern tomato farm in the easternmost Chukotka Autonomous Region (across the sea from the mainland of the United States), or communicating with many Russian soldiers who participated in the special military operation against Ukraine in Novo-Ogaryovo, Moscow Region, and receiving rifles and presidential awards flag insignia, visited the famous armaments manufacturer Ural Rolling Stock Plant in Nizhny Tagil, and visited the Krasnodar Higher Military Aviation School to lay flowers for female pilots before Women's Day recently...
Tatyana Stanovaya, a researcher at the Carnegie Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies in Berlin, observed that Putin’s actions before the election were aimed at avoiding any social dissatisfaction. She wrote that any election would highlight changes in the relationship between the ruling authorities and society. And now, in wartime, the stakes are so high that the Kremlin must carefully consider any signs of public discontent.
"To maintain the continuity of military conflict (operations), the Russian leadership needs a popular mandate (mandate), which is why this election is crucial to achieve this goal." Geer, professor of Russian and Eurasian studies at the University of Helsinki, Finland Vladimir Gel'man recently told The Paper.
On March 11, the Russian Satellite News Agency quoted the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center as predicting that the turnout rate for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be around 71%, and presidential candidate Vladimir Putin may receive 82% of the votes. The forecast is based on data from an all-Russian telephone survey. After being elected president for the first time in 2000, he has served four terms as president (the 3rd and 4th terms from 2000 to 2008, the 6th and 7th terms from 2012 to 2024). In the last Russian presidential election in 2018, Putin received 76.69% of the vote. In 2012 and 2004, he received 63.6% and 71.9% of the vote respectively.

translation:
Life here is more or less peaceful, but sometimes people get angry for no reason and with no regard for the consequences. I don’t mean everyone, just some I’ve seen in real life and on online videos. People get bored and bored, and instead of trying to solve their problems, they become angry and even hurt others.
I am against war. That's all I can answer. People are dying because of the war, it's terrible. But most people have different views. There are also people who support the war, such as some people on the Internet, but they should never go to the front line. It is very hypocritical.
Regarding the election, I am very sure that Putin will be elected. No guesswork required. He has held this position for more than twenty years. Life here is relatively good. I do not care. I'm not interested in politics or the country itself. I'm just living my life, that's all.
But if possible, I hope to live in the United States. The United States has always attracted me. English is the only foreign language I know best, so first I'll try to get there. At least I want to try.

title: 普京无悬念胜选 演说提与习近平友谊 | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 18.03.2024
translation:
Since Russia launched war against Ukraine in 2022, China has not publicly condemned Russia and has continued to maintain trade relations with Russia. This has been questioned by Europe and the United States, which has allowed Russia to maintain its wartime economy. In February this year, the European Union also added a number of Chinese companies suspected of providing weapons to Russia to its sanctions blacklist.
Regarding Putin's "win", Ukrainian President Zelensky criticized him for being "addicted to power and doing everything he can to keep himself in power forever." Zelensky said: "In order to maintain his personal power, he does all kinds of evil, and no one in the world is immune to this."
The White House criticized Russia's election as "neither free nor fair" and said opposition politicians who could pose a threat were either not allowed to run, were imprisoned or fled abroad.
The German Foreign Ministry also stated that the Russian election results "will not surprise anyone." "Putin's autocratic rule is based on censorship, repression and violence. The so-called 'elections' conducted by Russia in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and once again violate international law." According to the "Daily Mirror", Germany A presidential spokesman said the German president would not send a letter to congratulate Putin.
Independent election observers have said there was systemic fraud in Russia's elections. There are reports that employees of state-owned enterprises were forced to vote, and hundreds of companies have posted photos of collective voting on social media. According to reports, Ukrainian people were also forced to participate in voting activities in the occupied territories of Ukraine.
There are approximately 114 million voters in this Russian election, including 4.5 million Ukrainians in the Russian-occupied territories. In the Crimean peninsula, which was annexed by Russia in 2014, the authorities also organized voting activities. The Russian opposition called on the international community to refuse to recognize the election results.
On the last day of the three-day voting period, supporters of the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny launched the "Noon" anti-Putin operation, calling on people to go to the polling stations at 12 noon on the 17th. Rally to paralyze polling stations with "long queues", or express protest by writing Navalny's name on the ballot and voting for other candidates.

title: 俄罗斯大选 普京获得连任 白宫回应 | 大纪元
translation:
For the first time, 29 Russian regions are using this voting system in presidential elections.
Thousands of opponents of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in an Arctic prison last month, showed up at polling stations in Russia and abroad to protest against Putin at noon on Sunday.
Putin commented on Navalny's death for the first time after winning the election, calling Navalny's death a "sad event" and confirming that he was ready for a prisoner swap with opposition politicians.
"Given that Mr. Putin imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running against him, it is clear that this election was neither free nor fair," a White House National Security Council spokesman said.
The German Foreign Ministry issued a statement on social media platform Violence. The 'elections' in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and another violation of international law."
British Foreign Minister David Cameron said on the ”
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Putin wanted to stay in power forever and that the vote was illegal.
In this election, more than 114 million Russians are eligible to vote, including voters in what Russia claims as "new territories." In October 2022, Russia announced the annexation of four Ukrainian regions. Ukraine says the Russian elections held there are illegal and invalid.
Poland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement saying that Russia held so-called presidential elections and "the voting took place under conditions of extreme repression in society, making it impossible to make a free and democratic choice." 
This election was held against the background of the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine. Analysts pointed out that the Kremlin hopes to see high turnout in this election and hopes for a major victory for Putin to legitimize the war.
Andreas Tursa, consultant for Central and Eastern Europe at consulting firm Teneo, commented on Thursday (March 14): “The Kremlin seeks an election result that will show public opinion of Putin and his domestic and overwhelming support for the foreign policy agenda.”
Putin easily won a fifth term, which means that his rule in Russia will last until at least 2030. This would make him surpass Josef Stalin to become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
translation:
In this general election, online voting is available in 29 regions, including Moscow, accounting for one-third of the country's electoral districts. According to statistics, the turnout rate for online voting reached 94%.
 
Some analysts believe that voting in Russia's presidential election lasted for three days because Putin hoped to increase turnout to demonstrate Russia's comprehensive support for him.
 
Election under fire
 
This election was the first wartime election held in Russia. Two years ago, on February 24, Putin launched a "special military operation" against Ukraine. Now the conflict is entering its third year.
 
The shadow of war has not dissipated during the three-day Russian presidential election. According to a Reuters report on March 18, in the past few days, Ukraine has repeatedly attacked Russian oil refineries, shelled some areas of Russia, and tried to break through the Russian border.
 
According to "Russia Today", there were some attempts to interfere with voting during the Russian election. Pamfilova, chairwoman of the Russian Central Election Commission, said that there were about 30 incidents of attempts to interfere with voting in 20 regions of Russia. Some people tried to burn ballot boxes and some tried to pour dyeing liquid into the ballot boxes. In St. Petersburg, Molotov cocktails were thrown at polling stations, but there were no casualties.
 
In the Russian-controlled Kherson and Zaporozhye regions, Russia's Central Election Commission also reported several Ukrainian attacks on polling stations, including drone strikes and shelling, which injured some people.
 
Regarding Ukraine's attacks during the Russian election, Putin responded at the press conference after winning the election. According to the TASS news agency, Putin said at a press conference that Ukraine has assembled about 5,000 soldiers in the border area to carry out cross-border attacks. In this regard, Russia may be forced to establish "some kind of buffer zone", which will be quite difficult to cross.

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出，普京迎接“硬核”挑战_新闻频道_中国青年网
translation:
On March 18, local time, the Russian Central Election Commission released data. Among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the presidential election.
Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the same day, thanking voters for their trust and support, and stated that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.
At present, Russia is facing an extremely complex situation. The outside world is paying attention to how Putin will lead Russia to meet the "hard core" challenge.
Take orders in times of danger
In 2023, the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center conducted a survey among Russians over the age of 18. The most common comments given by respondents to Putin's image and political achievements were: calm, energetic, decisive and wise. Nearly three-quarters of the respondents believe that Putin has the ability to ensure Russia's stability and development.
These characteristics were gradually revealed when Putin entered the political arena.
The "shock therapy" and economic crisis in the 1990s caused the Russian economy to hit rock bottom and social problems became prominent. Putin wrote in the article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia's gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by almost 50%...Russia is in one of the most difficult historical periods in hundreds of years. This is probably Russia's last two years. For the first time in three hundred years, it was truly in danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world.” He realized that stabilizing and developing the economy was the “top priority” at that time.
After taking over the Kremlin in 2000, Putin adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms on the one hand; on the other hand, he began to reveal his "strongman" style, vigorously combating oligarchy and restoring the country's control over the economic lifeline.

File photo: The Kremlin in central Moscow. Photo by Tian Bing issued by China News Service
During this period, which coincided with the rise in international oil prices and a relatively stable political and economic environment, Russia seized the opportunity and developed rapidly. In the first eight years of the 21st century, Russia's GDP grew by about 70% and its industry grew by 75%; in 2005, Russia ranked among the top ten economies in the world.
With the improvement of economic strength, Russia's international influence has gradually increased. The 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics and the 2018 World Cup were held in Russia.
Over the years, Russia's poverty problem has improved. From 2000 to 2023, the number of poor people decreased from at least 42 million to 13.5 million. Putin also proposed that Russia’s poverty level should be further reduced to below 7% by 2030.
"Putin's political achievements have brought tangible benefits to the Russian people and have won their love and support." Chen Yurong, a researcher at the China Institute of International Studies, told China News Service.
Many tests
After the Ukrainian crisis escalated in 2022, Russia was subject to more than 10,000 Western sanctions, and a large number of Western companies withdrew from the Russian market. Subsequently, Putin signed an order to switch to using rubles to settle natural gas bills with "unfriendly countries". The Russian economy showed "stability and resilience" and withstood the impact. GDP reversed the decline in 2023 and achieved 3.6% growth.
Chen Yurong pointed out that Russia is currently facing a complex international environment and its economy is facing the problem of sustained and stable development. This means that during his new term of office, Putin will also face various difficulties brought about by Western all-round economic sanctions, such as the adjustment of economic structure inside and outside Russia.
In his 2024 State of the Union address, Putin proposed many specific goals, such as increasing the share of the country's high-tech products and services in the domestic market, increasing non-resource and non-energy exports, reducing the proportion of imports, and achieving more technological independence.
​

translation:
In general, my personal life has not changed much, of course, the war affected the life of every Russian, many countries imposed a lot of sanctions on Russia, different brands and products left Russia, so a lot of things in our country Unavailability or the price has increased several times, which has a great impact on our daily life and quality of life.
But after those brands and companies that left, new brands and companies appeared. Russia's domestic economy also began to develop rapidly, small businesses flourished, and many excellent domestic brands appeared! I sincerely hope that they can also reach a new level and go international as soon as possible!
My attitude towards war is very negative, because I am a very peace-loving person! Honestly, it's hard to answer this question definitively because I don't know all the context. There is a lot of information out there and it's hard for me to filter it all, some are false and some are true. Of course, as a human being, I wish for a world without war, conflict and suffering so that the next generation would not be afraid of anything and look forward to a bright future.
As for Putin, of course I think he is very good because he is the president of our country. He will win the election. As my mother said, it was with his rise to power that Russia became what it is now. At the beginning of the 21st century, thanks to his efforts, Russia's political and economic development began to develop rapidly, since in the 1990s a wave of economic crises occurred in many countries. I feel that he has held a strong position among world political leaders for many years and that we Russians can rely on him. He created the image of our country and Russia externally, which is related to his personality.

title: 俄罗斯总统普京实现其第五次总统选举的胜选
translation:
[Putin’s camp declared victory in the presidential election. Putin received 87.17% of the votes so far, with a vote count of 70.03%. In response to President Putin's fifth victory, the United States, Ukraine and other countries criticized the election as being undemocratic. 】On March 18, a combination of TASS, AP Current Affairs, Reuters, AFP, Daily Telegraph and other foreign media reported that later on the 17th of this month, Moscow local time, according to preliminary statistics from the Russian Central Election Management Committee: As of that night, the turnout rate for the presidential election was 70.03%, of which Putin received 87.17% of the votes among the four candidates. There is no suspense about his victory. Putin will continue to rule the Russian government for the next six years. The 71-year-old Putin declared victory after confirming his fifth re-election. He said at the campaign headquarters: "First of all, I want to thank the Russian people. We are one. Although there are many issues at hand, our unity is beyond doubt. The election results are The trust of the people is also the people’s hope that everything will go according to plan.”
In addition to voting in the eight federal districts across Russia, this election will also take place in the Crimean Peninsula, which the Putin regime has actually controlled since March 2014, and Donne in eastern and southern Ukraine, which unilaterally announced the merger in September 2022. Voting also took place in four oblasts: Tsk, Lugansk, Zaporizhia and Kherson. The above-mentioned four states have also held "state parliamentary elections" in Russia's unified local elections in September 2023. However, the United States and other Western countries and Ukraine, which is at war with Russia, have strongly criticized the presidential election. The White House commented on the 17th local time in Washington, DC, saying: "Considering that Putin puts political opponents in jail and prevents them from running for election, The election is obviously neither free nor fair. "Ukrainian President Zelensky criticized: "This kind of election behavior has happened repeatedly in Russian history. It has no legitimacy and cannot exist. This man is bound by power for eternity. Rule Russia at all costs." Other Western countries have criticized Russia's election results.
The attitude of voters who support Putin's re-election is also unusually firm. On March 16, at the Sergeyev Posad polling station, 60 kilometers northeast of Moscow, local residents were voting for suitable candidates. Sergeyev Posad is strongly influenced by Orthodox Christianity and has an important Orthodox monastery. Local voters told AFP: They believe voting for Putin can end the current armed conflict. Eduardo, 54, voted for Putin. "I want to vote for someone who does his best to eliminate strife in the world, so I'm here. Putin is a person who can save the world." Eduardo showed full trust in Putin. Alexandra, a 77-year-old Orthodox nun, said regarding Russia's military attack on Ukraine: "It is not contradictory, and it will ultimately save more lives." Voters in St. Petersburg, Putin's birthplace, also expressed the same opinion as above. Konstantin, a 46-year-old civil servant, said, "I hope it will be nice to wake up in the morning to a world without fighting or death. Even so, to be honest, I don't think anyone can replace Putin, so I vote for him."

My family lives near Moscow, almost in Moscow. Ukrainian drones have been shot down near my house several times. I have thought about leaving the place where I live now. The Russian presidential election is coming and, of course, Putin will be re-elected. Navalny died in prison a few days ago, but we don’t know the real cause of death. I won't vote; but on the other hand, I'm not pro-Western either. Europe and the United States provide Ukraine with a lot of weapons. I have mixed thoughts about war. We had reasons to start this war, but it is still very sad that this happened. But I'm sure we have to win.
I really miss some live concerts right now. Depeche Mode and a lot of the bands I want to see are touring around the world right now. But they will not come to Russia because of the sanctions. I previously bought tickets for the Gorillaz and Killers performances in 2019, but the performances were cancelled. First it was the COVID-19 pandemic, then the war...

title: 俄罗斯总统大选中胜出,普京迎接“硬核”挑战
translation:
Diplomacy breaks down
"When will you invite Russia to join NATO?" Putin asked then NATO Secretary-General Robertson when he visited NATO headquarters in 2001.
Russia and NATO once had a "honeymoon period." However, as NATO continues to expand eastward, relations between the two sides have experienced ups and downs. After the Crimea incident in 2014, NATO stopped all military exchanges with Russia, and relations deteriorated overall.
Today, NATO has achieved a new round of expansion, absorbing Russia's neighbors Finland and Sweden. Coupled with the fact that the United States and the West continue to "fire up" the Ukraine crisis, the geopolitical game has intensified, and the relationship between Russia and the United States and the West has fallen again and again, slipping into an icy valley.
Chen Yurong pointed out that the current relations between Russia, the United States, and Russia and Europe are in the worst situation since the Cold War. After Putin's re-election, it will be difficult to change the tense confrontation between Russia and the West in the short term. "The future changes in Russia-Western relations will largely depend on how the Ukraine crisis is resolved."

However, in the face of Western containment, Russia has worked hard to break through the situation and actively expanded its relations with countries in the Global South.
In December 2023, Putin withstood the pressure of the United States and some European countries to isolate Russia and visited the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia to discuss oil cooperation and the Palestinian-Israeli conflict; this year, Russia continued to cooperate closely with the CIS countries and carried out cooperation with India. Intensive political dialogue, convening a Russia-Africa summit to interact with many African countries.
In the new version of the "Foreign Policy Concept" approved by Putin in 2023, Russia also plans to give priority to developing relations with Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria, and strengthen cooperation with ASEAN countries in economic, security and other fields.
"A multipolar international relations system is taking shape, which is an irreversible process." Putin has said many times, "We will work hard to unite most countries in the world to respond to global challenges."

title: 新京报 - 好新闻，无止境
translation:
"Russia Today" pointed out that Putin's main policy goals include solving poverty and supporting families with children while strengthening Russia's economic independence.
 
According to the current vote count, Putin has successfully locked in a fifth presidential term. Previously, he won four presidential elections in 2000, 2004, 2012, and 2018. Reuters pointed out that as his fifth term is approaching, Putin will surpass former Soviet leader Stalin and become the longest-serving leader in Russian history.
 
In 2008, Russia extended the presidential term to six years, and the president cannot serve more than two consecutive terms. In 2021, the Russian Federation Council passed a law on the presidential term. Under this law, Putin can serve two more terms after his current term ends. This also means that after the end of this six-year term, Putin can run for re-election for one term.
 
record turnout
 
Before the Russian election, the outside world believed that there was basically no suspense about Putin's overwhelming victory. The only thing that might highlight Russia's domestic attitude towards Putin was the turnout.
 
Previously, the sudden death of Alexei Navalny, a well-known Russian opposition figure in prison, attracted the attention of the international community. Navalny’s wife, Yulia Navalnaya, accused Putin of being responsible and called on Navalny’s supporters to protest against the election, either by not participating in the vote, by supporting other candidates, or by being on the ballot. translation:
Since February 25, in four Russian-occupied regions of Ukraine, women armed with name tags and piles of documents have been knocking on doors or trying to approach residents outside apartment buildings or houses.
The documents were voter lists, and the women (and rarely men) were elected officials, who often taught in nearby schools, collected utility bills, or worked as government clerks.
Former and current residents of the occupied areas told Al Jazeera reporters that they asked residents to show their identification documents and urged them to fill out an early voting form containing the names of the four candidates in Russia's presidential election.
One of the candidates is Vladimir Putin, who is almost certain to win the fifth election, and the remaining three presidential candidates are all figureheads of pro-Kremlin parties. Observers generally believe their involvement is designed to create the illusion of choice.
Al Jazeera has learned that Ukrainians rarely give very convincing reasons for refusing to fill out their ballots - a masked, gun-toting Russian soldier stood next to election officials, while more armed men sat in a car nearby. personnel.
The "poll" usually takes place near the apartment entrance, where election officials and armed soldiers can see whose names are checked on the ballot.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
How did the campaign go?
The permitted campaign period began on February 17 (28 days before the start of voting according to law) and ended at midnight local time on the first day of voting, March 15. The “Day of Silence,” when campaigning had to stop 24 hours before voting day, was abolished for multi-day elections in May 2021. In the case of one-day elections, the rule of silence remains.

Campaigning could be carried out on television channels (in the form of public debates, discussions, round tables, and so on), in print and online publications, distributing campaign materials, and also holding public events. Candidates and the parties that nominated them were provided with free airtime on television channels, as well as free print space in periodicals. In this campaign, candidates were given seven hours of television time, including 3 hours and 30 minutes for debates. Putin refused free airtime to participate in the debate.

In addition, candidates could purchase paid advertising on television. As RBC wrote, paid television advertising turned out to be of little demand in this election race. Kharitonov focused on free-to-air debates and meetings with voters, as well as outdoor advertising on billboards; Slutsky used free airtime on television and radio and conducted a “banner campaign”; Davankov bought advertising on TV and outdoor media, and in addition, enjoyed free airtime. Putin's election videos were shown on federal channels, and billboards in support of the candidate were placed in the regions.

According to the law, printed materials that candidates used for campaigning, such as leaflets or posters, including those placed on advertising structures, do not need to be removed when voting begins.

Nomination of candidates for Russian elections.

Putin held a press conference in the early morning of the same day, thanking voters for their trust and support, and stated that he would continue to promote national development in the new term.
At present, Russia is facing an extremely complex situation. The outside world is paying attention to how Putin will lead Russia to meet the "hard core" challenges.

Take orders in times of danger
In 2023, the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center conducted a survey among Russians over the age of 18. Respondents gave the most comments on Putin's image and achievements as: calm, energetic, decisive and wise. Nearly three-quarters of the respondents believe that Putin has the ability to ensure Russia's stability and development.
These characteristics were gradually revealed when Putin entered the political arena.
The "shock therapy" and economic crisis in the 1990s caused the Russian economy to hit rock bottom and social problems became prominent. Putin wrote in the article "Russia at the Turn of the Millennium" that "Russia's gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by almost 50%...Russia is in one of the most difficult historical periods in hundreds of years. This is probably Russia's last two years. For the first time in three hundred years, it was really facing the danger of becoming a second- or third-rate country in the world." He realized that stabilizing and developing the economy was the "top priority" at that time.
After taking office in the Kremlin in 2000, Putin adjusted economic policies and carried out tax reforms on the one hand; on the other hand, he began to reveal his "strongman" style, vigorously combating oligarchy and restoring the country's control over the economic lifeline.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
"Sasha and the others are the heroes of Donetsk. God knows how much more shelling we would have had to endure if they had not driven the Ukrainians away from Malinka and Avdeevka," Karina said.
Of course, not all locals are like Karina who regard this election, which is not much suspense, as a must-attend event. Karina admitted that some neighbors did not go to the polling stations, and they were often visited by election workers. These people brought ballot boxes and visited residents to advise residents who did not go to the polling stations to exercise their right to vote.
The election is just one step in Russia’s deep embeddedness in local politics and public life. Before the presidential election, the Russian government has been encouraging residents of newly occupied areas to replace their Russian passports and identity documents, and the payment of some social benefits has also been linked to this. Nowadays, not only passports, but also all personal documents need to be replaced, including driver's licenses, real estate certificates, notarized documents, etc. Teachers at local primary and secondary schools have already started using Russian textbooks.
The new “territory” also became more deeply connected with the Russian hinterland. A local female student studying at university in Luhansk told The Paper that since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, her university has often suspended normal teaching and switched to online classes. However, starting from the second half of 2023, due to the decrease in the frequency of shelling, the school began offline teaching again. Not only that, the school also frequently organizes students to study in cities such as Moscow and St. Petersburg, visit museums, historical sites, etc., and receive Russian patriotism education.
"Before the conflict broke out, I had a few friends in school who identified with Ukraine. Some of them went to Kiev, and some became refugees in Europe. They left their hometowns, forgot their identities, and severed ties with their hometowns. I didn't want to think about it. Those days,” she recalled, admitting that she would vote for Putin in the election.
"Putin was president when I was born. The only reason to vote was so that I could identify myself. Like those young people who proudly shouted out that they were Ukrainian in the squares of Kiev a decade ago, I just want to have the same The right to choose a culture that I identify with and not be judged by others.”

translation:
Putin said at the forum that day that the global economic system is undergoing "fundamental and irreversible" changes, and Russia hopes to establish a world economic development model with truly fair competition for all participants. Published by Xinhua News Agency (Photo by Alexander)
 In the 1990s, when Russia became an independent country, the political situation was ups and downs and continued to be unstable. "Shock therapy" led to a severe economic recession, soaring prices, and poor people's livelihood. Putin once worriedly believed that Russia was in danger of becoming a second- or even third-rate country in the world.
 Since taking over the Kremlin in 2000, Putin has vigorously cracked down on the oligarchy and restored the country's control over the economic lifeline. At the same time, he actively adjusted economic policies, promoted structural reforms, and combated the shadow economy. At the beginning of the 21st century, Russia took advantage of the rising international oil prices to step out of its predicament and achieve rapid economic development. As its economic strength increases, Russia's international influence gradually increases.
 When the Ukraine crisis broke out in 2014, facing the threat of Western sanctions, Russia began to make long-term plans, implement an import substitution strategy, strive to get rid of its dependence on energy exports, strengthen financial security construction, and continue to promote economic de-dollarization. Russia withstood the comprehensive sanctions initiated by the West in early 2022 and began to achieve economic growth in the second half of 2022.
 Russian political scientist Oleg Matvechev said that it is under Putin's leadership that Russia has resolved one crisis after another.
 Moscow citizen Irina said she was proud of the country and President Putin. It was Putin who made Russia a country that would not be bullied at will. The West always attempts to use various means such as economic sanctions to isolate Russia, but their plots have not succeeded.
 Fighting Western Suppression
 Shortly before the start of voting in this Russian presidential election, Sweden became the 32nd member of NATO, completing a new round of expansion of NATO. At the same time, the United States and the West continue to "add fuel to the fire" to the Ukraine crisis, and the geopolitical game between Russia and the West is intensifying.

 On March 11, Swedish Prime Minister Kristersson (left) and NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg attended a joint press conference at the NATO headquarters in Brussels, Belgium. NATO held a ceremony for Sweden to join NATO at its headquarters on the same day. Sweden becomes the 32nd member of NATO. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Zhao Dingzhe
 Putin has stated on many occasions on different occasions that he will never sit idly by and ignore NATO's provocations, and emphasized his determination to safeguard the country's territorial sovereignty. His warning was straightforward, highlighting Russia's uncompromising bottom line on national security issues.
 When Putin delivered his State of the Union address this year, he said that the West had failed in its attempts to plunge Russia into strife and civil strife. Russia does not allow anyone to interfere in Russia's internal affairs, and any armed intervention will suffer an unprecedented defeat.
 Russian political scientist Sergei Markov said that people support Putin because Putin is a symbol of sovereignty and independence in the face of Western pressure on Russia. People realize that Putin has the ability to lead Russia to fight back against U.S. hegemony and safeguard national interests.
 Russian voter Vycheslav said that Russians regard Putin as a leader who fights against U.S. hegemony and are willing to work with Putin to oppose NATO's eastward expansion and defend national security.

title: 西方冷对俄大选结果 普京再提“第三次世界大战” | 德国之声 来自德国 介绍德国 | DW | 18.03.2024
translation:
(Deutsche Welle Chinese website) According to China Central Television, on March 18, Chinese President Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of the Russian Federation. Xi Jinping said that Putin's re-election fully demonstrated the Russian people's support for him. He stressed that China attaches great importance to the development of China-Russia relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era.
According to the KCNA report on the 18th, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un also sent a congratulatory message to Putin. Also congratulating the Russian President on his re-election were Venezuelan President Maduro, as well as the national leaders of Nicaragua and Tajikistan.
According to exit polls, Putin received nearly 88% of the vote. After the results came out, Putin held a press conference in Moscow to thank the Russian people for their support and once again threatened NATO with a "world war."
When asked by reporters about the risks and possibilities of conflict between Russia and NATO, Putin responded that "everything is possible in the modern world." He said: "Everyone knows that (if there is a conflict between NATO and Russia), it is only one step away from World War III. I don't think anyone wants to see this situation."
Putin also said that Moscow knew that NATO troops were deployed in Ukraine. But he did not provide clear evidence, only saying that the Russian army heard people speaking English and French on the battlefield.
Western countries have accused Russia of lacking free and fair presidential elections. A spokesman for the White House National Security Council said on Sunday that Russian President Vladimir Putin "has imprisoned his political opponents and prevented others from running against him" and that the presidential election was "clearly neither free nor fair."
The German Foreign Ministry’s "The so-called 'elections' conducted by Russia in the occupied territories of Ukraine are invalid and once again violate international law."
A spokesman for the German president confirmed to Berlin's Tagesspiegel that Federal President Steinmeier would not send a letter to congratulate Putin on his election. When Putin was last re-elected in 2018, Steinmeier congratulated him.
The French Foreign Ministry pointed out that Putin's re-election took place against the background of repression of civil society and praised "the courage of the many Russian people who peacefully protested against the violation of their basic political rights."
British Foreign Secretary Cameron also criticized Russia's election on Sunday as lacking "free and fair". Cameron posted on the X platform that the "illegal" election held on Ukrainian soil showed that Russia is not interested in finding a path to peace.
"Russia's presidential election was illegitimate, not free and unfair," Poland's Foreign Ministry said in a statement on Sunday, saying the vote was taking place "in the context of severe repression" in occupied Ukraine. The move violated international law.
Ukrainian President Zelensky said that Putin "has once again simulated an election" and believed that Putin would do whatever it takes "in order to maintain his personal power." Zelensky said the "Russian dictator" must be sent to the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
(comprehensive report)
© 2024 Deutsche Welle Copyright Statement: All contents of this article are protected by copyright law and may not be used without special authorization from Deutsche Welle. Any misconduct will result in recovery of damages and criminal prosecution.
​

title: ЦИК объявил о победе Путина с 87% голосов
translation:
MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters) - Current Russian President Vladimir Putin wins the presidential election with 87.17% of the votes based on the results of processing 80.93% of the protocols, data from the Central Election Commission shows.

The turnout in the elections was 74.22% percent.

In second place is the candidate from the Communist Party of the Russian Federation Nikolai Kharitonov with 4.22% of the votes, in third is Vladislav Davankov from “New People” with 4.03%, in fourth is Leonid Slutsky from the Liberal Democratic Party with 3.16%.

Polls predicted an unconditional victory for Putin in his fifth election.

In power for almost a quarter of a century, Putin promises in the next six years to reduce poverty, increase life expectancy, increase non-resource exports, increase labor productivity and ensure growth in investment.

In March, he estimated his initiatives for the next six years at 14 trillion rubles.

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
translation:
Putin's supporters also call him the "collector of Russian lands" for launching war against the former Soviet republic of Georgia in 2008, recognizing two smaller states that broke away from Georgia, and annexing Crimea in 2014 , and also annexed parts of four other Ukrainian regions in 2022.
On February 16 this year, Putin's most outspoken political opponent Alexei Navalny died in a prison in the Arctic region. His family, supporters and many people in the international community called this a "political murder" .
Navalny was denied registration in the 2018 presidential election, which Putin won with nearly 78% of the vote.
Two other opposition figures, Ilya Yashin and Vladimir Kaza-Murza, were sentenced to eight and a half years and 25 years in prison respectively for criticizing Putin's war in Ukraine.
Thousands more - opposition figures, critics and ordinary Russians who posted anti-war comments online or simply liked or shared them - face criminal charges.
Tens of thousands have been arrested, fined or forced to leave the country.
In addition, after the outbreak of the war - especially after Russia announced its "mobilization" in September 2022, at least 1 million Russian men fled the country.
Demyan, a 32-year-old web designer who fled to Georgia and then to southern Portugal in late 2022, told Al Jazeera, “I have nothing to do with this farce. They want me dead, they want my son to be orphan."
The authorities have done little to prevent their exodus. But they passed a law allowing their property to be confiscated for "criticism of special military operations." “Special military operations” is the Kremlin’s preferred euphemism for its war in Ukraine.

title: 新华社快讯：初步统计数据显示普京在俄总统选举中得票领先 - 新华网客户端
translation: At about 21:00 on the 17th, Moscow time, Russia’s Central Election Commission released preliminary statistics showing that Putin was leading the vote in the Russian presidential election.

title: 习近平祝贺普京“连任”   中俄联手引发国际安全担忧 — 普通话主页
translation:
Putin also continued to "surrender" to China at the press conference after the presidential election. He said that provocations by China's enemies around Taiwan are destined to fail.
Lin Jian responded: "China highly appreciates President Putin's statement. There is only one China in the world, the government of the People's Republic of China is the only legal government representing all of China, and Taiwan is an inalienable part of China's territory. This is a general consensus of the international community. and basic norms of international relations.”
Scholar: China and Russia continue to strengthen alliance to fight against the West
Weng Lvzhong, associate professor at the Department of Political Science at Sam Houston State University in the United States, analyzed that in Putin’s next six-year term, Russia will undoubtedly further strengthen its alliance with China.
"Not only will it strengthen relations with China, but also with India." He said: "I believe that Putin increasingly feels that even if the Russia-Ukraine war ends and Russia has a slight upper hand, Western countries led by the United States will probably not It will change his attitude towards Russia. Therefore, Putin feels that the key to keeping a distance from Western countries is whether he can win over China and India.”
However, Weng Luzhong believes that Russia is trapped in the quagmire of the Russia-Ukraine war and is not capable of assisting China's aggressive actions in the Taiwan Strait. Moreover, the Sino-Russian alliance is still based on their respective interests and is not "confidest friends".
He said: "Although Putin expressed his stance on the situation in the Taiwan Strait and even emphasized that Taiwan is part of China, the most important thing is to express diplomatic support for China and then to improve relations with China. The signal that China now hopes to convey to the United States through Russia is : If the US attitude towards China does not change, China will choose to get closer to Russia.”
This station has reported that Putin hinted that the West would target China in an exclusive interview with former American Fox News host Tucker Carlson last month. Putin bluntly stated that Russia lags far behind China in terms of population and economic size: "The West's fear of a powerful China far exceeds its fear of a powerful Russia."
Wang Weizheng analyzed that although China and Russia stated that their partnership was “unlimited,” in reality, they had “each other’s own agenda.” At present, the common interest of the two countries is still how to confront the West.
He said: "As for Russia, although it is the successor of the Soviet Union, it is actually very uneasy about the rise of China. After all, the Soviet Union and the United States were equal in the past. Now after the rise of China, will China be equal to the United States? In such a situation, Has Russia become a vassal state of China?”
Wang Weizheng further pointed out that the national security strategy issued by the U.S. government has determined that China is “the only competitor that has both the intention and the ability to reshape the international order.” Judging from the current international situation, Russia may have intentions but does not have the capabilities. Therefore, Russia must cooperate with China to jointly confront the West and the current international order.
According to statistics from the General Administration of Customs of China, the bilateral trade volume between China and Russia reached a record high of US$190.27 billion in 2022, a year-on-year increase of 29.3%. When the Russo-Ukrainian war broke out and Russia faced sanctions from Western societies, China became Russia's most important trading partner.
input:
Western attempts to create provocations.
Targeting by cyberattacks and military actions involving Russia and other entities.
Year-on-year increase in economic indicators for China-Russia trade and Russian economy.
The outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

title: 普京胜选！最新讲话回应这些问题
translation:
According to Xinhua News Agency, data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time showed that among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, the current President Putin led other candidates by a large margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the election. presidential election.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.
Public information shows that the 71-year-old Putin’s term as the current president of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after this term ends.

Win the election
According to Xinhua News Agency, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
In his speech, Putin also mentioned the challenges ahead. He first thanked the soldiers on the front lines of the conflict and said that Russia's current priority must be to complete special military operations. He said that the Russian army has taken the lead in the war, and if Western troops appear in Ukraine, it may push the world to the brink of World War III. Putin also emphasized that as long as the country is united, no one can suppress Russia.
In addition, Putin also talked about the relationship between Russia and China, saying that Sino-Russian relations are a stabilizing factor. China is very successful on the global stage. He is convinced that the relationship between the two countries will be stronger in the next few years.
Compared with previous elections, this election has a number of "firsts" records, such as the first use of multi-day continuous voting, and the first use of a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting. Also during this election, polls are open on multiple days.
input:
Putin's re-election as President of Russia.
Putin delivering a speech.
Putin thanking Russian voters in a speech.
Russia's progression and strengthening.
Suppressing Russia.
Putin's discussions on various geopolitical and regional issues.
Conviction that China-Russia relations will strengthen under the guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin.
Comparison of the current election with previous elections.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024｜五个“首次”，这场选举有何特殊？
translation:
For Russian overseas voters, the head of the Russian embassy abroad can change the start, end and duration of voting depending on the situation.
The law also clearly stipulates that only authorized personnel can take photos and videos at polling sites, and media reporters with formal work contracts can be certified at polling stations. In areas of Russia where a state of war has been declared, additional protective measures will be taken to ensure the safety of voters and the smooth conduct of the voting process. The Russian State Duma said the move was aimed at allowing people living in frontline areas and on combat missions to participate in the vote.
At the same time, this will also be the first time that Russia holds presidential election voting in the four "new regions" of Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhia and Kherson. All four regions are currently in a state of war.
Previously, after Putin signed a law in May 2023 allowing elections to be held in areas subject to wartime conditions, local elections were held in the above four places. Subsequently, according to a relevant resolution on the presidential election adopted by the Russian Central Election Commission in December 2023, voting for the Russian presidential election will be held in the Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions. Considering that local people may not have obtained Russian passports for various reasons, the election committees in the above-mentioned regions will have the right to determine what documents local voters can present to successfully participate in the presidential election voting if they are unable to present their Russian passports when voting.
The official voting in the Russian election will be held from March 15 to 17, and this will be the first time that Russia holds a three-day presidential election voting. Multi-day voting was originally used during the coronavirus pandemic to prevent overcrowding of voters at polling stations. According to media reports, the first application of this voting method was during the Russian constitutional referendum from June 25 to July 1, 2020.
This election will also be the first time that Russia uses a combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting in a presidential election. According to Russian official instructions, a total of 29 regions in Russia can apply for remote voting. In these areas, people can choose to go to local polling stations to vote in person, or they can vote via computer or mobile phone after submitting a remote voting application from January 29 to March 11.
In addition, according to the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, due to tensions with unfriendly countries, some Russian embassies and consulates overseas have been closed, and the number of Russian polling stations set up overseas for this election has also been reduced. Pavel Andreev, a member of the Russian Central Election Commission, said on February 21 that 281 polling stations will be set up in 144 overseas countries during the Russian Federation’s presidential election, and 7 polling stations will be set up in Baikonur. The total number of polling stations will reach 288. In the 2018 presidential election, Russia set up 394 polling stations overseas. Russian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Zakharova said that the security situation at Russian embassies and consulates has deteriorated significantly recently, and not all European and American countries have responded to Russia’s note requesting to ensure the security of polling stations on election day. Regarding the reduction of overseas polling stations, Andreev also said that this is not Russia’s fault, but the fault of the country where the polling stations are located.
input:
Russian constitutional referendum in 2020.
