title: 习近平电贺普京“当选连任”，传北京考虑参加瑞士举行的乌克兰和会
translation:
After Russian President Vladimir Putin won an unquestionable victory in a presidential election with no real opponent, Chinese President Xi Jinping called Putin on Monday (March 18) to congratulate him on his re-election. , committed to maintaining close communication with Russia and promoting the continued and in-depth development of Sino-Russian relations.

Meanwhile, China's ambassador to Switzerland Wang Shiting said Beijing was paying close attention to the Ukraine peace conference that Switzerland was about to host and that China was considering the possibility of participating in the conference.

Russia is holding a new presidential election as Putin's war of aggression against Ukraine enters its third year, but two anti-war candidates with real popular support are banned from running by the Kremlin, while the opposition leader Putin fears most Putin's "overwhelming" victory in the election that ended on Sunday came as no surprise after Alexei Navalny died under mysterious circumstances in a prison above the Siberian Arctic Circle last month. .
"Your re-election fully reflects the Russian people's support for you," Xi Jinping said in a congratulatory message to Putin. "I believe that under your leadership, Russia will be able to achieve greater achievements in national development and construction."

After Putin brazenly invaded Ukraine in February 2022, Russia was strongly condemned by the United States and Western allies and met with rounds of severe sanctions. However, instead of accusing Moscow of its aggressive actions, Beijing took the opportunity to strengthen political, diplomatic, and economic and trade relations with Russia, and even aggressively purchased energy products, including oil and natural gas, that Russia was forced to sell at a discount due to Western sanctions.

Before launching the war in Ukraine, Putin made a special visit to Beijing and signed a series of cooperation documents with Xi Jinping known as "unlimited". China and Russia have obvious intentions of holding back-to-back to warm up in the face of resistance from the United States and the West.

"China attaches great importance to the development of Sino-Russian relations and is willing to maintain close communication with Russia to promote the sustained, healthy, stable and in-depth development of the China-Russia comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for a new era to the benefit of the two countries and their peoples," Xi Jinping's congratulatory message said.

According to reports from Chinese state media, Xi Jinping and Putin will have multiple meetings this year.

“China and Russia are each other’s largest neighbors and comprehensive strategic partners of coordination in the new era.
input:
Xi Jinping called Putin to congratulate him on his re-election as President of Russia.
China congratulating Putin on his re-election.
The Russo-Ukrainian war entering its third year.
"Banning".
The death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny in an Arctic prison.
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

title: 俄罗斯部分地区开始提前投票选举总统
translation:
According to the TASS news agency on the 25th, early voting for the Russian presidential election has been launched. Voters in some areas with inaccessible and remote areas can vote for the president starting from the same day.
According to the news, some voters in more than 30 regions including Altai Krai, Arkhangelsk Oblast, Kamchatka Krai and Krasnoyarsk Territory can vote for the president in advance. Voters living in remote areas of the above places can vote in advance starting from February 25, while Russian voters living abroad can also vote in advance starting from March 1, but voting activities for both groups of voters must be on March 14 Ending, the specific voting dates vary by region.
Groups of voters who can participate in early voting include hunters, fishermen, loggers, miners, lighthouse and nature reserve workers, soldiers at border stations in remote areas, voters sailing on ships during the official voting period for the presidential election, and voters living abroad. Voter groups further from polling stations can also vote early.
The official voting for the Russian presidential election will be held from March 15th to 17th. Four candidates, including current President Vladimir Putin, are running.
input:
Russian voters living abroad voting early starting March 1.
Participation of current Russian President Vladimir Putin in a presidential election with three other candidates.

title: 俄罗斯大选：普京宣布获压倒性胜利， 数千民众抗议“操纵选举” - BBC News 中文
translation:
Russian officials announced that according to preliminary vote counting results, current President Vladimir Putin received more than 87% of the vote and is certain to win and will be re-elected until 2030. When announcing his victory at the campaign headquarters, Putin expressed his gratitude to voters and Russian soldiers fighting in Ukraine.
However, the United States and other countries called the election "illegitimate." At noon on the last day of voting (March 17), thousands of Russians flocked to polling stations across the country to participate in the "noon" anti-Putin activities called by the opposition. Dozens of protesters were arrested.
If Putin's 87% of the vote is confirmed, he will become the Russian candidate with the highest vote share since the collapse of the Soviet Union. At the same time, he will also surpass Stalin and become the Russian leader with the longest reign in more than 200 years.
input:
Putin expressing gratitude to voters after election victory.
Arrests of individuals across Russia during protests, monitored by OVD-Info.
Putin surpassing Stalin as Russia's longest-serving leader.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
translation:
Some people say that Russia has become dangerous because of the war, maybe dangerous if you are a man, but I don't think so because nothing is really happening here right now.
But now some international brands have increased their prices a lot. Two years ago, a pair of Nike shoes cost 5,000-8,000 rubles (approximately RMB 393-628 yuan), but now the same Nike shoes cost at least 15,000 rubles (approximately RMB 1,177 yuan). You can’t buy them casually because there is no official Nike store. There are many people who buy Nike and other brands in Turkey or Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and bring them back to Russia to sell them, with prices rising by 50% or more. However, some people have friends in China. They can ask their friends to buy them from the online fashion trading platform "poizon" and then mail them from China. The postage is about 300-500 rubles per kilogram, which is super cheap compared to the shoes brought back from Turkey. I am also planning to buy some shoes from "poizon" this summer.
But we also have many good local Russian brands.
As for the impact of the war on me, personally, it was only psychological. It was very stressful at first. I have a lot of relatives in Ukraine and this really makes me sad.
Speaking of the general election, we now have only one candidate who opposes the war, and that is Nadezdin (Note: Due to problems in submitting campaign materials, failure to collect enough signatures, etc., Nadezdin was ultimately unable to qualify for the election). I don't care about any politics, I don't want to choose a side, I don't even want to think about it. A month ago, I wanted to leave Russia and go to Armenia or Georgia. I wanted peace and I wanted the right not to be afraid of all this. But it's difficult. You need a visa, you need a reason to stay in the other country, you need to learn a language, and you may be deported or discriminated against. But now more and more people are learning English in order to immigrate, and English teaching websites are increasing.
"Whose Crimea is it?"
input:
Price increases.
Purchasing goods.
The impact of Western sanctions on Russia.
Submission of documents to the Russian Central Election Commission.
Candidates qualifying for the 2024 Russian general election.
Russians leaving the country after the Ukraine war started.

title: Российские «выборы»: взгляд изнутри и со стороны
translation:
Expert comments

Meanwhile, the figures announced by the authorities seem to have been received with satisfaction in the Kremlin, despite foreign criticism of the entire process, David Kankia, an expert with the Voice movement, said in a commentary for the Russian service of the Voice of America. According to him, this pleases the pride of the authorities and supposedly proves that all decisions made in recent years are supported by the majority of society.

“In fact, elections are held primarily not because, as stated in the Constitution, it is necessary to identify the will of the people and on the basis of this to form power structures, but because an inverted pyramid has been established in the country,” he clarified. – For the authorities, this is another reason to check how loyal the population and the bureaucratic apparatus are to it, “darling”, and how ready the latter is to fulfill any assigned tasks. In fact, the population and the bureaucracy are tested before the incubator (the current holder of the position - V.V.), and not vice versa.”

If the Kremlin’s goal was to “please” Vladimir Putin, then it has been realized, David Kankia also stated: “If the goal was to convince someone of the legitimacy of the elections, it seems to me that this is very far away. Everything that we saw during the election campaign on voting days, as well as the international reaction to this and the interest, for example, in the materials and analytics of Golos, suggests that an alternative point of view is still in demand in Russia. And those who doubted the integrity of the electoral procedure carried out in the Russian Federation only strengthened their opinion.”

In addition, it became clear that those who do not want to receive alternative information will not receive it, the expert continued: “Now, in fact, there are two Russias, which exist in two different information spaces with different agendas, and they have completely different visions elections. People who were forced to come to polling stations and vote involuntarily, as well as members of the commission who rewrote protocols in violation of the law, understand perfectly well the real cost of such elections. Just like the presidential administration, which had a hand in all this.”

But the current owner of the Kremlin is probably pleased - at least he obviously believes that everything is in his power, everyone can be forced to dance to his tune and even pretend that they believe in the interest rates presented, David Kankia summarized.

As a result of the presidential campaign, the Russian authorities achieved everything they wanted, says political scientist Fyodor Krasheninnikov. In his opinion, they are not at all confused by the methods by which the desired results were obtained.

“Now they will interpret any nuance in their favor,” he added in a comment to Voice of America. – For example, there are no elections in Ukraine, but they took place in Russia. Therefore, the Kremlin will say that Putin is legitimate, but Zelensky is not. In addition, there are doubts about the election results outside, not inside Russia. Inside, any “sedition” is mercilessly suppressed. But the authorities and propaganda will tirelessly repeat that Putin was legitimately elected, and with an overwhelming advantage.”

The excessively high percentage for Putin is explained by the fact that the Kremlin is convinced that during a war, the entire people should unite around the leader, believes Fyodor Krasheninnikov: “Although it is clear that the record result was achieved solely due to unprecedented falsifications. Not only is electronic voting an uncontrollable abyss, but it has also been revealed that tens of millions of people, many of whom most likely do not exist at all, or those who simply did not go to the polls, nevertheless “expressed their will” as they should. The same applies to voting in the occupied Ukrainian territories. Everyone there was en masse enrolling as voters. Thus, it is generally impossible to analyze these elections taking into account the huge number of attributions and other frauds.”

Of course, many people voted for Putin, but, of course, not in such absurd numbers, the political scientist concluded.

Vladimir Putin's inauguration is scheduled for May 7 this year. His estimated reign is six years.
input:
Convincing others of a particular viewpoint or legitimacy.
Putin receiving election results.
Forced voting in elections.

Election Falsifications.
Russian citizens expressing opposition to election restrictions.
Russian illegal occupation of Ukrainian territories.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
The psychological pain and struggle caused by the war are endless, but the lives of ordinary people will continue after all. In Rostov-on-Don, life remains peaceful most of the time. Faced with rising prices, while people are working harder to maintain their lives, they are also looking forward to peace coming as soon as possible and life to return to what it was before. Military mobilization was once people's greatest fear. But as the conflict continues and the situation becomes clearer, this concern is no longer as strong as before.
For Andre personally, the war did not have a very profound impact on his life. He only vaguely remembered that a drone was shot down in the city where he lived last year. If there was anything that briefly broke the tranquility of his life in the past two years, it was probably the "rebellion" launched by Prigozhin in June 2023.
At that time, the Prigozhin and Wagner soldiers who rose up from Rostov-on-Don were supported by many people here. Two months later, Prigozhin and many senior Wagner officials died in a plane crash.
Faced with a situation that he was unable to change, Andre turned his attention away from politics and focused on his own life. He summed up his attitude towards the war with this sentence: "Honestly, I don't want to find out who is right and who is wrong, I just want it to end."
Currently, he is working in a furniture company. In addition to his daily work, he also spends time learning foreign languages ​​to explore more possibilities for himself. From time to time, he earns some extra money through photography, and occasionally shoots videos and uploads them to social platforms. Andre still has his own expectations for the future.
"If there used to be many foreign products in the Russian market, now there are fewer, and many new opportunities have emerged. This will give you the motivation to build your own brand and business. For example, the Russian version of YouTube, the Russian version of Spotify. I I’m making videos now, but it’s just a hobby, and I don’t have many fans. This spring, I’m considering changing my job, and the content should be in the direction of social media marketing.”
Military industrial enterprise engineer: preparing to change jobs
Young Andre was not the only person who saw new opportunities under the flames of war. Since the war has greatly promoted the development of Russian military industrial enterprises, Yuri, who is 56 years old this year, has just received a new job offer.
Yuri is currently the chief engineer of a Russian company on the Russian-Ukrainian border. His work belongs to the initial stage of steel manufacturing, that is, the ore mining and beneficiation process. Before the war, Yuri's company sold half of its steel overseas. However, after the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke out, Western countries began to ban the purchase of steel from Russia. Now, most of these steels are bought by the Russian government and used to make military equipment, artillery shells and other war supplies.
After the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, Russia significantly increased its defense spending and increased its support for military-industrial enterprises.

title: Президентские выборы в России: «Давайте не будем признавать легитимность Путина как президента», – заявил председатель ПАСЕ
translation:
The Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe unanimously calls on the international community to no longer recognize Putin's legitimacy as president. We call for an end to all contacts with Putin, except on the issue of achieving peace and humanitarian goals, for example, organizing a prisoner exchange or returning home the missing children of Ukraine.

Putin's excessive powers, exacerbated today by his extremely long tenure in power, coupled with the lack of any checks and balances such as a strong parliament, an independent judiciary, a free media and a vibrant civil society, have unfortunately turned the Russian Federation into a dictatorship of de- fact.

This is not what the Russian people deserve. Nor does he deserve to be mocked for the elections we witnessed today.

The Parliamentary Assembly will continue to support the development of an alternative vision of Russia as a peaceful, free, democratic and accountable country that does not pose a threat to its neighbors and its own citizens. We will strengthen our support for the Russian democratic opposition, which shares the principles and values of the Council of Europe, human rights defenders, independent journalists and free civil society. We will support all those who dare to fight for freedom in Russia, who condemn the aggressive war against Ukraine and fully recognize its territorial integrity.

Freedom and democracy will triumph in Russia!”

title: 普京胜选连任 得票率远超上届
translation:
Facing the next six-year term, Putin said that he will continue to promote the country's development, all the country's tasks will be completed, and Russia will become stronger, stronger and more efficient.
According to Xinhua News Agency, data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th showed that among the 85% of votes that had been counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led by a large margin with 87.19% of the votes, and he had actually won the election.
This means that the 71-year-old Putin will start his fifth presidential term.
No suspense about re-election
Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, expressing his gratitude to voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family and the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters.
Since 1999, Putin has been in charge of the overall development of the country as president or prime minister, and there is no suspense about his re-election this time. Three polls conducted by the Russian Public Opinion Research Center in the first three months of this year showed that Russian people's trust in Putin has always remained at a high level of nearly 80%, and he also enjoys high prestige among young people.

"We are the Putin generation." 27-year-old Zarbek believes that Putin is the person who can ensure the stability of Russian society. "Based on my observations, memories, and what we have now, the situation has become better." The 25-year-old Korenov also believes that life is getting better. "We support Putin. No one else can lead this country because the country is now developing in an all-round way."
input:
Promotion of national development by Vladimir Putin.
Putin delivering a speech.
Putin expressing gratitude to voters after election victory.
Economic and technological development by various countries.

title: 普京得票率88%，延长他的统治
translation:
Russia announced that President Vladimir Putin won 88% of the vote in the first round of Sunday's presidential election, leaving the dictator with no real alternative in his ruthless suppression of dissent.

The three-day election that began on Friday, extending Putin's 24-year rule by another six years, was held in a tightly controlled environment that prohibited public criticism of Putin and the war in Ukraine.

Putin's fiercest political opponent Alexey Navalny died in an Arctic prison last month, and other critics are in jail or in exile. But voters responded to Navalny's final political demands, lining up at polling stations in major cities around noon to cast a symbolic vote against Putin.

Navalny's aides encouraged people to join the protests he had endorsed before his sudden death.

Reuters reported that the Communist candidate Nikolai Kharitonov received less than 4% of the votes and ranked second; the third place was Vladislav Davankov, fourth It was the uber-populist Leonid Slutsky.

Reuters reported that a spokesman for the White House National Security Council said, "Mr. Putin imprisoned political opponents and prevented others from running. The election was clearly neither free nor fair."

Russians dissatisfied with Putin went to the polls around noon in "midday against Putin" protests, either to vote for the other three candidates or to destroy their ballots.

Others also said they wrote Navalny's name.

Polling stations were also reported to have been vandalized dozens of times.

The OVD-Info group, which tracks political arrests in Russia, said more than 50 people were arrested in 14 cities across Russia on Sunday.

Similar protests took place at Russian embassies around the world. Hundreds of Russians also lined up at noon at polling stations at the Russian diplomatic missions in Australia, Armenia, Kazakhstan and Japan.

Navalny's widow Yulia Navalnaya participated in a protest at the Russian Embassy in Berlin, Germany, and was applauded by those present.

"Alexey is fighting for very simple things, which is freedom of speech, fair elections, democracy and our right not to live in corruption and war," Navalnaya said at a rally in Budapest on March 15. Putin is not Russia. Russia is not Putin.”

Despite his show of opposition to Putin, Putin is almost certain to win re-election. If he is re-elected and completes his six-year term, he will surpass Stalin and become Russia's longest-serving leader in more than 200 years.

The election was held against the backdrop of Russia's war in Ukraine. Putin said before the election that this was Russia's battle for survival against the West.
input:
Putin's extension of his rule over Russia through a rigged election.
Tightly controlled Russian election.
Public criticism of Putin and his war in Ukraine.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
Putin was congratulated on his victory by Chinese President Xi Jinping, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as well as Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi. In addition, the presidents of Nicaragua, Bolivia and Honduras, the prime minister of Myanmar, and the heads of Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan sent congratulations.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz will not congratulate Putin on his victory, the German government said. The head of the Republic's Foreign Ministry, Annalena Berbock, in turn, said that the elections in Russia were not free and fair. Earlier, the G7 countries and the EU representative stated that holding elections in Crimea, DPR, LPR, Zaporozhye and Kherson regions violates the sovereignty of Ukraine and they do not recognize the results. Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova called this statement biased. According to her, the time of the G7 is “irretrievably gone.”
More than 12 million DDoS attacks on election system resources have been recorded since the beginning of the presidential campaign, which is 150 times more than usual, Pamfilova said. On election days, according to her, there were 420 thousand attacks on DEG resources.
On March 21, the Central Election Commission plans to hold a meeting at which it will sum up the official election results.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное

The ballots filled with brilliant green in Moscow were taken into account, deputy chairman of the Moscow City Election Commission Dmitry Reut told RIA Novosti. “I would like to note that the 115 ballots filled with brilliant green at PEC 690 in Otradnoye and 217 ballots at PEC 2084 in Chertanovo Yuzhny are all readable, the marks on the ballots are visible. Everything was calculated and taken into account. Not a single vote was lost,” he said.

title: 普京胜选后欧盟援乌调门依旧坚定，但准备好真金白银了吗？
translation:
As a representative of the entire EU, Borrell has moderated his rhetoric. The foreign ministers of the three former Soviet republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are almost all eager for the EU to send troops to Ukraine. The Foreign Minister of Latvia expressed full praise for French President Macron's recent speech, and it feels like Western Europe has finally woken up.
At a press conference after the election vote on the 17th, Putin responded for the first time to questions about the death of the famous Russian opposition leader Navalny. This shows from the side that Putin is confident in his control of power after winning the election. This also leads to the dilemma facing the EU - facing a Russia that is unlikely to change its attitude in the short term, and a Russia that is determined to survive Ukraine until the oil is exhausted, how can the EU effectively support Kiev in the long term?
Since the all-out war between Russia and Ukraine, the United States has been Ukraine's main arms aid provider. The negative consequences of the EU's long-term over-reliance on the United States under the NATO structure are now clearly revealed. The EU's own defense industry is not sufficient to support it alone in providing Ukraine with the weapons and ammunition that the latter needs. Without US involvement, it would be difficult for the EU to support it on its own.
Trump successfully won the Republican presidential nomination, the current US President Biden is in an "age crisis", and the Republican-dominated House of Representatives has blocked military aid funding for Ukraine several times, all of which are questioning whether the United States can continue to stand firm after the year-end election. Winning this protracted war with Europe has become questionable.
In fact, since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, European countries have been actively expanding their defense industries. Germany immediately announced a substantial increase in its defense budget. Poland's defense expenditure will rise to 4% of GDP in 2023, ranking first in NATO. France, the traditional military leader within the EU, is actively taking the lead in building the EU's own defense industry chain.
But freezing three feet doesn't last a day. Since the end of the Cold War, Europe has been at peace for a long time. With the exception of France, other NATO member states have relied heavily on the United States for weapons and equipment, and their own R&D and production capabilities have been unable to quickly build up.
At the same time, France and Germany also have different views on who should lead the EU defense industry. France believes that as a traditional power, it has an independent defense industry, is a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, and a legal nuclear-armed country, so it should naturally take the lead. On the other hand, Germany believes that it is the main investor. At the same time, Germany is far more active than France in aiding Ukraine, and it should be led by itself.
A good example is Macron’s military theory on Ukraine. As soon as this statement came out, public opinion in France was in an uproar. On the one hand, of course, the French are unwilling to die for Ukraine. On the other hand, French media also pointed out that France’s military aid to Ukraine lags far behind Germany’s. Instead of attracting attention, it is better to honestly send more money first.
As the saying goes, it is better to listen to what someone says than to watch what someone does. Although the EU can remain firm in its policy adjustments, real money, weapons and ammunition are the real challenges that the EU will face this year and even next year.
input:
The death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny.
Expanding cooperation and defense capabilities amidst sanctions and conflict.
Performance increase in various sectors and measures.

title: 俄总统选举中国观察员团观察声明：民主透明公正，未发现违规情况
translation:
On March 18, 2024, Li Hui, head of the Chinese Observer Mission for the Russian Presidential Election and the Chinese government’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs, submitted an observation statement by the Chinese Observer Mission for the Russian Presidential Election to the Chinese and Russian media. The full text of the statement is as follows:
At the invitation of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, from March 15 to 17, 2024, the Observer Group of the People's Republic of China observed the preparation and implementation process of the presidential election in the Russian Federation.
The Chinese observer team upheld the principles of respecting sovereignty and non-interference in internal affairs and effectively performed its observation duties. While in Russia, the observer team met with representatives of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other institutions, and listened to a briefing on the preparations for the election. The observer team visited polling stations in Moscow and observed on-site the preparation of ballots and ballot boxes, voter identity verification, ballot collection, voting and counting. The election committees of the constituencies observed comprehensively and timely announced election regulations and candidate information, effectively ensuring voters' right to know. The election process was covered extensively by the media.
The Chinese observer team believes that the Russian presidential election was democratic, transparent, and fair. The election process was smooth and calm, and no irregularities were found. The election results are the independent choice of the Russian people. China respects the choice of the Russian people, sincerely congratulates President Putin on his re-election as Russian president, and believes in and firmly supports Russia in achieving national stability, development and revitalization.
The Observer Mission expressed its gratitude to the Central Electoral Commission of the Russian Federation, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other institutions and departments for their support and assistance.
input:
Submission of documents to the Russian Central Election Commission.
Observation of the Russian Presidential Election.
China congratulating Putin on his re-election.
Putin's role in ensuring Russia's stability and development.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
translation:
As Nikolai Bulaev, deputy chairman of the Central Election Commission, previously said, the bulk of the voting participants in the special operation did so at regular polling stations. For the rest, temporary polling stations operated on the territory of military units in the special operation zone.

When will the election results be known?
The counting of votes began immediately after the polling stations closed, that is, at 20:00 local time. The CEC is obliged to announce the general election results within ten days after the vote.

As Ella Pamfilova later reported, the Central Election Commission will officially sum up the results of the Russian presidential election on March 21

To win in the first round, a candidate needs to win more than half the votes of voters who took part in the elections. If this does not happen, then a second round of elections will take place in three weeks.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
On these three days, starting Friday, polling stations were open from 8:00 to 20:00 local time. In 29 out of 89 regions, including Moscow, it was possible to vote remotely, through the remote electronic voting system (DEG). It was available until 20:00 on Sunday.

The total number of voters in Russia is 112.309 million people, and almost 1.9 million more outside, the Central Election Commission reported. Since July 2023, according to the department, the number of voters in Russia has increased by 4.394 million people. In January of this year, the Central Election Commission for the first time disclosed data on voters in the Donetsk People's Republic - 1.971 million people, in the Lugansk People's Republic - 1.652 million, in the Zaporozhye and Kherson regions - about 470 thousand people each.

Citizens who could not come to the polling stations from March 15 to 17 could vote early from February 25. In the Kherson region, 58.14% took advantage of this opportunity, Marina Zakharova, chairman of the regional election commission, told reporters. In the DPR, already on the third day of early voting, the turnout was 36.91%, the chairman of the DPR election commission, Vladimir Vysotsky, said on March 12.

According to reports, five people familiar with the matter revealed that Putin will go to China in May to hold talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping. This may be Putin’s first overseas trip in his new term.
Putin won Russia’s 2024 presidential election on the 18th and won a new six-year term. title: 俄罗斯大选2024·选民｜年轻的俄罗斯人怎么想？
translation:
My parents have been working in Crimea on and off since 2021, and I lived there with them for a while. They choose to go to Crimea because they like the place and can get higher salaries here. My mother, for example, was an engineer and there was construction going on in Crimea and Russia was investing a lot of money there. In Crimea, my mother can earn $1,500 a month (approximately RMB 10,785).
There are many different people in Crimea, Russians, Ukrainians, Belarusians and other foreigners, and we can chat together. But the interesting thing is, did you know that there is a word called "Крым крымчан"? The word means "Crimea for Crimeans" and many people born here think they are just Crimeans. They know and think Crimea is part of Russia. But if you ask them whose Crimea belongs, most people will answer that Crimea belongs to the Crimeans.
During Soviet times, Ukraine was part of the Soviet Union and a nation, just like Russia, but later our country began to be divided by external political forces. I don’t think we should fight, but I think we are a nation, just like Russians and Ukrainians, our ancestors fought together against Nazi Germany, but recently the Ukrainian authorities want to join NATO, which will pose a strong threat to Russia, so A terrible conflict occurred.
Maybe for Ukrainians my opinion is not pleasant, but what I say is that we are a people and we should not fight, any war is terrible and we should be like all people in the world friend.

title: ЦИК подсчитал 99,59% голосов: Путин набрал 87,33% на выборах президента
translation:
According to the results of counting 99.59% of the votes, Vladimir Putin received 87.33%. Nikolai Kharitonov (Communist Party of the Russian Federation) scored 4.3%, Vladislav Davankov (New People party) - 3.81%, Leonid Slutsky (LDPR) - 3.2%, follows from the CEC broadcast data
The Central Election Commission counted 99.59% of the votes in the Russian presidential election: Vladimir Putin received 87.33%, none of his rivals received 5%. From the CEC broadcast data it follows that Nikolai Kharitonov (Communist Party of the Russian Federation) scored 4.3%, Vladislav Davankov (New People party) - 3.81%, Leonid Slutsky (LDPR) - 3.2%.

Voting in the Russian presidential elections lasted from March 15 to 17. Following the election results, Davankov recognized Putin’s victory, Kharitonov announced the unity of Russians. After the completion of the vote, Putin named among the goals of his fifth presidential term the solution of the tasks of a “military special operation”* and the strengthening of Russia’s defense capability and army.

Material on the topic
The Ministry of Internal Affairs reported the initiation of 61 criminal cases during the presidential elections

Previously, Vladimir Putin won the presidential election with a smaller result - in 2018 he gained 76.69%, in 2012 - 63.6%, in 2004 and 2000 he was in the lead with 71.31% and 52.9%, respectively. Dmitry Medvedev won in 2008 with a score of 70.28%, Boris Yeltsin won in the second round in 1996 with a score of 53.82%.

The elected president's term of office will be six years. Kharitonov participated in the presidential elections for the second time (13.69% in 2004), Davankov and Slutsky for the first time. According to human rights activists, on March 17, more than 75 people were detained in 17 Russian cities. The Ministry of Internal Affairs reported the initiation of 61 criminal cases and 155 administrative protocols. 33 criminal cases were opened due to the bringing of dyes and flammable liquids into voting stations, Deputy Head of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Alexander Gorovoy said at the Central Election Commission.

* According to the requirement of Roskomnadzor, when preparing materials about a special operation in eastern Ukraine, all Russian media are required to use information only from official sources of the Russian Federation. We cannot publish materials in which the ongoing operation is called an “attack,” “invasion,” or “declaration of war,” unless this is a direct quote (Article 57 of the Federal Law on the Media). In case of violation of the requirement, the media may be fined in the amount of 5 million rubles, and the publication may also be blocked.

Broadcast of a Russian election event.
The announcement of election results.
Detention of individuals in Russia and annexed Ukrainian regions related to voting activities.
The invasion of Ukraine by Russia.

title: В России завершились выборы президента. Как прошло голосование, что происходило на участках и на границе с Украиной?
translation:
All Russians detained for damaging ballots are checked for cooperation with the Ukrainian special services. If it is confirmed that the detainees actually carried out the order of Ukrainian curators, they may face Article 275 (“Treason”) of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation. According to it, they can get up to 20 years in prison. So far, in most cases the matter concerns obstruction of the exercise of electoral rights or the work of election commissions (Article 141).

Commenting on cases of damaged ballots, Ella Pamfilova said that Ukraine and European states were involved in them. The head of the Central Election Commission indicated that calls demanding that ballots be spoiled came from call centers, most of which are located in territory controlled by Kyiv.

Deputy Chairman of the Russian Security Council Dmitry Medvedev warned Russians of responsibility for such offenses. He said that arson, vandalism and other acts at polling stations could be classified as treason.

Exercise of electoral rights.

title: 普京在总统选举中胜选,得票率为 87.22%,对俄罗斯意味着什么？
translation:
In Russia, each voter has only one vote, which is similar to what Americans call a "dictatorship."

The electoral system in the United States is mainly the Electoral College system, that is, the president is not elected directly by each voter, but by voting on a state-by-state basis. Voters in each state first vote for their state's Electoral College, which then votes for the presidential candidate. There are 538 electoral votes in total, and a candidate wins the election when he receives 270 or more.

Therefore, the U.S. electoral system is a complex mixture that combines elements of direct and indirect elections, as well as electoral rules formulated by each state, which brings flexibility to operations, but also contains some controversies and defect.

From this perspective, Russia is more democratic than the United States.

According to 92.01% of the votes that have been counted, Putin leads the other candidates by a wide margin with 87.22% of the votes, which means that Putin ended in victory in this presidential election.

translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on the 18th that Russia-China relations will continue to deepen and develop, achieve new achievements, and benefit the people of both countries.

 On March 18, Putin answered questions from reporters at the campaign headquarters in Moscow, the Russian capital. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
In the early morning of the 18th local time, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters, thanking voters for their support. When accepting questions from Xinhua News Agency reporters, he said that after years of development, Russia-China relations are very stable and highly complementary.
Putin pointed out that Russia and China have many points of convergence in economic, diplomatic and other fields. As far as the development of the Eurasian region is concerned, Russia-China relations are an important stabilizing factor, and the joint construction of the "Belt and Road" initiative proposed by China is very important.

 On March 18, in Moscow, the capital of Russia, a Xinhua News Agency reporter asked Russian President Vladimir Putin a question. Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Cao Yang
Putin spoke positively of China’s development achievements. He believes that China is achieving rapid development with great confidence and transforming into an innovative economy; China is increasingly active on the international stage and has achieved great success, and has many friends around the world.
Putin emphasized that Taiwan is an inalienable part of China; those attempts to provoke provocations around Taiwan and take various measures to retard China's development will undoubtedly fail completely.
According to data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time, of the 85% of votes that have been counted in this presidential election, Putin is significantly ahead of other candidates with 87.19% of the votes, and has actually won the presidential election.
The official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russian presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the final results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within 3 days after the election results are confirmed.

title: Президентские выборы в России: «Давайте не будем признавать легитимность Путина как президента», – заявил председатель ПАСЕ
translation:
Following the presidential elections in Russia, PACE President Theodoros Roussopoulos made the following statement today:

“A few minutes ago, the polling stations organized for the so-called “elections” in the Russian Federation closed and the exit polls were announced. The results were not particularly surprising. In fact, we have all known about this result for months. Vladimir Putin confirmed another term of office.

These elections are not considered legitimate. There were no real alternative candidates, no free media, no credible observers. Civil society is forced into silence. And most importantly, these elections were also held on the illegally occupied and annexed territory of Ukraine. All political opposition is brutally suppressed, and all critics of the regime are either imprisoned or expelled from the country. Tragically, the most vocal and popular leader of the opposition, Alexei Navalny, was killed in prison a month ago after being subjected to months of torture and inhumane treatment.

In such circumstances there can be no free and fair elections. Mr. Putin clearly has no democratic legitimacy.

This was confirmed by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe, which found that the procedure for granting Putin an even longer term of office violates Russian constitutional law and is contrary to long-established international legal principles.

title: 普京胜选！最新讲话回应这些问题
translation:
According to Xinhua News Agency, data released by the Russian Central Election Commission in the early morning of the 18th local time showed that among the 85% of votes counted in the Russian presidential election, current President Putin led other candidates by a wide margin with 87.19% of the votes, and actually won the election. presidential election.
Official voting for Russia’s eighth presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to Russia's presidential election rules, the person who gets more than 50% of the votes in the election is elected president. The Russian Central Election Commission will confirm the results of the presidential election no later than March 28 and announce them within three days after the election results are confirmed.
Public information shows that the 71-year-old Putin’s term as the current president of Russia will end on May 7, 2024. According to the Russian constitution, Putin can seek re-election for two terms until 2036 after the end of this term.

Win the election
According to Xinhua News Agency, Putin delivered a speech at the campaign headquarters in the early morning of the 18th, thanking all voters for their support. He said that Russia is a big family, the results of this election reflect the trust and expectations of voters, and all the country's tasks will be completed. Russia will move forward and become more solid, stronger and more efficient.
In his speech, Putin also mentioned the challenges ahead. He first thanked the soldiers on the front lines of the conflict and said that Russia's current priority must be to complete special military operations. He said that the Russian army has taken the lead in the war, and if Western troops appear in Ukraine, it may push the world to the brink of World War III. Putin also emphasized that as long as the country is united, no one can suppress Russia.
In addition, Putin also talked about the relationship between Russia and China, saying that Sino-Russian relations are a stabilizing factor and that China is very successful on the global stage. He is convinced that the relationship between the two countries will be stronger in the next few years.
Compared with previous elections, this election has a number of "firsts" records, such as the first multi-day continuous voting and the first combination of on-site voting and remote electronic voting. At the same time, during this election, opinion polls will also be open on multiple days.
In addition to Putin, there are three candidates in this election. The latest results show that Kharitonov of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation ranked second with 4.24% of the vote, Davankov of the Russian New People's Party ranked third with 3.99% of the vote, and Slutsky of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia ranked third. Ranked fourth with 3.16% of the vote.
It is worth noting that according to the current incomplete statistical results, Putin's vote share has far exceeded the results of the 2018 general election. At that time, Putin's vote rate was 76.69%.

There are still these challenges in the next six years
Putin also said that he will continue to promote national development in the new term. He said that all the main tasks of national development have been elaborated in the recent State of the Nation Address to both houses of parliament, and he will do his best to achieve the set goals.
In his annual State of the Union address before the election, Putin outlined in detail Russia's political and economic goals for the next six years. For example, in the next six years, Russia's non-resource and non-energy exports should increase by two-thirds; by 2030, Russia's imports as a share of GDP should drop to 17%; and the share of Russian domestic high-tech products in the domestic market should increase by 1.5 times. At the same time, Putin also mentioned that Russia should vigorously develop AI.
Regarding this State of the Union address, Zhang Hong, a researcher at the Institute of Russian, Eastern European and Central Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, told China Business News: "By introducing future plans for domestic and foreign affairs, Putin conveys confidence to Russian voters and outlines the overall plan for Russian society."
The latest data released by the Russian Federal State Statistics Service show that the Russian economy will grow by 3.6% year-on-year in 2023, reaching 171.04 trillion rubles; the real wages of Russian people will increase by 7.8% year-on-year; the real disposable income will increase by 5.4% year-on-year. The latter two are the highest in the past five years. In addition, Russia's unemployment rate was 3.2% last year, the lowest level since 1992.
Looking to the future, Wei Jinshen, associate professor at the School of Politics and International Relations at Lanzhou University, believes that Russia will face many major challenges in the next six years, such as how to deal with the international and regional environment worsened by the Russia-Ukraine conflict, thereby creating a better environment for Russia's development. Favorable space; at the same time, the Russian government also needs to consider how to promote the optimization and adjustment of the domestic economic structure to cope with the impact of sanctions on the domestic economy and transform the current wartime economy into a normal economy.
In addition, what measures to take for social mobilization and strengthening the unity of Russian domestic society are also one of the important tasks of Putin's new government in the future.
input:

title: 中俄独裁者互祝连任 “友谊”会突变吗？ | 普京 | 习近平 | 俄罗斯 | 大纪元
translation:
"Now the world is undergoing a wave of transformation, such as requiring human rights and green supply chains in the economy. Many countries have begun to be wary of Chinese products on the grounds of national security. Everyone is emphasizing the need to protect China. De-risking, I think for Russia too.”
Although China and Russia have high-profilely promoted their strategic partnership, Russia recently commemorated the 55th anniversary of the victory of the "Damansky Island" defense battle involving the border conflict between China and Russia in a high-profile manner.
The "Damansky Island" defense battle commemorated by Russia is called the "Zhenbao Island Self-Defense Counterattack" or the Zhenbao Island Incident in China.
Zhenbao Island is a small island on the Chinese side of the center line of the main channel of the Ussuri River, the Sino-Russian boundary river. After the end of World War II, it was once occupied by the Soviet Union. In March 1969, three bloody armed conflicts broke out between China and the Soviet Union on Zhenbao Island on the border, resulting in heavy casualties on both sides. After the conflict, China actually took control of Zhenbao Island. The Zhenbao Island incident caused a complete fallout between China and the Soviet Union at that time.
The "Damansky Island" defense battle commemorated by Russia is a hotly discussed topic in mainland China's Weibo, Douyin and WeChat groups, but the Chinese Communist Party is officially silent.
Weng Mingxian said that the CCP has remained silent on Russia’s commemorative issues because the CCP believes that the biggest source of threats lies in the Sino-Indian border, as well as the territorial disputes with ASEAN’s Vietnam and the Philippines in the South China Sea, coupled with the United States’ freedom of navigation on the high seas in the South China Sea. These are the key points, so the CCP must stabilize the north.
Lai Rongwei said that the current contradiction between the CCP and Russia is not the main contradiction, but there are also hidden conflict factors.
He gave an example: On the issue of the Russia-Ukraine war, the CCP actually helped Russia economically and politically, but on the surface it maintained false neutrality because it also knew that if it supported Russia too much, its legitimacy in the international community would be compromised. very bad. But the CCP’s false neutrality also makes Russia unhappy. “Can’t Russia’s Putin and Russian politicians see this?”
Earlier this month, the British Financial Times reported on a leaked confidential Russian military document, which revealed Russian military drill scenarios in response to an invasion by the Chinese Communist Party and described when to use nuclear weapons against the Chinese Communist Party.
National security threat expert Craig Hooper wrote in Forbes that the leaked documents show that Russia is acutely aware that border "friendships" can change quickly.
input:
Commemoration of the 55th anniversary of the Damansky Island defense battle between China and Russia.
Military battle.
Russian illegal occupation of Ukrainian territories.

title: Результаты выборов президента России–2024. Главные цифры
translation:
The Russian Central Election Commission summed up the results of the presidential election. The number of votes cast for Vladimir Putin in the country does not reach 90%, and in some regions it has exceeded this mark. An unprecedented turnout was also recorded. The main figures, trends, records are in the Kommersant material.

Record turnout
According to the head of the Central Election Commission of the Russian Federation, Ella Pamfilova, the turnout in the presidential elections of the Russian Federation in 2024 was a record in the modern history of Russia. It amounted to 77.49% (87.6 million voters). Before this, the 70 percent mark was exceeded only once - in 1991.

The turnout at overseas sites was also significant. According to inconclusive data announced by the Russian Foreign Ministry, at least 372 thousand people voted. In the last elections, 474 thousand Russians voted abroad, but there were significantly more polling stations then - 401 versus 295.

The top Russian regions in terms of turnout are headed by Chechnya, the lowest figure is in the Komi Republic.

The final turnout on the federal DEG platform is 94%. This voting method was used by 4.4 million people in 28 regions. In Moscow, which uses its platform, almost 3.7 million people, or half of all voters, voted online.

The turnout among military personnel of the Russian Armed Forces was 99.8%. Polar explorers demonstrated 100% turnout at all stations and scientific expedition vessels in the Arctic and Antarctic. In Moscow pre-trial detention centers, almost 100% voted, everyone who expressed a desire. In total, 77 thousand people in custody and about 40 thousand people who have restrictions and prohibitions that prevent them from visiting polling stations exercised their rights in the FSIN system.

Outstanding results
After processing 100% of the protocols, Vladimir Putin scored 87.28% (76.3 million votes). He improved his last result by more than 10 percentage points, or 19.9 million votes.

Chechnya returned to first place in the top regions that provided the greatest support to the current president. The leader of 2018, Kabardino-Balkaria, is in fifth place. In addition, the top ten includes Crimea, Sevastopol and three out of four new regions. In the fourth, Kherson region, Vladimir Putin also received an impressive 88.12%, but for all participants in the top 10 his result was over 90%, and in Chechnya it was generally close to 100% (98.99%).
input:
Summing up the results of the Russian presidential election by the Central Election Commission.
Casting rigged ballots in a Russian election.
Recording of a record voter turnout.
Exercise of electoral rights.
Processing of election protocols in Russia.
Providing support.
Including occupied and annexed territories in Russian elections.

title: 普京大选“获胜”虽无悬念，最后投票日见“中午反普京”人潮
translation:
Two candidates who oppose the war in Ukraine and have real support from many Russians have been banned from running by the Kremlin, while Alexei Navalny, the opposition leader who poses the greatest threat to Putin, was in the Siberian Arctic last month. A sudden and mysterious death occurred in a prison within the circle.

Navalny's supporters called on Russian people to go to polling stations around noon on the last day of voting, but not to vote, but to show up to express silent protest. This protest action, which was approved by Navalny during his lifetime, was called the "Noon Anti-Putin" demonstration.

“Today we say something to all of us – noon is just the beginning,” Reuters quoted the “Noon Against Putin” demonstration initiative as saying in a post on social media Telegram early Sunday morning.

"Yes, some of us are scared. Yes, making this choice is not easy. But we are the people. We face our choices and responsibilities head-on," the initiative's post said.
Reuters reported that there were sporadic protests across Russia during the first two days of voting. Some polling places were set on fire and some ballot boxes were sprayed with paint. Russian officials have called those responsible for these actions "scum" and "traitors."

According to Reuters, at a polling station in the city of Novosibirsk in Russia's Far East, about 100 people came out to queue at noon on Sunday. In front of the polling stations opened by Russia overseas from Thailand to Sydney, from Bishkek to Tashkent, long lines of people also appeared at noon on Sunday. But it is unclear whether these people went to vote or showed up to protest.

When Putin launched the Ukraine war more than two years ago and issued a mobilization order in Russia, many young Russians of military age had already fled abroad, and many Russians who opposed Putin also left. Although Putin behaves like a strongman in Russia, the West generally views him negatively, calling him a dictator, a war criminal and a butcher.
input:
"Banning".

title: 俄罗斯总统选举：普京、权力与抗议的可能性 | 政治 新闻 | 半岛电视台
translation:
Russian President Vladimir Putin is almost certain to win his fifth election.
But according to the 2020 constitutional amendment, his previous term was "abolished". Under such circumstances, the election from March 15 to 17 will be his "first" election.
Putin announced his plans in December during an elaborate ceremony in the ornate Kremlin hall while speaking to Artyom Zoga, a separatist "colonel" from Ukraine's southeastern Donbass region. Candidacy.
At the time, Artem, perfectly uniformed and adorned with medals, told Putin, "On behalf of all our people, our Donbass, the land reunited with Russia, I ask you to participate in this election."
In response, an expressionless Putin replied, "I will not hide this. I have different ideas at different times, but now it is time to make a decision and I will run for office."
Putin has served four terms as president. He was elected president in 2000 and was re-elected three times in 2004, 2012 and 2018.
If Putin wins, as expected, he will remain in office for another six years, thanks to a constitutional amendment that extends his term. And this will also mark his fifth presidential term.
He can also be re-elected in 2030 for a sixth term.
This means he can rule until 2036, when he will be 83 years old.
The 71-year-old former KGB agent is already the longest-serving Russian leader since Soviet-era leader Stalin.
Putin's increasingly heavy-handed treatment of opponents, critics and anti-war protesters has been widely compared to Stalin's "Great Terror" campaign.
But to Kremlin loyalists, Putin is a political "genius" who has prevented the disintegration of Russia, ruled over billionaire oligarchs and crushed separatists in Chechnya.
input:
"Heroes of the Motherland Day" award ceremony in December 2023 at the Kremlin.
Putin winning his fifth presidential term.
Putin's extension of his rule over Russia through a rigged election.
Putin's re-election as President of Russia.

translation: In Belgorod, all three election days were under fire. title: 大选投票期间，俄称边境城市别尔哥罗德遭乌军炮击致2死3伤
translation:
According to a report on the CCTV News Client on March 16, on that day, the governor of Russia's Belgorod Region announced that the city of Belgorod was shelled by the Ukrainian army, resulting in 2 deaths and 3 injuries.
As the Russian general election enters the voting stage, Belgorod Oblast, located in the border area between Russia and Ukraine, has recently become the target of attacks by the Ukrainian army. Russian President Vladimir Putin said on the 15th that the Ukrainian army had repeatedly attempted to attack the Russian mainland in recent days without success, and that the Ukrainian army was trying to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting through attacks.
Putin said that from the 12th to the present, Ukraine has mainly used special forces, foreign mercenaries and Ukrainian army support troops to repeatedly try to enter Russian territory and cause many sabotage and terrorist attacks, four of which occurred in Belgorod. direction, together took place in the direction of Kursk.
Putin said that the Ukrainian army used more than 2,500 men, 35 tanks and 40 armored vehicles for this purpose, but failed, and as a result, it lost 60% of its personnel and more than 50% of its armored equipment.
He also emphasized that the above-mentioned actions of the Ukrainian army are "meaningless" from a military perspective and "criminal acts" from a humanitarian perspective. Their purpose is to disrupt the Russian presidential election voting process and "terrorize Russian civilians in areas bordering Ukraine" ".
Official voting for the 2024 Russian presidential election will be held from the 15th to the 17th. According to the Russian President’s website, Putin participated in the presidential election vote online on the 15th.

The death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·议题｜参军、跳槽、养娃……“我们在同一条船上”
translation:
According to the Russian federal budget plan, Russia's defense spending in 2024 will increase by nearly 70% compared with 2023. Defense and security spending combined are expected to account for about 40% of all budget spending. This is the first time that Russia's military spending has exceeded social spending. .
The substantial growth in defense spending and manufacturing related to military operations has largely played a role in promoting Russia's economic development. According to Russian official data, as of the end of 2023, Russia's GDP will increase by 3.6% compared with 2022. In addition to growing consumer demand and increasing adaptation to Western sanctions, the growth of manufacturing is also an important driver of Russia's economic growth.
According to estimates by Alexander Isakov, an economist at VTB Capital, manufacturing growth will contribute 1.2 percentage points to Russia’s GDP growth in 2023, and about half of this will come from companies closest to the military-industrial complex. Metal, electronic equipment and transportation manufacturing and other fields.
Against this background, Russian military-industrial enterprises’ demand for personnel has increased rapidly. Putin said in February this year that the Russian military-industrial complex currently includes 6,000 companies with a total of 3.5 million employees. In just one and a half years, the Russian military-industrial complex has created 520,000 new jobs.
According to Yuri, since the main buyers of steel are still Western countries and military demand is relatively small, his company's overall turnover has still declined to a certain extent. However, Yuri's salary did not decrease as a result. On the contrary, his income is increasing. Yuri explained that this is inseparable from the labor shortage problem that Russia is currently facing.
As one of the early people affected by Russia's delayed retirement policy and a practitioner in military-related industries, 56-year-old Yuri has a deep understanding of Russia's long-term demographic crisis and the current labor shortage. He was supposed to retire at the age of 60, but now he still needs to continue working for 9 years.
Yuri mentioned that continuing to work after retirement is very common in Russia. This way people can earn more money on top of their pension. After delaying retirement, the time during which they can receive "double salary" is shortened.
In addition to the demographic crisis, Russia's labor shortage has become increasingly serious due to the impact of military mobilization after the Russian-Ukrainian conflict and a new wave of "immigration." According to a latest research report released by the Russian Academy of Sciences, Russia's labor gap will reach 4.8 million people in 2023, and this problem is becoming a constraint on Russia's economic development.
"The shortage of labor forces employers to pay higher wages in order to retain employees." Yuri explained.
According to relevant data on the Russian labor market, the current salary levels of mechanics, welders and other employees in Russian military factories have exceeded that of many ordinary white-collar workers. In pursuit of better treatment, personnel previously engaged in civilian production are moving to related companies in the machinery manufacturing field, including the military industry sector. Even so, Oksana Dmitrieva, the former minister of the Russian Ministry of Labor and Social Policy, once said that the current labor shortage problem in military industry, machinery manufacturing, metal processing and other fields is still the most prominent.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
Incidents during voting
The Electoral Commission of the Kherson region on Friday reported attacks on premises in the city of Kakhovka and in the village of Brilyovka, Aleshkinsky district, where precinct commissions were located. “We managed to avoid casualties in Kakhovka. There are victims in Brilyovka, they are being provided with assistance,” the election commission noted.
On Sunday in Perm, an explosion occurred on the territory of a polling station in the House of Culture, the regional Ministry of Territorial Security reported. A woman brought a large firecracker into the building and exploded it in the toilet. According to Baza, the woman is 64 years old and her arm was torn off.
In St. Petersburg on Friday, a girl threw a Molotov cocktail at the sign of one of the precinct commissions, said the head of the local election commission, Maxim Meiksin. The fire was put out.
In addition, in Kogalym, Khanty-Mansiysk Autonomous Okrug, a woman tried to set fire to a stationary ballot box using a Molotov cocktail (video footage from the polling station is below). She was detained and the fire was extinguished. The ballots and equipment were not damaged, the press service of the Ugra Electoral Commission clarified.

In the south-east of Moscow, a woman at one of the polling stations set fire to a voting booth with a flammable liquid, the Investigative Committee reported. A criminal case has been initiated under Art. 141 (obstruction of the work of election commissions).
At another polling station in Moscow, a girl poured a dye into a ballot box. A case was also opened against her under Art. 141 of the Criminal Code. According to Deputy Chairman of the Moscow City Election Commission Dmitry Reut, there were about 100 ballots in this ballot box.

On the morning of March 15, similar incidents occurred in Borisoglebsk in the Voronezh region. According to Notebook Borisoglebsk, trash cans in the South-Eastern and Northern microdistricts of the city were filled with green paint. The Borisoglebsk TEC reported that members of the precinct commission sealed the slots in the boxes and installed other ballot boxes, and voting continued. They will later check to see if the colored ballots can be considered valid.
In Yekaterinburg, a professor at the Ural Federal University, Emilia Nosova, tried to spoil the ballots at one of the city’s polling stations. She had some brilliant green with her. A Ura.ru source in law enforcement agencies claims that the UrFU professor came to the polling station with brilliant green under pressure from unknown persons, to whom she had previously transferred 15 million rubles.
input:
Throwing objects at Russian election-related sites.
Detention of individuals in Russia and annexed Ukrainian regions related to voting activities.
Ballot boxes filled with green paint or brilliant green.
Spoiling ballots during elections.

title: ЦИК РФ: Путин побеждает на выборах с рекордным результатом
translation:
"Noon against Putin"
Despite threats from the prosecutor's office, offers to vote via the Internet and fakes about the cancellation of the event, thousands of Russians came to the polling stations at 12 o'clock on Sunday. Earlier, the opposition called on those who disagree with the policies of the current President of the Russian Federation to take part in the “Noon against Putin” action.

In Moscow, queues of people wishing to vote at noon were observed at several polling stations. At MIPT, where Boris Nadezhdin taught and voted, students began chanting his name. He was not allowed to participate in the elections after the Central Election Commission invalidated part of the signatures collected in his support in February.

Abroad, at Russian diplomatic missions, by midday there were hours-long queues of Russians wanting to vote. In some cities they had to wait in line for 6-7 hours.

One of the largest events abroad took place in Berlin. According to some estimates, about two thousand people took part in it.

Alexei Navalny's widow Yulia came to the Russian Embassy in Germany at noon to vote, like dozens of other Russians. Mikhail Khodorkovsky was also seen at the rally.
input:
Chanting names and slogans at political events.
Opposition candidates were not allowed to run in the election.
Collecting signatures for election candidacy.
Voting at Russian diplomatic missions abroad.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·特写｜堡垒、新领土和“变得更像俄罗斯”的小村庄
translation:
In a documentary filmed by an independent Russian director for German television, another town named Yelniya also shows some features of contemporary "deep Russian society."
There, the legacy of the Soviet Patriotic War dominates the town’s public life, with almost all festivals, ceremonies and gatherings centered around that war. More than 80 years ago, in order to buy time to prepare for the battle to defend Moscow, which was crucial to the survival of the Soviet Union, the Red Army troops held on to Yelniya for many days at an absolute disadvantage, and suffered heavy casualties. After the fierce battle, the Red Army finally slowed down the advance of the Nazi German army. Behind rows of fallen Red Army soldiers, a defense line to defend Moscow was built.
However, what happened more than 80 years ago is too far away after all, and most of the direct parties have passed away. Over the years, the town has gradually declined and become dilapidated, losing young people and its Soviet-era infrastructure has become seriously outdated. For the residents who remain there, time seems frozen.
But the conflict between Russia and Ukraine broke this state. After February 24, 2022, Russian media continued to enter this originally quiet town. The purpose of their reporting was clear: to focus on the glorious history of the town and to use the sacrifices of the Soviet Red Army to arouse the patriotic enthusiasm of the Russian public. As a result, the popularity of the town began to gather again, and some people even made special trips to visit the war relics.
In other words, the war burning in Ukraine seems to have revived the town of Yelnya, which has been dormant for decades. Residents feel that the attention of the outside world, and even the whole country, has returned to Yelniya.
"They say the military is not a woman's job, but no job is inherently a man's job. We can dig trenches, we can treat the wounded, and we bring combat effectiveness!"
Masha, a 16-year-old girl from Yelniya, wore a camouflage uniform and sang "Women in Uniform" dedicated to the Soviet female soldiers in the Great Patriotic War. She received bursts of applause at the Victory Day performance in the town. She is an undoubted good student in the small town middle school. She always sits in the front row in class. Whenever the teacher asks a question, she rushes to raise her hand to answer the question. What she is best at is retelling the course of the Great Patriotic War in history classes. She knows the time, place, and course of those major battles by heart.
With the support of her parents, teachers and townspeople, Masha has been rehearsing hard, hoping to win a place in the city's youth song competition and leave a good impression on the authoritative judges from Moscow. However, under the competition of many popular music programs, Martha, who participated in the competition for the first time, was a little nervous, and in the end she failed to achieve the good results expected. Alongside girls of the same age who sang Western songs and wore sexy and fashionable clothes, Martha, who was wearing a military uniform and a St. George ribbon, did not forget to cross her chest and pray before going on stage. Her temperament seemed very out of place.
input:
Putin's continued dominance of Russia.
Military battle.
Advancing deeper into Ukraine.
The passing away of individuals, including Mr. Navalny.
Return of Russia to the international stage.
singing Soviet Union songs by various individuals and groups.

title: Путин побеждает с 87,28 % голосов: как прошли самые скандальные выборы в истории России. Главные итоги выборов президента России 2024
translation:
On the other hand, Russia's traditional partners and allies, such as China, India, Turkey, Iran and the CIS countries, rushed to congratulate Putin on his re-election and praised the level of organization of the elections. The leaders of the DPRK, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Nicaragua and Venezuela even called Putin’s victory a contribution to stability and security throughout the world.

Interestingly, in some Western capitals and megacities - from The Hague and Vilnius to Tel Aviv and New York - it was not Putin who won in foreign polls, but the candidate from the “New People”, Vladislav Davankov. However, this did not make a difference for the entire Russian diaspora abroad (about 2 million voters) - Putin scored more than 70% there too, according to the State Automated Information System “Vybory”.

The Russian Foreign Ministry called the turnout abroad “unprecedented” - 372 thousand people. Below is a photo of a line of people wishing to vote outside the embassy in Berlin.
input: China congratulating Putin on his re-election.

title: 俄罗斯大选2024·现场｜战时选举的低调氛围与稳步推进的政治进程
translation:
It’s the Year of the Dragon again, and I have another opportunity to watch the Russian election live. The author got up early on the first day of the election on March 15, walked 20,000 steps in Moscow city walk to observe the city, and went to three election sites near the subway station "Belarussky Station", Tverskaya Street and Michiulin Street. The polling stations also did not miss the various cultural activities being held in the city center and Red Square. Compared with 2012, this election has essentially unchanged parts, but everything is very different from 12 years ago.
Inaccessible polling stations and bustling "Malaysian Days"
The first thing that can be felt is that to outside observers, voting sites are becoming more closed and less open. The general election voting sites 12 years ago may be set up in the public areas of the main university building or inside residential areas. Foreigners will not be restricted in entry and exit. In addition to the curtains being drawn when entering the station to vote, they can follow the flow of people even if they are not voting. Go inside the polling station to observe the situation. In addition, on the 2012 election day, there was a rally gathering to canvass votes in Victory Park. Thousands of people even started queuing from the subway station passage. Parties gave speeches in the open space of the park, which was very lively.
Today, there are only a few crowds in the park square, mostly Chinese tourists or Russian student groups who come for patriotic education. The voting sites are no longer fully open and free to enter and exit. You need to enter your residential address accurate to the house number to find the corresponding polling station address on the Federal Election Commission's official website, and the process of selecting "observation samples" becomes more complicated.
In addition, polling stations are often set up in public educational institutions (i.e., state budget education institutions, for example, the three polling stations selected today are all municipal elementary schools or art schools), with their own access control and security facilities, and are naturally isolated. The curious gazes of the crowd. The polling station near Tver Street is located on the ground floor of a historical building, but there are card access controls and security guards at the door. When I saw a sudden flash of an exotic face, I asked if I could come in out of curiosity if I said I would not vote. Immediately afterwards, I received a polite but decisive rejection.
The polling place near the Belarus station was relatively lively, with people coming in and out from time to time. However, there were security guards stationed on the long road from the gate to the station entrance. They could only guard the door and occasionally catch people who had just cast their votes to ask about the situation. Some young people generously said that they "voted for Putin", but some middle-aged couples faced our questions and joked with a little caution, "This is our secret" (Это тайна наша).
Polling place near metro station Belorussky.

title: Выборы президента России. Главное
translation:
Pamfilova stated that “no Bolshevik replacement” of elections at polling stations with online voting “is not expected and cannot be.” “They will coexist together,” she said.
61 criminal cases were opened during the election period, First Deputy Head of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Alexander Gorovoy reported to the Central Election Commission. The majority of cases were brought under articles of knowingly false reporting of a terrorist attack and obstruction of the exercise of voters' rights. 155 administrative protocols were also drawn up.
Roskomnadzor said it blocked or deleted 1.3 thousand resources and publications with calls to participate in uncoordinated actions during the elections.
In several regions, citizens who tried to interfere with the elections were arrested. Thus, in St. Petersburg, a court arrested a girl who threw a Molotov cocktail at the entrance to a polling station. A girl was arrested in Moscow for pouring liquid into a ballot box. In Yekaterinburg, the court arrested a professor at the Ural Federal University for a similar reason: a woman was detained on March 16 after attempting to spoil ballots at one of the city’s polling stations. She had some brilliant green with her.
A man threw two Molotov cocktails into the courtyard of the Russian Embassy in Chisinau. Voting is underway in the Russian presidential election at the diplomatic mission. The man was detained, the polling station continued to work.
